I understand from the Registrar General that he has investigated the circumstances of this birth registration. He has advised that the birth referred to by the Deputy was registered some weeks after the birth in 1990 and a birth certificate was available at that point.

I am informed by the Registrar General that an application for his authority to re-register the birth to include paternity details was received in his office on 14 May 1996. The document furnished lacked certain detail and it was necessary for his office to write to the mother seeking clarification. When the necessary information is received the application will be processed with due despatch.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rehabilitation Treatment.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the lengthy waiting lists at the Rehabilitation Hospital, Dún Laoghaire, County Dublin; the steps, if any, he proposes to take to improve the situation for patients urgently in need of rehabilitation treatment; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the nature and extent of services for people with brain injuries; his views on whether there is a considerable need for comprehensive rehabilitation services for these people; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 219 and 222 together.

MainHeading.P: Rehabilitation services, including services for people with brain injuries, are provided by the National Rehabilitation Hospital. My Department's 1996 allocation to the NRH is £6.202 million.

In April this year I was pleased to officially open a new head injuries unit at the NRH. The new facilities have meant that the number of beds available for people with head injuries has increased from 23 to 34. Separate wards for adults and children have been created with specialised facilities for the more severely disabled patients. Nineteen additional staff have been recruited in the fields of physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech and language therapy, social work, psychology as well as nursing. This has facilitated the development of a multi-disciplinary approach to the rehabilitation of the patient. I was pleased that my Department was able to make £150,000 capital available towards the development of the new accommodation and £300,000 ongoing funding for the running of the facilities.

I also recently approved a capital grant of £50,000 for the development of a pre-discharge unit on the grounds of the hospital. This unit is for patients immediately prior to discharge to rehabilitate them to the outside environment. I have also recently agreed to the establishment of a hospital development project team at the NRH which will comprise representatives of the hospital and officials of my Department. This team will look at all aspects of service provision at the hospital and plan future improvements.

A wide range of services is available for people with brain injuries in addition to those provided at the NRH. In line with the Government's commitment to disability issues, additional funding has been made available for the development of services for people with physical and sensory disabilities, including people with brain injuries. As a result, improvements have taken place in a number of services, including home support services, community based therapy services, provision of aids and appliances and additional grants to voluntary organisations.

The review group on services for people with a physical or sensory disability is currently examining the service needs of people with disabilities, including the provision of rehabilitation services. Its report is expected to be published very shortly at which time I will make a decision about the development of rehabilitation services as part of my overall decision on the appropriate development of services generally for people with disabilities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Office of Health Gain.

Qst.Quest: the role and operations of the office of health and social gain established in each health board; the effectiveness of the offices; the plans, if any, he has for the future expansion of their roles; the extent to which they have concerned themselves with issues of concern to people with disabilities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I presume the Deputy is referring to the office of health gain, a partnership which has been set up by the chief executive officers of the eight health boards to facilitate joint working by the boards. I am asking the office to send the Deputy details of its activities.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of any financial settlements or extraordinary severance arrangements entered into with civil servants in his Department or with public servants in State agencies under the aegis of his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Since the appointment of the present Government, and my appointment as Minister for Health in December 1994, there have been no extraordinary severance or early retirement packages obtained by staff in the Department. Severance and early retirement packages are entered into with public servants in State agencies under the aegis of the Department only in exceptional circumstances, and any such packages are in line with the superannuation guidelines applicable to public servants.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Speech and Language Therapists.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: when he will respond to the ruling from the European Court of Justice regarding speech and language therapists; his views on whether they provide a vital role in dealing with a range of communication disorders; the plans, if any, he has to resume negotiations on pay; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The European Court of Justice ruling referred to by the Deputy relates to a case which was forwarded to the court by the UK Court of Appeal from a decision of the UK Employment Appeals Tribunal. It is a particularly complex case and the European Court of Justice ruling has yet to be implemented in the UK. An independent expert had to be appointed to carry out a job evaluation exercise and his report will not be made available until September 1996 at the earliest, following which time the employers' defence will be considered by the UK Employment Appeals Tribunal.

I am satisfied that the ruling has no implications for the pay claim currently being pursued by IMPACT on behalf of the profession. A meeting was held on Wednesday, 26 June 1996, between management and union, under the auspices of the Local Government Staff Negotiations Board. Both sides explored whether the provisions of the joint Government-ICTU statement of 15 May 1996 could usefully be applied to resolving the impasse in the negotiations.

MainHeading.P: I am pleased to advise the House that both sides have agreed to re-enter direct negotiations with a view to achieving a mutually satisfactory conclusion as soon as possible. Therefore, it would be inappropriate for me to comment further at this stage.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has for dealing with the current crisis in the provision of services for the mentally handicapped.

the proposals, if any, he has to make additional funding available to tackle the inadequacy of residential places available to mentally handicapped people; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea) Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 225 and 226 together. As the Deputies are aware, substantial additional funding has been made available in recent years for the development of services to persons with a mental handicap. Additional funding of £56.58 million was invested in the services in the period 1990-96 which has enabled health boards to put in place over 1,000 additional residential places and 2,200 day care places.

I am satisfied that this additional annual funding has made a significant impact on the number of persons with a mental handicap awaiting services. However, I am aware that more needs to be done. The Government is committed under both the health strategy document “Shaping a Healthier Future” and “Government of Renewal” to the continued development of the service as resources become available. That commitment is reflected in my decision, with my colleague, the Minister, to prepare a five year service development plan to meet the needs identified by the national mental handicap database. I expect the plan to be ready later this year.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, which has been made in each health board towards implementing the recommendation of the Needs and Abilities report concerning the establishment of a comprehensive database; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea) Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea)
Speaker.P: A mental handicap database has been established at regional level in each health board area as recommended by the report of the Review Group on Mental Handicap Services, “Needs and Abilities”. In addition, a national mental handicap database has been established in my Department based on the eight regional databases.

The database will provide my Department with a more accurate estimate of both current and future service requirements. A researcher was recruited to the health research board in late 1995 to work on validation and processing of the information from the various health board regions. Details of the initial information from the database were recently published. I will forward a copy of the article to the Deputy under separate cover.

As the Deputy is aware, it is my intention, with my colleague, the Minister, to prepare a five year service development plan for the services to persons with a mental handicap to meet the needs identified by the database. I expect the plan to be ready later this year at which time the database will also be launched.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the efforts, if any, which have been made to ensure that section 65 grants for voluntary organisations are awarded in a timely and transparent manner; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Decisions on the agencies to be awarded section 65 grants are, in the first instance, a matter for the health boards taking into account the local needs and priorities for services. My Department provides monthly cash flows, including section 65 grants, to the health boards which enable the boards to meet their due debts on time. In addition, officials of my Department have regular meetings with health board management to ensure that expenditure and payments are in accordance with the approved determination. If the Deputy wishes to provide me with details of any particular difficulties of which she has become aware, I will have the matter taken up with the health boards.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Child Care Services Review.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the current status of the review of child health services; whether the review will be published; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): As part of the review of the child health service a consultant was engaged to carry out a fundamental examination of all aspects of the service. This examination has been completed and his report is currently being considered in the Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Patients with Speech and Hearing Impairments.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: his views on the general lack of expertise of medical personnel in dealing with non-speaking patients; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am aware of concerns about the need for effective communication with people with speech and hearing impairments and this issue is being examined by the review group on services for people with a physical or sensory disability in its forthcoming report.

Following tripartite discussions between the National Rehabilitation Board, the National Association for the Deaf, and the Irish Deaf Society to consider the provision of a deaf interpretative service, I have received a lottery application for funding to which I am currently giving careful consideration. In addition, a grant of £11,000 was provided in 1995 by the Eastern Health Board to NAD and the Irish Hard of Hearing Association for lip-reading services.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Services for People with Disabilities.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the number of people with disabilities receiving day and residential care in each county and each health board area; the number of persons waiting for these services; and the plans, if any, he has for meeting this shortfall.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The information requested by the Deputy on services for people with physical disabilities is not readily available in my Department. I will ask the health boards to put together this information in so far as it is available to them and I will forward it to the Department in due course. As the Deputy will be aware there is no database on physical disability. I understand that the forthcoming report of the review group on physical and sensory disability will recommend the establishment of such a database.

MainHeading.P: The review group is examining all aspects of service provision for people with physical or sensory disabilities. This will include examination of the existing provision of services and identification of unmet needs across all health board areas. It is my intention, following publication of the report, to ask health boards to prepare local plans for implementing the report based on a total assessment of needs across the services in their areas.

In relation to services for persons with a mental handicap, this information is being compiled as part of the five-year plan for the development of services which I will be announcing later this year. At that time I will also be launching the mental handicap database which will provide the type of information requested by the Deputy.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the concern of many mothers that when their newborn child is diagnosed with a particular condition which may require more specialist care that they should be transferred with their child; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that this can be a particular concern of mothers of children with disabilities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Newborn babies requiring specialist referrals from maternity hospitals are, in the main, referred to Our Lady's Hospital for Sick Children, Crumlin. The hospital authorities are not aware of any specific concerns of mothers, as a group, in relation to their transferring with their newborn babies to the hospital.

Demand for parents' accommodation in the hospital is considerable and currently there are 55 parents' beds provided in a unit on the third floor of the hospital. Pressure on specialist beds has prevented the development of parent-child accommodation on wards.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that many parents of children with disabilities are not fully aware of their entitlements to assistance; the plans, if any, he has to deal with this situation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): At present a wide range of statutory and voluntary bodies provide information to people with disabilities and parents of children with disabilities. These include the health boards, National Rehabilitation Board, National Social Services Board and Disability Federation of Ireland. An information booklet “Information Guide to our Health Services,” which contains a section on services for people with disabilities, is widely available from my Department, health board offices, relevant organisations, libraries and the Internet. Separate information leaflets are also available on domiciliary care allowance and disabled persons maintenance allowance. In addition the Eastern Health Board has in place an information unit which operates as a one-stop shop for information on the full range of health services. This unit is open to a personal callers and can be contacted by a freephone number.

The review group on services for people with physical and sensory disabilities, due to report shortly, deals with all aspects of service provision for people with physical and sensory disabilities. The group's report will address the issue of information needs and will make recommendations so as to ensure that a coherent and comprehensive information service is available to everyone.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to address the issue of the gap in qualification ages between the cut-off for a domiciliary care allowance and a disabled person's maintenance allowance.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): There is no gap in the qualification ages for a domiciliary care allowance and a disabled person's maintenance allowance. DCA is paid by health boards in respect of children between the ages of two and 16 who are so severely physically or mentally handicapped that they require care and attention which is considerably in excess of that normally required by a child of the same age. Disabled person's maintenance allowance is the primary income support scheme operated by health boards for people between the ages of 16 and 66 who, because of their disability, are unable to work and are not in a position to maintain themselves in the community.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Health Nurse Service.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the level of the public health nurse service in each health board area; and the reviews, if any, which have been undertaken to ensure that they are providing the nursing care required by people with disabilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Public health nurses perform a dual role in the care of people with disabilities living in the community. They provide direct nursing care and advice on maintaining good health. They also supervise and co-ordinate the provision of support services. This role of the public health nurse has recently been reviewed as part of a broader review of the public health nurse service. A report is due shortly which, I understand, will confirm the important role of the public health nurse in supporting people with disabilities in the community. The report of the review group on services for people with physical and sensory disabilities will also identify the important role public health nurses currently play in the early identification of disability.
The number of public health nurses in each health board area is set out below.

MainHeading.P: Public Health Nurses in each health board area on 31 December 1995

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the nature and extent of the twilight nursing service available in each of the health board areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): A planned twilight nursing service which is run by the majority of health boards operates from 6 p.m. to 11 p.m. This service is provided as part of the services for the care of the elderly. In specific circumstances where nursing care is required outside of this age group, arrangements are made to cover such cases. The activities carried out by this service are a mix of technical nursing and procedures aimed at maintaining the activities of daily living. This service is operated by registered general nurses. In areas where there is not a planned twilight service arrangements are in place for public health nurses to provide nursing services, if required, during the hours from 6 p.m. to 11 p.m.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if he will undertake in each health board area a study of the therapy needs of children with disabilities, which have not been met, similar to that completed by the South-Eastern Health Board in 1995.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): As the Deputy is aware, the review group on physical and sensory disability is examining all aspects of service provision for people with physical or sensory disabilities. This will include examination of the existing provision of services and identification of unmet needs across all health board areas. It is my intention, following publication of the report, to ask health boards to prepare local plans for implementing the report based on a total assessment of needs across the services, including the therapy needs of children, in their areas.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the nature and extent of all permanent funding available for the provision of peer counselling services for people with disabilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Peer counselling services are currently being provided by the Irish Wheelchair Association. The Department of Social Welfare gave initial funding to assist in the establishment of the service which was officially launched in 1995. The Eastern Health Board has provided £10,000 funding in 1995 and in 1996. The board is committed to providing this grant on an annual basis. The Irish Wheelchair Association is involved in preliminary discussions with the remaining health boards with a view to providing peer counselling services on a nationwide basis. I understand that the training course for the peer counselling programme is funded by the EU under the Horizon (Disabled) Programme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Services for Persons with Autism.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the number of people with autism who are not receiving appropriate care provisions in each of the health board areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea) Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. O'Shea)
Speaker.P: The provision of services to persons with autism is a matter in the first instance for the relevant health board.

The detailed information sought by the Deputy is not immediately available to my Department. I have asked the health boards to forward it to my Department and I will communicate it to the Deputy as soon as it is received.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the current status of the report of the Review Group on Services for People with a Physical and Sensory Disability; the intended publication date; and the level of discussion he anticipates in respect of its recommendations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Following a consultative seminar earlier this year with service providers and users the report of the review group was re-drafted.

The review group met on 18 July to discuss the final draft report. A number of amendments is required following that meeting after which the report will be submitted to me. It is my intention to publish it without delay and following publication, to ask health boards to prepare local plans for implementing the report based on a total assessment of needs across the services in their areas.

Qst.Quest: if reports of the holiday closure of the Breast Screening Clinic at the Mater Hospital, Dublin 7, are correct; and if so, the steps, if any, he will take to prevent a recurrence of this distressing situation for so many women.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I understand from the Mater Hospital that mammography investigations are carried out by the breast screening unit. Most of the staff in this area work on a part-time basis. I understand that the unit has closed for four weeks to coincide with holidays and alternative cover for mammography investigations is being provided until the unit re-opens.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disabled Person's Maintenance Allowance.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if he will investigate an application lodged with the Southern Health Board for a disabled person's maintenance allowance in respect of a person (details supplied) in County Cork who is in ill health; and if he will recommend that the application be dealt with speedily.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Payment of disabled person's maintenance allowance in any individual case is a matter for the health board concerned. Accordingly, the Deputy's question has been referred to the chief executive officer, Southern Health Board with a request that he examine the matter and reply directly to the Deputy as a matter of urgency.

Qst.Quest: the number of nursing appointments to be made by the Midland Health Board at St. Loman's Hospital, Mullingar and the Lough Sheever Centre, Mullingar, County Westmeath over the next few weeks; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The Midland Health Board is responsible for the management of services and deployment of staff at St. Loman's Psychiatric Hospital, Mullingar, and the Louth Sheever Centre, Mullingar, County Westmeath. Current personnel policy for the health services provides that health agencies which are managing resources within their allocations may fill non-consultant posts, including nursing vacancies, without recourse to the Department.

The Midland Health Board has appointed seven staff nurses to permanent positions at St. Loman's Psychiatric Hospital since April 1995, and three further appointments are currently being processed. Some 12 permanent staff nurse appointments have been made at the Lough Sheever Centre, Mullingar, since a panel was created in October 1994. No further appointments are planned.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Herbal Medicines.

Qst.Quest: whether, in view of the evidence given to a recent inquest into the death of a woman and the possible link between her death and the taking of herbal medicines, he intends to investigate the matter further; the proposals, if any, he has to make regulations regarding the availability and distribution of such medicines; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I have examined the recent report of the inquest into the death of a woman referred to by the Deputy. The inquest was unable to establish conclusively the cause of death in this case. In addition to herbal remedies, the woman had also been taking a conventional medicine, naproxen, prescribed for her by her GP. Whilst the post mortem and the coroner's report suggest that the death was probably drug related, neither were able to indicate whether it was as a result of a rare reaction to the conventional medicines or a reaction to the herbal remedies.

MainHeading.P: It is important that I take this opportunity to stress the dangers in seeking to treat ailments by combinations of various medicines without seeking proper medical advice on the matter, because of the possibility of interactions between different medicines.

The controls governing the licensing and sale of all medical preparations are set out in the Medical Preparations (Licensing and Sale) Regulations, 1996. Herbal preparations may, in certain circumstances, be classified as medical preparations within the terms of the regulations. Products containing herbal ingredients are considered to be medical preparations when the labelling or accompanying or associated literature makes any preventative, curative or remedial claim, or any of the herbal ingredients presented is recognised as having medicinal properties. Where such a product is deemed to be a medical preparation it would be required to be the subject of a product authorisation as required by the regulations. All applications for product authorisations are assessed by the Irish Medicines Board to establish the safety, efficacy and quality of the product.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hepatitus C Research.

Qst.Quest: the amount of funding provided to the Royal College of Surgeons for research into hepatitis C; the reason for the delay in the publication of the results of the research; his views on the delay; and the steps, if any, he intends to take to expedite the publication of the research.

the assurance, if any, he can give to the victims of hepatitis C that the research work, carried out by former professionals at the Royal College of Surgeons, is now available to this group of women; the date of which it has been made available; if not, available to date, the date on which it will be made available; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 249 and 254 together.

No public funding has been provided to the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland for research into hepatitis C. The specific research to which I presume the Deputy is referring will, inter alia, contribute to a wider research project which is being supported by my Department and involves all six centres at which patients with hepatitis C are treated. The purpose of this project is to create an integrated clinical database. Work on the project is proceeding on schedule and no delays have occurred as a result of the matter to which the Deputy appears to be referring.
When this research is complete it is anticipated that its findings will be submitted for publication in line with usual scientific/medical research procedures.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy may also wish to know that as part of the package of health care agreed with interested parties, funding has been provided through the Health Research Board for research into heapatitis C. The closing date for receipt of application was 10 June 1996 and applications are still under consideration by the board.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hospital Waiting Lists.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the financial allocation to each health board under the waiting list initiative; the criteria under which these allocations were made; and the population per health board area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The details of the financial allocation to each health board area under the 1996 waiting list initiative and the population per health board area in 1991, the latest date for which figures are available, are set out on the table below:

MainHeading.P: The criteria under which these allocations were made to the various agencies as follows: record of achievement of the individual agency in reducing waiting times under previous waiting list initiatives; investment already made in designated specialities since waiting list initiative commenced; waiting times for patients who need procedures; price per procedure; size of fund available; and ease of access for treatment.

The waiting list initiative commenced in June 1993 when the Government provided £20 million to reduce waiting times in a number of target specialties where waiting times are considered excessive. The sum of £10 million was provided in 1994 and a further £8 million was provided in 1995. Since the first initiative commenced the total in-patient waiting list has been reduced from 40,130 in June 1993 to 27,752 in December 1995 which represents an overall reduction of 12,378 or 31 per cent over a period of 30 months.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the total number of people on waiting lists in the health board areas, for all hospitals and other such institutions under all procedures on 1 January 1995, 1 January 1996 and 20 July 1996; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The number of patients on hospital waiting lists in each health board area, for all hospitals and other such institutions under all procedures on 31 December 1994 and 31 December 1995, are set out on the attached tables. Waiting list figures are collected by my Department on a quarterly basis and, therefore, there are no figures available for 20 July 1996.

In June 1993, when the first waiting list initiative commenced, the total in-patient waiting list for specialties was 40,130. By 31 December 1995, this figure had been reduced to 27,752. Since it commenced the initiative has reduced the overall in-patient waiting list figure by 12,378 or 31 per cent over a period of 30 months. The Government has made an additional £7 million available in 1996 to allow work in reducing excessive waiting times to continue.

MainHeading.P: Total Public In-Patient Waiting Lists at 31 December 1994.
Total Public In-Patient Waiting Lists at 31 December 1995.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Clean Air Theatres.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the reason the clean air theatres at Merlin Park Regional Hospital, Galway are not being used on a regular basis; the date on which they will be commissioned; the total cost involved; the number of staff allocated to these theatres; the annual cost of this staff allocation; the number of operations that have taken place in these new theatres since they were opened for such operations; the reason they are not being used on a permanent basis; the action, if any, he proposes to take to rectify this matter; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The two clean air theatres in Merlin Park Regional Hospital opened in 1993. In order to facilitate this expansion in orthopaedic services, my Department provided the Western Health Board with additional moneys of £400,000 in 1994, and £70,000 in 1995.

I understand from the board that the total number of staff — medical, nursing, clerical and paramedical support — is 16, at an approximate annual cost of £300,000. Annual non-pay costs are in the region of £300,000 also. A total of 1,100 operations were carried out in the hospital in 1995.

I understand from the board that both clean air theatres are used for elective orthopaedic surgery, Monday to Friday, 9.00 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. Trauma procedures account for 70 per cent of the hospital's current orthopaedic workload and the trauma theatres are in use 24 hours a day, seven days a week. The board informs me that consultant anaesthetist cover is provided seven days a week for trauma work and this arrangement has affected the availability of anaesthetists for elective work. I understand that the board will be employing a locum anaesthetist to help alleviate this problem.

MainHeading.P: In this regard, I remind the Deputy that the planning and provision of elective orthopaedic procedures at Merlin Park Regional Hospital is a matter for the Western Health Board to address from within the resources available to it. My Department has recognised the need for the expansion of orthopaedic services at the hospital and this is reflected in the additional moneys made available to the board as outlined above. I am confident that the Western Health Board will identify ways of overcoming the present difficulties so that the facilities at the hospital can be fully utilised for the maximum benefit of orthopaedic patients.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Galway Hospice In-Patient Unit.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the continuing delay in providing the necessary financial resources for the utilisation of the in-patient unit at Galway Hospice; if the difficulties which he referred to on his recent visit to Galway have been resolved; if not, the action, if any, he proposes to take; the date on which the relevant funds will be made available; the amount of such funds; the number of beds to be made available in the hospice in 1996; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The proposed utilisation of the in-patient unit at Galway Hospice has been the subject of detailed discussions between representatives of the Western Health Board and representatives of the Galway Hospice Foundation. These discussions have now reached an advanced stage and I am confident that agreement will shortly be reached on the provision of funding by the health board to enable the hospice to open the in-patient unit on a mutually acceptable basis.

Qst.Quest: when a person (details supplied) in County Leitrim will be called for bypass surgery; if his attention has been drawn to the urgency of this case; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I understand the person in question was placed on the Mater Hospital's waiting list on 18 December 1995 and at this time the hospital is not able to give an exact date of admission. The scheduling of surgery is a matter for the clinical judgment of the consultant concerned, is based solely on the patient's condition and not on the length of time her or she spent on the waiting list. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - B. Tech Diploma.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the reason one of the stipulations for employment as a social worker in Irish hospitals is the need to have the higher diploma in social studies; the specific distinction between the acceptance of the diploma and the non-acceptance by the hospital authorities of the B.tech Diploma in social studies which is run by the vocational education committee in Inchicore, being a three year diploma course of a very high standard; the reason the B.tech. Diploma is not acceptable for working as a social worker within the health services under his Department; if there is no explanation for the non-acceptance of this particular diploma, if his Department will review its policy in this regard and clarify that the diploma is acceptable on the same basis that the higher diploma in social studies is acceptable for social worker employment in our hospitals; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): In July 1991, the then Minister for Health established a committee whose remit included reviewing the qualifications necessary for employment as a social worker in a health board.

The committee reported in March 1994 and recommended that those recruited to entry grade positions in social work under health boards should have a minimum entry qualification of four to five years combined academic and practice training and education, that is, an academic and a professional qualification. This recommendation was accepted. There is currently a limited number of degree and post-graduate courses available, in TCD, UCD and UCC which meet this professional standard.

MainHeading.P: I understand that the B. Tech Diploma was not one of the qualifications examined by the ad hoc committee. However, it is highly unlikely that the qualification would have fulfilled the academic and professional practice place requirements of a professional social work qualification. In the health boards and the voluntary hospitals which I tend to adopt qualification standards accepted by health boards, the recognised qualification for both recruitment and promotion over the past 16 years has been the professional qualification now known as the National Qualification in Social Work.

The committee, in its recommendations, also advised on the setting up of a permanent successor to itself, an advisory body in the form of a National Validation Body to oversee standards in social work training and education. This body, established in May 1995, is charged with assessing the equivalence of both national and non-national qualifications to the NQSW. I understand that if the holder of a B. Tech Diploma were to submit their qualification for assessment, the precise shortfall in course content and level of qualification would be detailed by the National Validation Body.
I am sure the Deputy will appreciate that it is essential that all those involved in the delivery and supervision of social work be appropriately qualified and experienced.

Qst.askee: Minister for Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: the total cost of surveys undertaken by the MRBI for his Department since January 1995; the number of such surveys undertaken; the costs incurred in respect of each survey; and the surveys, if any, which included a questionnaire to ascertain the level of support for political parties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor) Mervyn Taylor
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor)
Speaker.P: The MRBI undertook three surveys on behalf of my Department in the period since January 1995 at a total cost of £41,745. The surveys were conducted in March, October and November 1995 for the purpose and ascertaining public attitudes to divorce.

As is normal MRBI practice, each survey contained classification questions to enable the divorce data to be more effectively cross-analysed. The data was cross-analysed by responses to questions in each of the surveys on demographic factors, party support and referendum voting intentions. The cost each of the surveys undertaken its as follows: Market Research Opinion Survey, March 1995, £18,150; Divorce Campaign Research Monitor, October 1995, £11,797.50; Divorce Campaign Research Monitor, November 1995, £11,797.50.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.askee: Minister for Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: the current status of the working party on day-care for children; and the name and location of all day-care projects funded by schemes operated through his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor) Mervyn Taylor
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Equality and Law Reform (Mr. Taylor)
Speaker.P: There is no working party on day-care for children operating under the aegis of my Department. In 1994, however, I initiated a pilot childcare initiative which continues to operate. I introduced this initiative for the purpose of providing support for, and to facilitate, a limited number of innovative projects for the setting up, on a pilot basis, of childcare measures utilising the skills of suitably trained local people so as to enable local residents to avail of education, training, retraining and employment opportunities which they might otherwise be unable to undertake in the absence of a childcare facility. The initiative is targeted at designated disadvantaged areas and is to assist with start-up capital costs only.

The initiative is administered, on behalf of my Department, by Area Development Management Ltd., which is an independent company designated by the Government and the European Commission to support integrated local economic and social development in cooperation with relevant Area Partnership companies established by the Government in designated disadvantaged areas.
The name and location of all the projects which are being funded under the initiative are set out in tabular statement which I propose to have circulated with the Official Report.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Threat to Red Grouse Stocks.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the threat posed to red grouse stocks by the approval of commercial operations on the Knockmealdown Mountains; the plans, if any, he has to monitor the damage that may be caused to these species by such operations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: The principal conservation requirements of huntable species, including the red grouse, are met through the provision of a limited hunting season under section 24 of the Wildlife Act, 1976. Currently, the hunting season for red grouse is limited to the month of September and this restricts the hunting of the species by all hunters, both native and out-of-State. In addition, there are a number of additional controls imposed upon out-of-State hunters who form the principal market for commercial shooting-hunting operations in this country. The conservation controls imposed on such operations provide that shoot operators must submit details of their shooting rights to the National Parks and Wildlife Service of my Department for assessment of their shooting capacity. This ensures that lands are not overshot and hunting licences under the 1976 Act are issued by reference to this assessment. Shoot operators must also submit game bag returns at the end of each season and, in addition, National Parks and Wildlife Service rangers spot check shooting parties and inspect game bags. Hunters must hold a valid firearm certificate and hunting licence, and have the landowner's permission to hunt over the lands. Notices are also issued to all out-of-State hunters advising them of the general Irish hunting situation and rules.

The above controls apply to all commercial shoot operators and I am satisfied that through these controls no undue threat to the conservation of red grouse species will arise through hunting in the Knockmealdown Mountains.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Capital Expenditure.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the amount of capital moneys expended by his Department in each county in each of the years 1994 and 1995 and to date in 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Details of capital moneys expended directly by my Department in each county during 1994, 1995 and for the half year to 30 June 1996 are set out in Table 1 attached. The figures include expenditure by the National Heritage Council for the period to 9 July 1995, as, prior to the establishment of the heritage council as a statutory independent body on 10 July 1995, such payments came directly from my Department's Vote. Also included is expenditure in 1996 by former divisions of the Office of Public Works — the National Monuments and Historic Properties Service — which have now transferred to my Department. I have also included the comparative expenditure for 1994 and 1995, which, while paid out of the Office of Public Works Vote, was in respect of the operations of those heritage divisions which have now transferred.
Details of capital moneys expended by the Waterways Service are listed separately in Table 2 as much of the work carried out by this division overlaps county boundaries.

MainHeading.P: I should point out that the figures contained in Tables 1 and 2 do not refer to capital expenditure by bodies under the aegis of my Department where such expenditure is not included in my Department's Vote — for arts purposes, for example, through the Arts Council or broadcasting purposes through RTE.

In order to give greater clarity to the overall picture, however, I should also point out that I am responsible for expenditure not only through the Vote of the Department of Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht — including spending on heritage which prior to this year was channelled through the Office of Public Works Vote — but also for expenditure from EU Structural and INTERREG Funds.

Among significant cultural projects for which substantial funding has been provided or approved by me during the period in question are: Crawford Gallery, Cork, £1.8 million; Galway Theatre Project, £2.3 million; Hawkswell Theatre, Sligo, £0.344 million; Hunt Museum, Limerick, £0.9 million; Longford Theatre, £0.67 million.

Among major projects approved, commenced or completed in the heritage area were: Curvilinear Range Restoration, Botanic Gardens, Dublin, £4.7 million; Boyne Valley Visitor Centre, County Meath, £7.9 million; Kilmainham Gaol Visitor Centre, Dublin, £2.15 million; Purchase of Emo Court, County Laois, £1.5 million; Restoration of the Great Telescope, Birr, County Offaly, £1 million.

EU Structural Funding has also been approved by me for a number of major cultural capital projects in the national cultural institutions, which are not paid for through my Department's Vote, including: Collins Barracks, Dublin (Phase 1), £12 million; and Chester Beatty Library, Dublin, £5.4 million.

Finally, I recently approved funding in principle in excess of £13.3 million in respect of 24 projects under the Cultural Development Incentives Scheme, which is also underpinned by Structural Funding and will be a major source of support particularly aimed at developing arts infrastructure throughout the regions. The projects are located in Counties Donegal, Laois, Offaly, Westmeath, Tipperary, Clare, Kerry, Wexford, Mayo, Dublin, Roscommon, Cork, Galway, Limerick and Waterford.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Wildlife Bill.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if the owners of areas to be designated national heritage areas will be compensated where developments, such as forestry, will be prohibited due to the national heritage status, resulting in major financial losses due to the change in status; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the precise structure as regards identifying and designating areas to be classified as national heritage areas; the current state of progress with the process; the standing as regards developments in areas under consideration for designation as national heritage areas but where a final decision has not been reached; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the practical significance of the proposed natural heritage area designation of land; the limitations this will place on the use of land; the limitations this will place on the ability of persons to fence or otherwise alter the division of the land; the proposed processes for monitoring compliance with these requirements; and the role which State agencies may play in dealing with breaches of these requirements.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the significance of the area of scientific interest designation of land for the permitted use of such land; and the procedures for enforcing compliance with the requirement of the designation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Tógfaidh mé Ceisteanna Uimh. 280, Uimh. 281, Uimh. 297 agus Uimh. 298 le chéile.

I refer the Deputy to my replies to Questions Nos. 42 and 49 of 12 June 1996 and Question No. 128 of 2 July 1996. As I stated in those replies, I expect to be in a position to place a Bill to amend the Wildlife Act, 1976, before the House in the autumn. The Bill will, inter alia, set out the requirements for natural heritage areas and the question of compensation, if any, will have to be viewed in the light of those requirements. The Bill will also establish a formal system for hearing objections to NHA designations.

MainHeading.P: The proposed NHAs are areas which contain the best remaining examples of our native wildlife species and habitats. It is EU policy that any developments in receipt of grant aid should have no adverse impact on the environment. Developments in areas under consideration for NHA status that comply with planning law and meet any necessary grant regulations are not affected by the proposed NHAs. However, where it is considered that development proposals will damage the environment, the National Parks and Wildlife Service of my Department will object to those proposals.

With regard to the identification of NHAs, a survey has been undertaken by the NPWS of former areas of scientific interest to determine whether or not they should be proposed for NHA designation. The criteria used by NPWS in selecting sites which are proposed for designation are set out in Appendix I. These criteria are applied in the light of best current scientific knowledge.
APPENDIX I
Criteria for selection of NHAs:

(a) Protection of site will make a substantial contribution to the conservation of one or more species* which are considered vulnerable, rare or endangered in the site's locality, region, Ireland or Europe, and whose survival in the area depends on the protection of the area and the habitats contained in it.

(b) The site contains habitats which are judged to be rare or endangered in the site's locality or region, or in Ireland or Europe, or which, where they do occur, are normally to a much greater degree of damage or disturbance.
(c) It contains habitats which, if they were to be destroyed, could never be re-created or which could not be recreated within a reasonable time scale or at a reasonable cost.

(d) It warrants conservation on the grounds of its diversity of species, plant or animal communities, habitats or structural features — such diversity being judged by reference to other sites of a similar or related type.

(e) It contains geological or geomorphological features or land forms which are rare in its locality, region, Ireland or Europe, or which, where they do occur, are normally subject to a much greater degree of damage or disturbance.**

(f) it contains habitats, geological or geomorphological features, land forms or other natural features considered as good representative examples of their type with reference to the range of natural variation in such features.**

(g) It is one of a number of sites whose conservation is essential in order to conserve the full range of natural variation in a given species,* habitat type, geological or geomorphological feature or landform or other natural feature in Ireland.**

(g) Conservation of the entire area is essential on the grounds that it comprises a landscape unit which contains a number of natural features, the combined conservation value of which is greater by virtue of their occurence in one area.**
(i) It has the potential, if managed appropriately, to qualify under one or more of the criteria listed above, in a reasonable time scale and at reasonable cost.
(j) It is judged to warrant selection as an SPA or SAC under EU Directives.
* “species” is used as defined in the Wildlife Act, 1976 and includes sub-species and hybrids.
**Sites will be proposed for NHA designation on geological or geomorphological grounds on the advice of the Geological Survey of Ireland.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has for the excavation, preservation and protection of the Armada artefacts found off Streedagh Strand, Grange, County Sligo; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: The State's claim to ownership of the Spanish Armada wrecks and artefacts, off Streedagh, County Sligo, has been affirmed as a result of High Court and Supreme Court judgements. However, some matters are still the subject of litigation.

The drivers, who initiated the litigation, have continued to carry out a non-invasive survey of the site under licence and supervision of the National Monuments and Historic Properties Service of my Department.
Until such time as the current litigation has been concluded, my Department's resources will be concentrated on the protection and preservation of the wrecks and their artefacts in situ.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to my reply to Question No. 83 of 13 December 1995 (columns 1480 and 1481 of the Official Report for that date refer).

The issue raised by the Deputy is the responsibility of the RTÉ Authority and I have no statutory function in the matter. Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the reason an application for an EU grant, plus a State grant, for the proposed development of an Arts, Cultural and Heritage Centre in Scartaglen, County Kerry, which is in the heart of the Sliabh Luachra district in north west Cork and east Kerry, was not placed on the priority list by his Department for grant aid; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: I can confirm to the Deputy that an application was submitted to my Department for funding for this project under the Cultural Development Incentives Scheme which I am administering under the Operational Programme for Tourism. I should explain that some 170 applications were received by me for assistance under the first call for the CDIS, representing total funding demands of some £87 million. Since the total funds available to me under this first call was £14.7 million, the scheme was well over subscribed.

Based on the recommendations of the advisory committee which I appointed to assist in the evaluation process, I have recently made decisions on the selection of projects to be assisted from the applications received to date under the scheme.

The Deputy will appreciate that some very difficult decisions had to be made and that it simply was not possible for me to assist some worthwhile projects given the limited funding at my disposal. I regret that I was not able to include the Scartaglin project among the 24 projects to which assistance in principle has been offered under the scheme.

I should add, however, that it is intended to advertise this autumn for the submission of applications for the final stage of the CDIS, for which I expect to be able to allocate grant assistance of the order of £5 million towards successful projects. It will be open to project promoters to submit a new or revised application based upon the most up-to-date position pertaining in response to that advertisement.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts. Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: when the joint Northern Ireland full scale feasibility study on the restoration of the Ulster Canal will commence; when work is expected to be completed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)

At this stage, however, I cannot be specific as to when tenders are likely to be invited from consultancies interested in undertaking it or when the work is likely to be undertaken.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Advertising of Office of Public Works Positions.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the advertising of supervisory positions within the Office of Public Works; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: I assume that the Deputy is referring to the heritage service, which was formerly part of the Office of Public Works and now comes within my own Department.

The position is that supervisory positions within the industrial workforce of the heritage service are, at some locations, advertised internally and applications are invited from among eligible workers in accordance with union agreements. At other locations, positions are not advertised but are offered to the most senior and most suitable workers in line with custom and practice or according to local union agreements.
Supervisory positions arising in the general civil service staff are filled according to agreed procedures for promotion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if he intends to bring forward legislation to allow for the development, management and maintenance of the Boyne Canal; if so, the stage of preparation of such legislation; and when it will be published.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: A draft scheme of the Bill for the establishment of an inland waterways navigation authority has approved by Government and will shortly be referred to the parliamentary draftman for the preparation of the draft Bill. Under this draft, there is a provision that the Minister can designate additional areas of land or water for the purposes of the Act. This will provide for the designation by the responsible Minister of additional waterways, which could include the Boyne navigation, for restoration and development. I am not at present in a position to say when this Bill will be for publication.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if he will review the case of funding made by him by the Committee of the All-Ireland Amateur Drama Festival for much-needed funds for the refurbishment and renovation to St. Peter's Hall, Athlone, County Westmeath; and if he will make a sufficient financial allocation to ensure that Athlone remains the centre of the All-Ireland Amateur Drama Movement.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: The only funds at my disposal to assist applications of this nature are under the Cultural Development Incentives Scheme which I am administering under the Operational Programme for Tourism 1994-1999.

I intend to advertise this autumn for the submission of applications for the final stage of the CDIS for which I expect to be able to allocate grant assistance of the order of £5 million towards successful projects. It will be open to project promoters to submit applications for consideration in response to that advertisement.

I should add that An Comhairle Ealaíon continues to make capital grants available for projects involving refurbishment and renovation and it is open to the promoters of St. Peter's Hall, Athlone, to seek assistance from this source.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cultural Development Incentives Scheme.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: whether further allocations will be made under the cultural development incentive scheme; if so, when these allocations will be announced; the total finance available under this extra package; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Following an invitation for applications under the Cultural Development Incentives Scheme, which I am administering under the Operational Programme for Tourism 1994-99, a total of 170 applications were lodged with my Department involving assistance of some £87 million. The total amount available to me under the scheme during the five year period 1994-99 is £19.7 million, which, together with the matching funds that have to be provided by successful applicants, will enable a total capital infrastructure of at least £26 million to be put in place in the period up to 1999. A total of £14.7 million has been designated for allocation to successful applicants from the 170 applications received. The remaining £5 million available under the scheme will be allocated following a second and final call for applications. This call will be made in the autumn.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Scéim na mBóithre Áise.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: Cultúir agus Gaeltachta cén uair a dhéanfar cinneadh maidir leis an gcaiteachas ar Scéim na mBóithre Áise i mbliana; cén uair a fhoilseofar liosta na mbóithre a bhfuil caoi le dul orthu i mbliana; agus an ndéanfaidh sé ráiteas ina thaobh.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Faoi mar a cuireadh in iúl don Teach mar fhreagra ar Cheisteanna Uimh. 166 agus 167 ar 18 Meitheamh 1996, níl soláthar i Vóta mo Roinne i mbliana le haghaidh caitheachais ar bhóithre Gaeltachta agus, ar ndóigh, is ceist go príomha don Roinn Comhshaoil agus do na comhairlí contae iomchuí í staid na mbóithre sin.

Nuair a bheidh cúrsaí níos soiléire ar ball maidir le caiteachas mo Roinne i 1996 ar scéimeanna feabhsúchán sa Ghaeltacht, breithneofar an scéal tuilleadh, i gcomhairle leis an Aire Airgeadais, féachaint an dtig linn soláthar éigin a chur ar fáil i mbliana chun bóithre áise agus bóithre portaigh sa Ghaeltacht a fheabhsú.

MainHeading.P: San idirlinn tá iarrtha ag mo Roinnse ar gach comhairle contae a bhfuil ceantar Gaeltachta faoina cúram liosta a chur ar fáil de na bóithre sna limistéir Ghaeltachta gur gá a fheabhsú nó a dheisiú mar aon le garbhmheastachán ar chostas na hoibre atá de dhíth.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: There are plans in place to create a car/coach parking area as part of the development of visitor facilities at the National Botanic Gardens; Work on visitor facilities should commence in the later half of 1997 following completion of the library/herbarium project which is currently in progress. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Severance Arrangements.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if he will give details of any financial settlements or extraordinary severance arrangements entered into with civil servants in his Department or with public servants in State agencies under the aegis of his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: It is assumed that the financial settlements referred to by the Deputy are in the context of severance and no such arrangements have been entered into by my Department since its establishment in January 1993.

MainHeading.P: In relation to the non-commercial State agencies and bodies under the aegis of my Department, the position regarding arrangements made in the same period is that one officer got the benefit of a voluntary early retirement package approved by the Department of Finance. Two other officers were paid amounts which totalled £27,000 on leaving office.

With regard to RTE — the only commercial State agency under the aegis of my Department — the Authority is responsible for the remuneration and allowances of its officers and servants. My consent is required in relation to any alteration to the remuneration or the terms and conditions of the Director General. Since the establishment of my Department, my consent has not been sought for any unusual or extraordinary settlements with regard to that post.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the financial assistance, if any, given to overseas film productions under section 35 of the Finance Act.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Section 35 of the Finance Act, 1987, as amended, does not provide for direct financial assistance in respect of film production. The amount of section 35 investments in film and television productions which has been authorised by way of certificates issued by me under the section since 1994, when I was assigned the certification role, is £153 million. Of this, £78 million relates to projects which would be regarded as indigenous — although it should be noted that many of these projects involve a greater or lesser level of foreign co-production finance — and £75 million relates to projects which would be regarded as non-indigenous.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tubber (Clare) Lough.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: his views on recreational and tourist fishing on Lough Bunny, Tubber, County Clare; and if he will have arrangements made to facilitate access to the lake.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: The greater portion of Lough Bunny, with some adjoining lands, have been acquired by the National Parks and Wildlife Service of my Department. These areas are now included in the Burren National Park.

Recreational fishing can be facilitated under the international criteria for national parks, provided it is found to be compatible with nature conservation objectives. At present, low levels of recreational fishing are allowed but each case must be examined on its merits. With regard to Lough Bunny, NPWS consider it inappropriate from a conservation viewpoint to develop an access route to the lake in order to facilitate recreational and tourist fishing there.

MainHeading.P: I am advised also that an unauthor-ised development of an accessway to Lough Bunny has been carried out recently by a commercial tourist fishing operator and that this work has encroached upon, and caused damage to, part of the national park. The matter has been referred by NPWS to the Chief State Solicitor for attention.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the reason he has not put measures in place to ascertain the number of migratory game species being taken out of the country at air and sea ports.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: The export of protected wild birds and protected wild animals is controlled under the Wildlife Act, 1976 (Control of Export of Fauna) Regulations, 1979, (S.I. No. 235 of 1979). This prohibits the export of certain wild species — live or dead — except under licence. These regulations do not apply to the export of specimens of legally shot game. There is no statutory requirement to ascertain the number of game species being exported from the country.

The National Parks and Wildlife Service of my Department monitors wild birds and assesses tourist shooting through the assessment of lands to determine the shooting capacity, the allocation of gundays and bag checks, etc. There is no evidence that hunting, including current levels of commercial shooting, pose a threat to migratory species. From an analysis of bag returns and bag checks carried out by NPWS staff, it has been found that the level of such shooting is not a threat to the conservation status of migratory species.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: whether it is his policy not to issue foreshore licences to out of State shooters.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: It is not my policy to refuse permits to hunt on State foreshore, inland waters or lakeshore accretions belonging to the State to out-of-State shooters.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, being taken to ensure that tourist shooters, who bring more than one shotgun to Ireland, do not lend one to an undocumented tourist and in this way get around gun day allocations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Under section 29 (2) of the Wildlife Act, 1976, out-of-State hunters must obtain a licence to hunt game. To hunt without a licence or to carry a firearm without a firearms certificate is an offence. The National Parks and Wildlife Service of my Department in monitoring wild birds and in assessing tourist shooting regularly carry out bag, gun and licence checks. A member of the Garda Síochána or an authorised person for the purpose of the 1976 Act may request an out-of-State hunter to produce his/her hunting licence for inspection.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Circumvention of the Law.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the law on the use of motor propelled boats is being circumvented by the simple expedient of using power boats to flush duck over guns standing on the shore by persons who are not shooting.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Under the definitions in section 2 (1) of the Wildlife Act, 1976, “hunt” includes “flushing”. Under section 36 of the Act it is an offence to hunt or disturb for the purpose of hunting any protected wild bird by means of such a vessel. Anyone found engaging in such a practice will be prosecuted.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. Ryan Mr. E. Ryan
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: whether the Interdepartmental review of the conservation of built heritage has been completed; if so, the date on which it was completed; when it will be published; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: I am pleased to state that the report of the interdepartmental working group on strengthening the protection of the architectural heritage has recently been completed and was submitted to myself and to my colleague, the Minister for the Environment, Deputy Howlin, on 21 June 1996 for our consideration. The Government has approved the publication of the report and it is intended that it will be available in September.

Following publication of the report and the debate which I hope will ensue, the Minister for the Environment and I will bring forward specific measures based on the recommendations in the report to give effect to the commitment to improve the protection for listed buildings in the policy agreement for Government of December 1994, entitled A Government of Renewal.

Qst.Quest: whether he is in receipt of the report on the increase in road fatalities in 1995; if so, if he intends to publish the report; and if he will make a statement on the continuing high levels of death on our roads.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Detailed analysis of the reports prepared by the Garda in relation to road accidents in 1995 has been undertaken by the National Roads Authority and the full results will be presented in their report Road Accident Facts, 1995. It is anticipated that the report will be published in September.
In relation to road accidents generally and the preliminary analysis of 1995 data, I refer to Questions Nos. 39, 45, 82 and 94 of 13 June 1996.

Qst.Quest: whether he intends to update the building regulations in 1996; and if he will be making it mandatory to install smoke alarms in all new public and private houses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I intend to amend the building regulations later this year. Part B of the First Schedule to the Regulations sets out the requirements in relation to fire precautions to be provided for in the design and construction of new buildings. Guidance in relation to compliance with these requirements is contained in Technical Guidance Document B, published under article 5 of the regulations. Houses designed and constructed in accordance with this document must be fitted with smoke alarms. It is planned to publish a revised version of the document by the end of the year which will contain more explicit provisions in relation to the installation of smoke alarms.
