Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The success/failure rates for males and females who undertook the driving test in Waterford test centre during 1995 were as follows: Males: 51.9 per cent, pass; 48.1 per cent, fail; Females: 53.4 per cent, pass; 46.6 per cent, fail.

Qst.Quest: the procedures in place and consultation required for a local authority to plan and put in place halting sites for the travelling community.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.P: Under section 13 of the Housing Act, 1988, a housing authority may provide, improve, manage and control sites for caravans used by those who traditionally pursue or have pursued a nomadic way of life, and may carry out works incidential to such provision, improvement, management or control, including the provision of services for such sites. Guidelines for residential caravan parks for traveller families, issued by my Department to local authorities in 1985, recommend full consultation with the travellers who are to use the sites selected or their representatives and, where possible, with local community groups or their public representatives prior to site acquisition. The need for the fullest possible consultation process has been restated repeatedly since then, and is referred to in the policy document Social Housing — The Way Ahead.

Qst.hpid: Mr. T. Kitt Mr. T. Kitt
Qst.Quest: the concerns, if any, he has in relation to the proposal to construct a motorway through Leopardstown Racecourse, Dublin 18; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The development of proposals for the proposed South-Eastern Motorway is a matter for Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council, as road authority for the area, acting under the general supervision of the National Roads Authority.

The Roads Act, 1993, outlines the statutory procedures which must be complied with before a project of this nature can proceed. These include a full environmental impact assessment, the preparation of a motorway scheme and the holding of a public inquiry into all matters relating to the scheme, including the environmental impact. These procedures, which involve extensive public consultation, give all interested persons or organisations ample opportunity to make their views and concerns known, and ensure that all views or objections are fully considered before a final decision is taken on a proposed scheme.

As Minister, I have a quasi-judicial function in relation to individual motorway schemes and it would not be appropriate for me to comment on any aspect of a proposed scheme until the statutory procedures have been complied with.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Qualified Planners.

Qst.Quest: the number of professionally qualified planners employed by each local authority.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Based on staffing returns supplied to my Department, the numbers employed in specialist planning grades at 31 December 1995 is set out in the following table. In addition, planning duties may be assigned to other officers but these are not identified in the returns supplied to my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Lough Derg Toxin.

Qst.Quest: the precautionary measures, if any, being taken following the discovery of algae toxin in Lough Derg; the other lakes or locations known to contain this toxin; if any system or programme exists for the regular testing on waters for such poisonous occurrences; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: My Department issued general advice to local authorities in 1992 and 1993 in relation to algal blooms and the protection of drinking water sources. Matters addressed included risk assessment, sampling procedures, public information on human health and animal protection aspects where the presence of toxins is detected, and arrangements, treatment methods, etc., to safeguard drinking water supplies.

As regards the present situation in Lough Derg, I understand that Tipperary North Riding County Council has appropriate monitoring and risk assessment arrangements in place and is being assisted by the Environmental Protection Agency and Cork Regional Technical College in responding to the algal bloom and its associated toxin problem. The council has advised the public to refrain from paddling and swimming in areas of the lake affected by heavy concentrations of algae and has indicated that individuals and animals should avoid contact with shoreline deposits. The council has also instructed that animals should not be allowed gain access to the lake shoreline. The need for these precautions will be kept under review by the council in the light of the results of its on-going water sampling programme.

MainHeading.P: Tipperary North Riding County Council and other local authorities adjoining Lough Derg and the River Shannon have programmes in hand to upgrade sewage treatment facilities. These include the provision of secondary treatment and-or phosphorus reduction facilities at Ballinasloe, Birr, Nenagh, Roscrea and Tullamore at an estimated cost of £6.5 million. Planning and construction of sewerage schemes at Athlone and Monksland, County Roscommon, is proceeding and will involve estimated expenditure of £2.85 million. The expenditure will be met from grants provided by the Department with EU assistance.

Extensive powers are available to local authorities to deal with agricultural sources of pollution. These have been complemented by a recent amendment of the Local Government (Water Pollution) (Amendment) Act, 1990, allowing local authorities to require farmers to prepare nutrient management plans, where warranted, in the interests of restoring or protecting water quality and by the application of the integrated pollution control licensing provisions of the Environmental Protection Agency Act, 1992, to new intensive pig and poultry rearing activities with effect from 3 September 1996.

I will shortly launch, in conjunction with the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry, a code of good agricultural practice aimed at protecting waters from pollution. The code has the support of farmer representative associations and will be promoted as the means to achieve sustainable agriculture taking account of environmental protection requirements.

The position in Ireland regarding the occurrence of toxin producing forms of algae is the subject of an investigation commissioned by the Environmental Protection Agency under the Environmental Monitoring, Research and Development Sub-Programme of the Operational Programme for Environmental Services, 1994-1999. The investigation will also address the environmental conditions which promote and sustain the development of toxin emitting algae of the cyanobacteria strain, test methods to establish the presence of toxins, the standards for safe levels of toxins in waters used for the abstraction of drinking water supplies and for water contact activities, the toxin levels which may entail animal deaths or human health illness if affected waters are ingested, the evaluation of existing techniques for removing toxins in water treatment plants, and proposals to upgrade these techniques where, and if, necessary.

I understand that Lough Derg will be examined at three locations as part of this investigation and that samples of algae will be collected from more than 40 lakes throughout the country. The lakes concerned are representative of waterbodies in each trophic category with existing or potential uses such as water abstraction, water contact sports, angling and shoreline facilities. The project is expected to take two years to complete.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transfer of Local Authority Tenants.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: whether it is proposed to put a system in place to facilitate the transfer of local authority tenants from one housing authority to another at the tenants' request; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.P: My Department's guidelines in relation to schemes of letting priorities under section 11 of the Housing Act, 1988, indicate that these schemes should normally contain provisions to enable housing authorities to cater for transfers by tenants to and from houses provided by other housing authorities, on conditions mutually agreed between the authorities.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in approving a contract for the construction of a causeway in relation to Galway main drainage sewerage scheme outfall and treatment works at Mutton Island; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The proposal to construct a causeway to Mutton Island with a sewage treatment plant on the island is the subject of a legal challenge in the High Court. In the circumstances, it is not possible to proceed with the award of a contract at present.

Qst.Quest: the number of dwelling houses in County Sligo that will be without a piped water supply after the current group water schemes and other developments already under way or for funds have been sanctioned are completed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: According to the 1991 Census of Population, the number of households without a piped water supply in County Sligo was 539. A further 2.283 households depended on private sources (other than group schemes or public supplies).

Since 1991, some 900 households have been served with a piped water supply under the group water scheme programme, and about 400 further households will be served when group schemes currently under construction are completed.
Information on the number of households now without a piped supply is not available in my Department; definitive information on this will not be available until the next census.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Communications Mast.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the large number of applications being made for communication masts in various parts of the country: if his attention has further been drawn to the fact that these applications are attracting objections from local communities due to environmental and health reasons; if he will consider requesting the various companies to come together in shared facilities or using existing masts; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the action, if any, he proposes to take to protect a community (details supplied) in County Galway; if his attention has been drawn to the gravity of the situation and the entire anxiety throughout the community as a result of the proposals for the area; if he will ensure that the health of the community and the local environment are protected; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 326 and 365 together.

Responsibility for national policy in relation to the development of mobile phone networks lies with the Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications. Any health issues arising from the development of such networks are matters for the Ministers for Health and Transport, Energy and Communications. As Minister for the Environment, my functions arise from the fact that communications masts require planning permission.

MainHeading.P: As indicated previously in the House. I issued draft consultation guidelines on the planning issues arising in connection with communications masts for the guidance of planning authorities, operators, and the general public. The draft guidelines advise that operators be required to furnish evidence that their installations comply with the International Radiological Protection Association guidelines or other relevant international standards. This is to ensure that best international practice is followed. The guidelines also advise planning authorities to assess the visual impact of communication mast proposals and the scope for sharing of existing facilities as a means of diminishing the impact on the landscape. Consideration of the large number of comments received in response to the circulation of the draft guidelines has now reached an advanced stage. The guidelines in final form will issue shortly.

I have no function in relation to individual planning permission applications. However, it is open to any person to make an objection to the planning authority where an application is made in relation to any particular communications mast and, if dissatisfied with the decision of the authority to appeal to An Bord Pleanála.

Qst.Quest: the discussions, if any, he has had with the Northern Ireland Roads Authority regarding the traffic holdups on the N2 national primary Dublin/Derry road via Aughnacloy; and the proposals, if any, he has in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I refer to the reply to Questions Nos. 14 and 92 of 12 December 1995, in which I outlined details of the ongoing contact and co-operation between the road authorities here and those in Northern Ireland.

I understand that the review of plans for the future improvement of the N2 route — referred to in that reply — is almost complete. The development of proposals for further improvement works on this route will be a matter for the individual road authorities under the general supervision of the National Roads Authority.

Qst.Quest: the reason an application for funding in 1995 for a dangerous drain at Drumillard. Castleblayney, County Monaghan, was not held over to be considered for funding in 1996 as stated in his reply to Parliamentary Question No. 140 of 2 July 1996; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Under my Department's small scheme programme, each county council is invited to submit two priority schemes or groups of schemes each year for consideration. The selection of schemes for submission in any particular year is a matter for the council concerned which is free to resubmit a scheme not selected for funding in an earlier year.

Qst.Quest: whether he intends to make funding available to ensure the completion of the Fonthill Road in Clondalkin, Dublin 22; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Road grants have been fully allocated this year and there are no funds available to me from which an additional allocation could be made to any local authority. It will be open to South Dublin County Council to consider whether to apply for funding in 1997 to complete this road, under the EU co-financed scheme of grants.

Qst.Quest: whether he is currently compiling a list for a register of architects; if so, the criteria used for entry onto such a list; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: It was decided in 1990 to seek an amendment of the Architect's Directive (85/384/EEC) to extend the protection of the Directive to persons who are not currently covered but who, prior to the commencement of the Directive, had been pursuing architectural activities the nature and importance of which give those persons an established right to pursue those actitities throughout the EU. Applications were invited at the end of 1993 from such persons and these are currently being considered by a review panel appointed for the purpose.

Qst.Quest: the body/organisation which has responsibility for compiling the voluntary register of driving instructors; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The voluntary register of driving instructors is being established by the Driving Instructor Register of Ireland Ltd., with an address at 39-41 Glasnevin Hill, Dublin 9. Arrangements for the register were developed jointly by the two national associations representing motor schools and driving instructors. The registration scheme was formally launched on 18 June 1996.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Group Water Supply Schemes.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he takes to ensure that there is adequate funding available to the organisers of group water supply schemes to enable county councils to adequately restore roads to an acceptable standard when the group water supply scheme works are completed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Where costs in relation to road restoration are submitted by county councils in respect of a group water supply scheme, these are included in the overall cost of the scheme. Grant allocations are calculated on the basis of a maximum of 75 per cent of the cost of the scheme, or £1,600 per eligible domestic supply and £1,200 per eligible farm supply, whichever is the lesser.

Qst.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that Wexford County Council favours widening the carriageway on Wellington Bridge, County Wexford; if his attention has further been drawn to the damage caused to the superstructure of the existing bridge and the poor condition of the bridge, discovered only when a detailed survey was carried out as a consequence of the collapse of the bridge following a fatal accident; the proposals, if any, he has to repair and widen the bridge; the cost of such proposals; whether he will fund such works; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Wexford County Council has recently completed repair works to the existing bridge. My Department has approved the council's proposals to prepare an outline brief with a view to engaging consulting engineers to prepare a preliminary report and estimate of the cost of widening the bridge.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, he has made in drafting regulations under section 35 of the Road Traffic Act, 1994, to restrict the parking of heavy goods vehicles in specified places in view of the fact that section 90 of the Road Traffic Act, 1961, is failing to answer the concerns of householders whose children are endangered by such hazards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: It is my intention that comprehensive new traffic and parking regulations will be made under section 35 of the Road Traffic Act, 1994 by the end of October 1996. These regulations will include a provision enabling local authorities to restrict the parking of heavy goods vehicles in specified places.

Pending the making of these regulations, there are provisions under section 90 of the Road Traffic Act, 1961, under which controls on the parking of heavy goods vehicles may be applied through traffic and parking by-laws or temporary by-laws made by the Garda Commissioner, subject to my consent.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the cases, if any, of environmental pollution in the area covered by the constituency of Cork East; the number of reported cases of pollution in respect of each of the years from 1991 to date; and the number of convictions for pollution in respect of each of the years from 1991 to date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Administration and enforcement of the Local Government (Water Pollution) Acts, 1977 and 1990, the Air Pollution Act, 1987 and the Waste Management Act, 1996, including monitoring of environmental pollution and the prosecution of offences, are matters for the local authorities concerned and the Environmental Protection Agency, as appropriate.
Administration of the Environmental Protection Agency Act, 1992, including monitoring and enforcement functions, is a matter for the Environmental Protection Agency.

Qst.Quest: when funding under the small schemes programme will be approved in respect of Bridgetown and Feakle water schemes, County Clare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I recently approved a grant of £71,295 for improvement to the water supplies at O'Briensbridge and Feakle. The O'Briensbridge scheme will also serve the Bridgetown area.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if he will have arrangements made to have a person (details supplied) in County Cork called for a driving test as soon as possible in view of the fact that he must have a full licence for his new job.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: An application for a driving test for this person was received in my Department on 15 July. In the special circumstances, he will be offered a test if and when a cancellation of a test appointment at the centre concerned arises but, in any event, will be tested not later than 26 August.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sligo Water Supply Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the current position regarding an application submitted on behalf of Sligo County Council for EU funding for the Sligo and environs water supply scheme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

when approval will be given for the Sligo and environs water supply scheme which his Department has indicated has been included in an application submitted for Cohesion Funding under the Lough Gill regional water supply scheme; if the contract documents for the scheme have been fully considered by his Department to date; if the attention of his Department has been drawn to the importance of this major scheme which will accommodate the future predicted water demands of Sligo town and a large rural hinterland; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 338 and 382 together.

I am aware of the importance of the Sligo and environs water supply scheme for the development of Sligo and its surrounding areas. As I indicated in the reply to Question No. 111 of 3 July 1996, contract documents for the scheme are being examined in my Department. A decision on the application for financial assistance from the Cohesion Fund is expected shortly from the European Commission.

Qst.Quest: when grants will be paid to Drumcavan group water scheme, Kilfenora, County Clare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: There is no record in my Department of a proposal for a group water scheme at this location.

Qst.Quest: if he will list all special committees, task forces or review groups that operate under the aegis of his Department; and if he will give details of their functions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The information requested is set out in the following table:

row.entry: Strategic Review Committee comprising representatives from DOE, construction industry and private-public sector clients.
To strategically review the Irish construction industry.
Informal Working Group comprising DOE and representatives of the County and City Managers Association.
To consider equality of opportunity and related matters in the local authority service.
Inter-Departmental Committee on Peace time Emergency Planning comprising representatives from DOE and Departments of Health, Justice and Defence.
To monitor and advise on the emergency planning arrangements of the local authorities, health boards and Garda Síochána.
Housing Management Group comprising officials from DOE, Department of the Taoiseach, ADM Ltd., local authorities and Northern Ireland Housing Executive (Consultants).
Promotion of best practice in Housing Management.
Inter-Departmental Committee comprising DOE and Departments of Finance, Health and Social Welfare.
To consider the issues arising from the proposed transfer of administration of SWA rent and mortgage supplementation to local authorities and to make recommendations.
Task Force on Housing Aid for the Elderly comprising representatives from DOE, Departments of Health and Social Welfare, local authorities, FAS, the Society of St. Vincent de Paul and ALONE.
Improvement of housing conditions of elderly persons living on their own in unfit or insanitary accommodation.
Greater Dublin Water Conservation Steering Group, comprising DOE and senior management representatives of the local authorities in the greater Dublin area.

A project management steering group, as recommended by the Greater Dublin Water Supply Strategy Study, to consider, and coordinate responses to, a series of water supply operational management and strategic policy issues arising directly from the Study.
Architects Directive Review Panel comprising DOE, Prof. Cathal O'Neill, James Pike, Gerry Walker and Helen Blair (Architects).
To review applications for inclusion in a proposed amendment to the EU Architects Directive.

To oversee the Public Art Research Project which aims to facilitate the more effective promotion of art in the public sector.

Dublin Docklands Task Force comprising DOE and representatives from Departments of Marine, Transport, Energy and Communications, Enterprise and Employment, Finance, Taoiseach, Dublin Corporation, Dublin Port and Docks Board and Grand Canal Corridor Study Task Force.

To recommend arrangements to develop an overall master plan for the docklands area of Dublin and appropriate implementation and co-ordination arrangements, and also to oversee the implementation of the Task Force's Report.
Ad-hoc Tidy Towns Committee comprising DOE, Super-Valu, Office of Public Works, Cork County Council, Carrickmacross Tidy Towns Committee, adjudicators, representatives, etc.
Review of Tidy Towns Competition format and content.
CZM, to assess the present situation in
officials from DOE and Departments of Marine, and Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht.
Ireland and to make recommendations as an input to the preparation of a national CZM policy catering for conservation and sustainable use.

To prepare the QSR on the Celtic Seas, covering all coastal and marine waters under Irish jurisdiction by way of input to a comprehensive assessment of the North-East Atlantic under the OSPAR Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment.

Monitoring Committee for the Operational Programme for Environmental Services 1994-1999 comprising representatives from Government Departments, implementing agencies, the Social Partners, NGO's, the European Commission and the European Investment Bank.
To monitor implementation of the Operational Programme for Environmental Services 1994-1999.

Monitoring Committee for the Operational Programme for Transport 1994-1999 comprising representatives from Government Departments, implementing agencies, the Social Partners, the European Commission and the European Investment Bank.
To monitor implementation of the Operational Programme for Transport 1994-1999.

Qst.Quest: the amounts raised in commercial rates by each local authority in respect of each of the years from 1990 to 1995.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Information relating to the amounts of commercial rates collected by each local authority for the years 1990 to 1993 can be obtained from the Returns of Local Taxation which are available in the Oireachtas Library. Outturn figures in respect of 1994 and 1995 are not yet available in my Department in respect of every local authority but estimates are contained in the Local Authority Estimates publications for both of these years, copies of which are also available in the Oireachtas Library.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the current position regarding a house grant application on behalf of a person (details supplied) in County Louth; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.P: Additional information requested from the applicant has been received and an inspection, with a view to payment of the grant, will be carried out as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ownership of Buildings and Sites.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the buildings and sites in County Louth under the ownership of his Department; the location of these sites; if such sites are currently in use by his Department; if not, the use which will be made of such sites; when it is envisaged to utilise these sites or buildings; the proposals, if any, there are to dispose of these sites or buildings; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: No buildings or sites are owned by my Department.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Kitt Mr. M. Kitt
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to increase the number of multilingual road signs indicating driving on the left hand side of the road in view of the number of road accidents in recent times.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Overall responsibility for the provision of traffic signs on the national roads network is a matter for the National Roads Authority and responsibility for signposting on non-national roads is a matter for each local road authority.

While there is no evidence to suggest that our traffic signing system creates undue difficulties for tourists generally, my Department is developing a standard multilingual sign to advise tourists to drive on the left to replace the various signs which have been provided on an ad hoc basis to date. Details of the new sign will be made available to local authorities within the next two months. The National Safety Council has produced a booklet of traffic rules for the information of visiting drivers. The rule regarding driving on the left is prominently stated.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to raise the upper limit for sewerage scheme grants in small towns and villages in order to include a greater number of small towns and villages.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Under my Department's small scheme programme, each county council is invited to submit two priority schemes or groups of schemes each year, and grant assistance of 75 per cent of the scheme cost, subject to a maximum of £75,000, is made available. The overall budget for the programme if £4 million in 1996. There are no proposals at present to revise the terms of the programme.

Qst.Quest: if he will have a driving test arranged urgently for a person (details supplied) in County Wexford who has secured a job as a bus driver provided he has a full driving licence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: This person's application for a driving test was received on 18 July. A test has been arranged for Monday, 26 August.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Halting Sites.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to amend the Housing (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1992, which prevents local authorities from taking action against unauthorised encampments unless there are vacancies on an official halting site within a radius of five miles of the unauthorised encampment; if he has satisfied himself that this provision is equitable in situations where the occupation of an unauthorised site is by way of forcible entry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: when the new guidelines for the construction of halting sites will be available for release in view of the fact that the existing guidelines, dating back to September 1985, are in urgent need of review; his views on whether full and open consultation with all parties concerned, namely residents, travellers, public representatives and local authorities, should be an integral part of proposals for the construction of halting sites in any local authority area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to provide funding for local authorities to maintain existing and new halting sites; if he has satisfied himself that the provision of capital funding for such sites is sufficient without any funding for ongoing maintenance being provided; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 348, 349 and 350 together.

The National Strategy for Traveller Accommodation, which I announced in the Dáil on 27 March 1996, includes a proposal to give wider legislative powers to local authorities to deal with unauthorised parking by travellers in circumstances where local authorities have provided sufficient accommodation for travellers in their areas. Preparation of the necessary legislation is currently under way.

The guidelines for residential caravan parks issued by my Department to local authorities in 1985 are currently being reviewed and I intend that revised guidelines will be issued shortly. The existing guidelines recommend that local authorities consult with the travellers who are to use the sites selected, or their representatives, and, where possible, with local community groups or their public representatives, prior to site acquisition. The need for the fullest possible consultation process was stressed more recently in the policy document Social Housing — The Way Ahead and this will be restated in the revised guidelines.

MainHeading.P: The National Strategy provides that management and maintenance of residential caravan parks, currently the responsibility of the housing authorities, is to be improved with a view to securing higher standards of upkeep. The question of providing assistance to local authorities in respect of the costs involved, as recommended in the report of the Task Force on the Travelling Community, is currently under consideration in my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Mayo Drainage Scheme.

Qst.Quest: when approval will be forthcoming in respect of Stage 2 of a drainage scheme (details supplied) in County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I refer to reply to Question No. 154 of 5 June 1996. The position is unchanged.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to change traffic speeding fines to an on-the-spot fine system; the difficulties, if any, involved in this respect; and the legislative changes, if any, necessary in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Proposals to apply on-the-spot fines to speeding offences, by regulations under section 103 of the Road Traffic Act, 1961, are currently being developed by my Department, in consultation with the Department of Justice and the Garda. It is my intention that the regulations will be made by the end of October.

The Garda will continue to be empowered to initiate court proceedings in relation to any case where an on-the-spot fine is not paid or where it is considered that such an approach is warranted in the light of the alleged offence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Monaghan Sewerage Scheme.

Qst.Quest: whether he has received a revised plan for the provision of a new sewerage scheme at Tydavnet, County Monaghan; if his attention has been drawn to the urgent need for this scheme; when funding will be provided in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if his Department has examined plans for the Tydavnet, County Monaghan sewerage scheme that was submitted by Monaghan County Council.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 353 and 355 together.

Revised proposals for the Tydavnet sewerage scheme have been received in my Department and are under examination. When this examination has been completed, I will consider the question of funding for the scheme.

Speaker.P: There is no record of the receipt of an application for a grant under the 1985 house improvement grant scheme in this case. She intimidated that she would make contact later with the Department, but there is no record of any subsequent contact. Payment of a grant cannot be considered at this stage as a claim for payment of the grant was not received by 30 June 1981, the final date for receipt of such claims.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Reduction in Water Supply.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the hardship being caused to many households in County Kildare due to the reduction in water supply; and if he will give consideration to the provision of an alternative water supply.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The whole issue of water supply in the greater Dublin area, including Kildare, is currently under consideration in the context of the Dublin regional water supply strategy study which was published earlier this year. A personal application for the provision of an alternative water supply for the Kildare area is currently under consideration in my Department. In addition, funding has been made available for a major refurbishment of the Leixlip water plant which is increasing the availability of water to the greater Dublin area.

In January this year, I approved the appointment of consultants to prepare a preliminary report for the north east Kildare regional water supply scheme; this report is expected to be completed shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Roadway Pollution.

Qst.Quest: if he will ensure that existing legislation and regulations at his disposal will be used against local authorities to ensure compliance with such regulations and to ensure that pollution on our roadways, particularly noise pollution, will be eradicated.

if he intends to make regulations under the Roads Act, 1993 to curb traffic noise on our major roadways, particularly roadways adjacent to housing estates; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he intends to use his powers under the Environmental Protection Act, 1992, to curb pollution emanating from our roadways in terms of toxic and noise pollution; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 368, 369 and 370 together.

Increasing vehicle numbers, with significant reductions in air pollution from stationary sources, make road traffic a relatively greater contributor to air pollution in Ireland than in the past. A range of statutory measures are in place to control air pollutant emissions from vehicles. In the case of all new vehicles, the relevant EU emission standards are implemented by the European Communities (Mechanically Propelled Vehicle Emission Control) Regulations, 1993 to 1995. More stringent standards for light commercial vehicles, required by Directive 96/1/EC will come into force from 1 October 1996 under regulations being drafted at present.

MainHeading.P: The Road Traffic (Construction, Equipment and Use of Vehicles) Regulations, 1963, prohibit a person using a vehicle in such a manner as to emit fumes which could be prevented by the exercise of reasonable care and prohibit use in a public place of a vehicle which causes excessive noise through a defect (including a defect in design or construction), lack of repair or faulty adjustment. The regulations also provide that a person must not drive a vehicle in such a manner as to cause excessive noise which could be avoided by the exercise of reasonable care. Enforcement of the regulations is a matter for the Garda Síochána.

Under the European Communities (Vehicle Testing) Regulations, 1991, light goods vehicles over four years old must be tested for roadworthiness every two years and heavy goods vehicles, buses and ambulances over a year old must be tested annually. The roadworthiness test includes emissions and noise tests on exhaust systems.
Regarding traffic noise, while there is no immediate intention of making regulations under the Roads Act, 1993, this matter will be kept under review.

The forthcoming national sustainable development strategy will address sustainable transport in the context of providing a framework of objectives and policies for achieving sustainability in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: There are no proposals for this scheme with my Department at present.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recycling Industry.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he proposes to take to encourage recycling and to assist the recycling industry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Support for recycling in Ireland is being intensified, in line with the policies and targets established in the Government's national recycling strategy. An increased financial provision, supported by EU co-financing, is now available to promote recycling infrastructure; applications under this new grant scheme are being assessed by my Department and a first block of grants will be announced shortly.

The industry led REPAK initiative is being mobilised and I am at present considering, in consultation with REPAK, the establishment of appropriate regulatory support for the initiative within the range of powers available under the Waste Management Act, 1996.

The Environmental Protection Agency National Waste Database Report 1995, which has been published today, shows that recycling in Ireland is increasing rapidly. The percentage of household waste recycled rose from 1.4 per cent in 1993 to 4.3 per cent in 1995. The percentage of overall packaging waste recycled from the municipal waste stream has risen from a reported 10.3 per cent in 1994 to 15.6 per cent in 1995.

MainHeading.P: I consulted other EU member states and the European Commission regarding possible international action to improve the situation at the informal meeting of EU Environment Ministers and Commissioner Bjerragaard held in Dublin last weekend. There was agreement as to the need for urgent consideration to be given to measures at national and-or Community level which will encourage more stable and adequate markets for recyclables. These could include public procurement based initiatives and incentives for sourcing a minimum quota of raw materials from recyclables.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of any financial settlements or extraordinary severance arrangements entered into with civil servants in his Department or with public servants in State agencies under the aegis of his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: No such settlements or arrangements have been entered into with civil servants in my Department since my appointment in December 1994.
In the case of State agencies the following is the position:—

In prospect of a restructuring of the board, under which health and local government operations were to separate, the chief executive officer decided to accept early retirement from 31 December 1995; this was approved in accordance with the Local Government (Early Retirement and Voluntary Redundancy) (Supperannuation) Scheme, 1992, and a superannuation award was made based on a salary which was personal to the officer concerned.
A staff member was granted an early retirement package which was in line with arrangements under public service pension schemes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - UN Convention on Climate Change.

Qst.Quest: in relation to his attendance at the Second Conference of the Parties to the UN Convention on Climate Change in Geneva, the names of those people who accompanied him and the capacity in which they attended; if funding to attend the conference was provided for any person other than himself and established civil servants in his Department; if so, the other persons so funded; the purpose of their attendance; if he will give a breakdown to the total costs of representation at the convention; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The second conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, and meetings of the Convention's four subsidiary bodies, took place in Geneva from 8 to 19 July. Ireland, which as Presidency was responsible for co-ordinating and presenting the EU position, was represented at the conference and subsidiary body meetings by the following departmental officials:
Mr. N. Callan, Department of the Environment (first week and part of second week).
Mr. J. Humphreys, Department of the Environment.
Mr. D. Enright, Department of the Environment.
Mr. B. Brangan, Department of the Environment.
Mr. D. Coppins, Department of the Environment (second week only).

MainHeading.P: Mr. M. Collins, Department of the Environment.
Ms R. Dempsey, Department of Transport, Energy and Communications.
Ms E. O'Connor, Department of Transport, Energy and Communications.

Accompanied by my Private Secretary, I attended the ministerial segment of the conference from 16-18 July. In my capacity as President of the EU Environment Council, I chaired a number of EU co-ordination meetings and presented the EU position in the wider conference negotiations. I also hosted a reception for Ministers and heads of delegations from Annex I parties to the Convention.

Irish Government costs as regards the conference relate solely to the above arrangements. Detailed compilation of the costs, which will consist mainly of travel and subsistence costs incurred in accordance with Department of Finance regulations, have not yet been completed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Action Against Litter Campaign.

Qst.Quest: the number of new full-time litter wardens employed since the launch of the Talking Rubbish campaign; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the number of new part-time litter wardens employed since the launch of the action against litter campaign; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the number of prosecutions initiated and the number of convictions secured against litter offenders since the launch of the action against litter campaign; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the achievements, if any, to date of the action against litter campaign; the cost to date of the campaign; the estimated future costs of the campaign; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 384, 385, 386 and 387 together.

Implementation of the action against litter initiative is proceeding in accordance with the strategy outlined in my policy statement of 12 February 1996. The following measures have or are being implemented:
—local authorities have been requested to prepare litter abatement plans for their functional areas,
—educational materials promoting anti-litter awareness have been distributed in all first and second level schools,
—the revised structure of the Tidy Towns Competition has been more closely aligned with this initiative,
—a major public awareness campaign is currently being promoted and will continue over the coming months,
—in co-operation with petrol retailing companies a special initiative will be mounted during the month of August to promote anti-litter awareness with motorists,
—the Government has already approved detailed proposals for comprehensive new legislation to deal with litter pollution; drafting of the Bill is proceeding with a view to early publication.

MainHeading.P: Expenditure on this initiative up to 30 June 1996 amounted to £210,000. The estimated total cost of this initiative in 1996 is £400,000 for which provision has been made in my Department's estimate.

Information on the number of litter wardens employed by local authorities is set out in the reply to Question No. 13 on 13 June 1996. This is the most up to date information available in my Department at this stage. Information on the numbers of prosecutions and convictions under the Litter Act, 1982 since the launching of the initiative is not yet available in my Department.

Qst.Quest: the number and dates of meetings of the Ministerial Committee on Sellafield of which he is the Chairman; the agenda and outcome of those meetings; the future plans, if any, of the committee; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I refer to the reply to Questions Nos. 2 and 40 of 13 June 1996. This set out the position about meetings of the Ministerial Group on Sellafield, the matters addressed and the future role of the group in co-ordinating and monitoring progress in respect of relevant commitments in the policy agreement, A Government of Renewal.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Local Government Audits.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has in relation to the publication of the audits on aspects of Local Government recently announced to ensure that such a long delay between completion and publication does not recur; the audits ongoing or planned beyond those already published; the estimated date of completion and subsequent publication of these audits; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the reason, in relation to the recently published audits on local government issued by his Department, the local authorities surveyed in the various audits were not named; the plans, if any, he has to do so; the steps, if any, he has take to date to or plans to take to ensure that the attention of the officials, public representatives and the general public in the relevant areas is drawn to the contents of these reports and their immediate relevance to them; if his attention has been drawn to a request from Deputy Dempsey to him to reissue the reports with the relevant councils named; if he will do so; if all future reports will be published promptly and will disclose the identity of the public bodies examined; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 389 and 390 together.

Value for money (VFM) reports on selected local authority operations, carried out by the VFM unit of my Department, are issued, as they are completed, to all local authorities. The local government auditors, in the course of their annual audits of local authority accounts, assess the extent to which the reports' recommendations are implemented by local authorities.

The VFM publication which I recently issued aggregated ten separate reports in one comprehensive volume. This was the first time that such reports were made available to the general public. Since publication, a report on local authority stores has been completed and has been issued to all local authorities. Work is currently under way on studies in relation to water production, housing maintenance and debt collection. A study on refuse collection is also planned. I propose to publish these, and all future VFM reports, at regular intervals.

MainHeading.P: Value for money auditing is still a relatively new and developing initiative, introduced within the local government audit service only these years ago. It is an evolving process which may require adjustment or “fine-tuning” as it develops. The purpose of the VFM reports is to assist local authorities generally in achieving efficiency, effectiveness and economy in the provision of services, rather than to identify defects or inadequacies in the case of individual authorities; this latter is more approporiate to the normal audit report. I have no proposals, therefore, to specifically identify those local authorities who contributed to particular studies based, on returns from a sample of authorities, but the issue will be kept under review in the light of developments.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has, in relation to the steps recently announced by his Department to tackle the problem of drugs in local authority estates, to ensure that similar problems encountered by private landlords are dealt with on an equal footing; the changes, if any, he will propose in relation to landlord tenant legislation to achieve this; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Ms McManus)
Speaker.P: The legislative measures proposed to deal with the problem of drugs and anti-social behaviour in local authority housing estates are designed to cater for the particular circumstances of those estates which are managed under the Housing Acts. The question of anti-social behaviour in dwellings generally, or in dwellings to which the Landlord and Tenant Acts apply, are not matters in which I have any functional responsibility. I might add, however, that the legislative measures already announced include a proposal to allow health boards to refuse or withdraw SWA housing assistance on grounds of anti-social behaviour.

if her Department can assist in placing a child (details supplied) in Dublin 7 in the Mater Hospital special school for children with behavioural problems in view of the special circumstances.

Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 392, 491 and 515 together.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Interdepartmental Committee.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the activities of her Department and the Health InterDepartmental Committee in so far as they specifically concern children with disabilities; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Interdepartmental Co-ordinating Committee on Services for Young People with Special Educational Needs was established in December 1995.

MainHeading.P: The terms of reference of the committee are:
(1) Identify existing and anticipated areas of service delivery where improved or modified approaches or structures are required.

(2) In respect of each area identified, to bring forward recommendations for future approaches, specifying in each case the respective roles and responsibilities of the Departments of Education and Health and their agents.
(3) To make such further recommendations as are considered necessary or desirable for the achievement of a more effective and efficient delivery of services to special needs children.
(4) To co-ordinate policy and monitor service delivery on an ongoing basis.

The committee is comprised of a core membership of administrative and professional staff from the Departments of Education and Health. Membership of the committee can be supplemented where necessary to address particular issues.

It is not envisaged that the committee will engage in the preparation of formal reports. Rather, it will pursue the objective of achieving maximum co-ordination of service delivery through consultation and agreement with relevant parties.
The committee will keep the Minister for Health and myself informed of the progress of its work and will consult where necessary on particular issues.

Qst.Quest: if she will give details of the extra financial allocation which she has made to Athlone Urban District Council, County Westmeath, for the proposed sports complex; the arrangements in place for the payment of this allocation; if she will confirm earlier financial allocation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As outlined in my reply to Parliamentary Question No. 178 of 14 May 1996, provision has been made in the context of the 1996 funding arrangements under the major facilities scheme to increase the grant for this project by £1 million bringing the total grant to £2.5 million.
The present position is that Athlone Urban District Council is preparing updated detailed drawings and costings, as well as details of the financial package, for submission to my Department.
In line with all such projects, payments are made on foot of architect's certificates as the work is undertaken.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Cork County Council has informed my Department that the student in question does not meet the academic attainment requirements of the 1992 higher education grants scheme which is the scheme that applies in this case. It is, therefore, not possible to award a grant in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cork Primary School.

Qst.Quest: whether she intends to have a primary school built in the Grange/Frankfield area of Cork in view of the ever increasing number of housing estates in that area; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have no plans at present for the provision of a primary school in the Grange/Frankfield area of Cork. Children in this immediate area attend schools in the neighbouring parishes of Ballinlough and Douglas.

MainHeading.P: Arrangements are being made for the provision of additional classroom accommodation in two schools in Ballinlough, St Anthony's and Our Lady of Lourdes. In addition, the construction of a new school building for Gaelscoil an Athar Tadhg Ó Murchú, Doughlas, was completed earlier this year.
It is expected that these projects will contribute to relieving any increased demand for primary school places from the Grange/Frankfield locality.
My Department will continue to monitor the situation closely in the light of current and projected enrolments, demographic trends, housing developments, etc.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Qst.Quest: if she will ensure that the current level of teaching staff be retained in view of the consequential effect of losing a teacher at a school (details supplied) in County Tipperary.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The staffing of a national school for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on the 30 September of the previous year.
The total enrolment of the school in question on the 30 of September 1995 was 420 pupils. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and 13 assistant teachers for the 1996-97 school year.
In addition to the staffing mentioned above, the school has a remedial teacher and two special additional assistants.
In the circumstances, the 14th assistant's post at the school has been suppressed.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Qst.Quest: if she will ensure that Inch national school, Thurles, County Tipperary retains the services of a third assistant teacher.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, the staffing of a national school for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on the 30 September of the previous year.

The enrolment of Inch national school on the 30 September 1995 was 89 pupils. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and two assistant teachers for the 1996-97 school year. Accordingly, the third assistant's post, which was sanctioned on a temporary basis for the 1995-96 school year, has been suppressed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Finance for Education Purposes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Appointment.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to applications by a school (details supplied) in County Louth for the appointment of a walking principal and assistant teacher to the school, which is classified as a disadvantaged area school; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The managerial authorities of the school to which the Deputy refers wrote to my Department requesting that the principal teacher at the school be released from her teaching duties to allow her to perform administrative duties and to allow the appointments of a temporary teacher in her place.

MainHeading.P: Unfortunately, it has not been possible to accede to this request. For a principal teacher of a primary school to become an administrative principal, a school must have eight assistant teachers. Since the school in question does not have eight assistants, the principal teacher cannot be allowed to relinquish teaching duties to concentrate solely on administrative matters.
The managerial authorities of the school have been duly informed in this matter.

Qst.Quest: the number of educational psychologists that will be appointed in 1996; the number of such psychologists that will be appointed in the north-west; and when these appointments will be made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I wish to inform the Deputy that ten psychologists were appointed in 1995 and at this stage it is not proposed to make any new appointments in 1996.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Breaking the Cycle Scheme.

Qst.hpid: Ms F. Fitzgerald Ms F. Fitzgerald
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to extend the deadline for applications for the scheme Breaking the Cycle in view of the fact that there appears to be confusion as to eligibility among small urban disadvantaged schools arising from the wording of her Department's leaflet which referred to 25 selected large schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have no plans to extend the deadline for applications for the scheme Breaking the Cycle.

MainHeading.P: All schools already designated as disadvantaged, regardless of size, in Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford and Galway were invited to apply for inclusion in Breaking the Cycle. In addition, all schools from all parts of the country with fewer than five teachers were eligible to apply for inclusion under the initiative. The Education Research Centre has recently been in touch with all the target schools and has invited applications for consideration for support under the new initiative.
The centre is currently prioritising all applications in terms of level of needs as represented by the data submitted by the schools and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Extension to Primary School.

Qst.Quest: whether an extension to a school (details supplied) in County Cork will be completed before September 1996.

when work will commence on the extension to a primary school (details supplied) in County Cork; and if the necessary funding will be provided to ensure commencement of the works by the 1996/1997 school year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 414 and 454 together.
I am not yet in a position to give a firm date as to when construction will commence on the extension to the school referred to by the Deputy.
Due to the current level of contractual commitments on the primary school capital programme, it is not possible to allow tenders to be invited immediately.
I wish to assure the Deputy that every effort is being made to ensure that the project can proceed at the earliest opportunity.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Breaking the Cycle Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the criteria she will use to assess applicant schools for the new 15 to 1 ratio at primary level for the Breaking the Cycle scheme in view of the brief nature of the application forms.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: the criteria used in relation to the selection of schools to be designated as disadvantaged; when decisions will be made in relation to these designations; the advantages that the designation of disadvantaged status confers on a school so designated; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the criteria used to establish disadvantaged status.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Question Nos. 415, 438 and 477 together. Schools are being selected for support under Breaking the Cycle Initiative by reference to new selection criteria, developed by the Education Research Centre, and taking on board the recommendations of the Combat Poverty Agency. The criteria were outlined in the Department's leaflet, Breaking the Cycle.

The following criteria are common to the identification of both urban and rural schools which serve children from disadvantaged backgrounds: long-term unemployment (one year or more) of the main breadwinner; the family having a medical card; living in a lone-parent household and the educational level attained by the mother and by the father.

MainHeading.P: In the case of urban schools, there is an additional criterion relating to the numbers of children who live in rented local authority accommodation and in the case of small rural schools, there is an additional criterion relating to the numbers of children from families in receipt of assistance because of limited incomes from farming. The advantages which will accrue to all schools included in Breaking the Cycle are: an additional £30 capitation grant; grant for the purchase of teaching and learning materials and special in-career development for school staff. In addition, there will be a maximum of 15 children in junior classes — that is junior infants to second classes — in urban schools. Co-ordinators will be appointed to promote the new initiative.

The application forms which were issued were very detailed and information was requested in regard to the school, enrolments, staffing, additional support schemes benefiting the school, details of the children in reception class, and commitment to in-career development, planning and the implementation of testing procedures for children with reading and numeracy difficulties.

Schools selected as a result of this process will be invited to submit five year development plans identifying current difficulties and putting forward specific proposals and targets to address the problem of educational disadvantage. Qualification for support will depend on the submission of suitable development plans.

The Education Research Centre is currently prioritising all applications in terms of level of need as represented by the data submitted by the schools and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly.

Qst.Quest: if she will give details of her proposals in relation to the future development of Gaelscoil Baile Phámar, Dublin 20; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department proposes to provide a new building for Gaelscoil Naomh Phádraig, Baile Phámar, Dublin 20, on a site in Lucan which is to be shared with the proposed Gaelcholáiste Leamhcáin. My Department has identified a suitable site for the schools and is making the necessary arrangements for the acquisition of the land.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disabled Children With Special Needs.

Qst.Quest: the number of pupils attending national schools who are considered disabled or children with special needs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department does not keep precise records of the number of children with special needs who are integrated into ordinary primary schools at any given time. A survey conducted in 1992 on behalf of the Special Education Review Committee indicated that there were approximately 8,000 pupils with specific disabilities in ordinary classes in primary schools.

Qst.Quest: the reason a student (details supplied) in County Tipperary who is in third class in national school must pay a school bus fare in spite of the fact that he lives furthest away from the parish national school due to the closure of three other national schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: School Transport entitlement is determined on the basis of the shortest available walking distance to the nearest school, rather than parish or other boundaries, such as county boundaries. The child referred to by the Deputy is not attending his nearest school, and is therefore entitled to concessionery fare-paying transport only, under the terms of the school transport scheme. Only in the event that the parents-legal guardians are medical card holders can the fare be waived.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teacher Training Colleges' Costs.

Qst.Quest: the cost to the State per student, per annum, of each of the five teacher training colleges, Mary Immaculate College, Limerick, St. Patrick's College, Drumcondra, Dublin 9, Froebel College, Blackrock, County Dublin, St. Mary's, Marino, Dublin 3 and Church of Ireland College, Rathmines, Dublin 6.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The cost to the State per student, in 1995 for B.Ed. students attenting the Colleges of Education for Primary Teachers was as follows: Mary Immaculate College, Limerick £2,800; St. Patrick's College, Drumcondra £3,300; Church of Ireland College of Education, Dublin £7,138; Froebel College, Blackrock £1,065 and St. Mary's College, Marino £1,065. This does not include costs arising from the higher education grants schemes.

Qst.Quest: the total cost of surveys undertaken by the MRBI for her Department since January 1995; the number of such surveys undertaken; the costs incurred in respect of each survey; and the surveys, if any, which included a questionnaire to ascertain the level of support for political parties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: No MRBI survey has been undertaken on behalf of my Department since January 1995.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to replace existing pre-fabricated classrooms and to provide additional rooms at St. Declan's Christian Brother's School, Nephin Road, Cabra, Dublin 7.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Architectural planning for a permanent extension to St. Declan's College, Cabra, is currently under way. Sanction has been given to the school authority to prepare Stage II — Outline Sketch Scheme — documentation. Additional information in relation to site investigations has been submitted to my Department and is currently under examination.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Proposed Regional Technical College.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to secure the reserved site in Blanchardstown, Dublin 15 for the proposed regional technical college as recommended by the Steering Committee on the Future Development of Higher Education; the plans, if any, she has to provide funding in the immediate future for the provision of the regional technical college; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The provision of a regional technical college at Blanchardstown and the funding implications of such a development is being considered by me in the context of the appraisal of the overall recommendations of the Steering Committee on the Future Development of Higher Education.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - VEC College of Music.

Qst.Quest: the consultations, if any, she has had with the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee in relation to the fee increase for the 1996/1997 school year at the College of Music, Ballyfermot, Dublin 10.

if her attention has been drawn to the fact that as a result of her decision in regard to the funding of music courses in the vocational education committee sector, it has been proposed to increase the fees for music courses at the College of Music, Ballyfermot, Dublin 10, by 41.25 per cent; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will intervene to ensure a reduction in the substantial increase in fees sought for music at the vocational education committee College of Music, Ballyfermot, Dublin 10; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 423, 459 and 516 together. Officials of my Department have been in consultation with the vocational education committee referred to, regarding fees for the 1996/97 school year for the College of Music. I am prepared to agree to a proposal made by the vocational education committee regarding the fee increase for the 1996/97 school year. The details will be outlined in correspondence to the vocational education committee.

Qst.Quest: if she will ensure equality of treatment in terms of the annual staffing schedules for all primary schools, irrespective of whether they are gaelscoileanna or not.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that the pupil-teacher ratio in primary gaelscoileanna is more favourable than that which applies to primary mainstream schools. This reflects the importance which the Government attributes to the Irish language. I am committed to reducing the pupil-teacher ratio in mainstream primary schools generally. Since taking office I have reduced the pupil-teacher ratio from 25.2:1 to 22.9:1. Unfortunately, however, current resources available do not permit me to allocate corresponding staffing schedules to both ordinary national schools and gaelscoileanna.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Report on Department's Communications System.

Qst.Quest: the cost of the work to date undertaken by Drury Communications in relation to the preparation and completion of a report on her Department's communications system; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will publish in its entirety the report prepared by Drury Communications on her Department's communications system; and if she will make copies of the report available to Members of the Oireachtas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Drury Communications Limited were contracted by my Department to produce an internal report on all aspects of communications in the Department. The total cost of the report was £22,869. The purpose of the report is to assist the Department in the development of a communications strategy as a vital input into the Strategic Management Initiative and as an input into a management plan being prepared in the Department. A steering committee, representative of various grades across the Department, has been established to formulate an implementation plan on the report's recommendations. When this plan is completed, it will be circulated to all members of the Department's staff and I will be delighted to forward a copy to the Deputy at that stage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hiring of Public Relations Company.

Qst.Quest: whether a public relations firm has been hired recently by her Department to advise her on the handling of issues relating to the White Paper on Education, inservice training and media matters generally; if so, the name of the company concerned; the tendering procedures used for the awarding of this contract; the timeframe used for the preparation of tender submissions from the firms selected to tender; the estimated cost of the contract awarded; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Bill O'Herlihy Communications Group was recently contracted to provide a public relations advisory service to my Department. The contract was awarded following an approach to five public relations firms inviting them to submit tenders. Requests for tender documentation were sent to the companies concerned on 14 June 1996, asking that the tenders be returned to the Department not later than 5 p.m. on 17 June 1996. Four of the five firms responded. Following consideration of the tenders, the contract was awarded. The procedures for the engagement of consultants were followed at all times in respect of the award of the contract. For commercial reasons, and in the interests of competitive tendering by Government Departments, I am not in a position to disclose details of the cost of the contract. However, I can assure the Deputy that the contract was awarded on the basis of the lowest most suitable tender and that the tender was very competitively priced. The Deputy will, of course, be aware that the details of this contract and payments made to the firm will be subject to audit by the Comptroller and Auditor General.

The consultants are required to provide a public relations advice service to my Department on: the implementation of the White Paper “Charting our Education Future”; the ongoing Civil Service-wide Strategic Management Initiative; the preparation and promotion of legislation to give effect to the decisions conveyed in the White Paper on future educational policy and the continuation of the process of building enduring capabilities and competencies through in-career development programmes for staff in the education area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Oideachas do Dhuine i Chontae na nGaillimhe.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: cén uair a bheidh socruithe déanta maidir le hoideachas a chur ar fáil do dhuine (sonraí tugtha) i Contae na nGaillimhe; agus an ndéanfaidh sí ráiteas ina thaobh.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Tá roinnt moltaí ag Cigireacht na Roinne, taréis tosca an cháis a fhiosrú, maidir le soláthar oiriúnach oideachais a chur ar fáil don dalta áirithe seo.
Tá stáidéar á dhéanamh ar na moltaí seo sa Roinn faoi láthair agus déanfaidh mé teagmháil leis an Teachta chomh luath agus a chinnfear ar bhreith sa chás seo.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appointment of Design Team.

Qst.Quest: when she will appoint a design team for the extension works at Kells Community School, County Meath.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department is making the necessary arrangements for the appointment of a design team for the project at Kells Community School. The school authorities will be informed of arrangements in due course.
