Qst.Quest: whether any of the schools in the County of Dublin area of need of Dublin 15 will get additional teachers under the new scheme to reduce the pupil/teacher ratio.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Deputy is referring to the important new initiative, “Breaking the Cycle”, which seeks to break the cycle of educational disadvantage in selected urban and rural areas, which I recently launched in response to reports that I commissioned from the Combat Poverty Agency and the Education Research Centre. As part of this initiative, a pupil teacher ratio of 15:1 is being made available to the junior classes of 25 selected schools in designated areas of disadvantage in the Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford and Galway areas. A substantial programme of other supports is also available to selected urban and rural schools under the initiative.

The Education Research Centre has recently been in touch with all the schools in question, including schools in the Dublin 15 area that are already in the disadvantaged areas scheme, inviting their applications, The centre is currently prioritising all applicants in terms of level of need as represented by the data submitted by the schools and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly. Schools selected as a result of this process will be invited to submit five-year development plans. Each such plan will be required to identify current difficulties and put forward specific proposals and targets for addressing the problems of educational disadvantage. Qualification for support will depend on the submission of suitable development plans.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Corduff (Dublin) National School.

Qst.Quest: the reason St. Patrick's national school, Corduff, Dublin 15, will lose a teacher in view of the fact that this school is in a County of Dublin area of need; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The staffing of a national school for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on 30 September of the previous year.

MainHeading.P: The enrolment of St. Patrick's national school, Corduff, on 30 September 1995 was 326 pupils. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and ten assistant teachers for the 1996-97 school year. Accordingly, the eleventh and twelfth assistants' posts at the school have been suppressed. I would point out to the Deputy that in addition to the staffing mentioned above, the school has a concessionary post on account of its disadvantaged status; a remedial teacher; three special class teachers; and one home-school-liaison teacher.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Schools Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the benefits available to schools under the disadvantaged schools scheme; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A wide range of supports is currently available for primary schools designated as disadvantaged. A supplementary capitation grant of £25 per pupil is paid in respect of these schools. This rate is being increased to £30 per pupil from September 1996, which will bring the total capitation funding for these schools to £75 per pupil. Until 1994, each school awarded disadvantaged status was also allocated an ex-quota concessionary teaching post. However, from 1994 onwards, when the disadvantaged areas scheme was last expanded, schools were allocated capitation grants only. In addition, the staffing allocation made to each disadvantaged primary school is set at a level which enables the school authorities to ensure that no class will have more than 29 pupils.

MainHeading.P: Schools in the disadvantaged areas scheme also receive the following supports: refund of television licence fee; 95 per cent building grant for building projects; schools with an enrolment of 200 or more may also receive a grant of £15 per pupil in respect of clerical-caretaking services, subject to a maximum of 500 pupils; under the scheme of grants to provide aid for school books for needy pupils, funding is provided specifically to aid in the establishment of loan-rental schemes for schools designated as disadvantaged and in 1993, a special initiative was introduced to alleviate the difficulties of certain schools in the disadvantaged areas scheme which were encountering serious current financial difficulties. One hundred and eighty-one primary schools which have been granted disadvantaged area status also avail of the Home School Community Liaison Scheme, 40 disadvantaged schools have been allocated Early Start Pre-School classes and 31 disadvantaged schools have access to teacher counsellors.

As the Deputy will be aware, I recently announced a major new initiative, Breaking the Cycle, targeted specifically on tackling disadvantage. The benefits which will be available to primary schools which will be granted disadvantaged status under the new initiative are as follows: an additional £30 capitation grant which issues to all designated schools; grants for the purchase of teaching and learning materials and in-career development for school staff. In addition, there will be a maximum of 15 children in junior classes, that is, junior infants to second class, in urban schools. Co-ordinators will be appointed to promote the development of the initiative and there will be additional funding for strategies which the schools will identify in their plans to address the needs of the children.

With regard to post-primary schools, the additional £30 capitation grant, in addition to the standard per capita grant, was introduced in 1994 for schools which were designated as disadvantaged. This brings the total capitation funding for post-primary schools designated as disadvantaged to £207 per pupil in 1996. These schools are also allocated an additional ex-quota teaching post. Eighty-seven post-primary schools designated as disadvantaged also avail of the Home School Community Liaison Scheme.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the position in Dundalk, County Louth, where St. Nicholas' Monastery boys school is in the disadvantaged schools scheme whereas Castletown girls school on the same campus is not included in the scheme; if she will consider designating Castletown girls school disadvantaged status under the scheme in view of the fact that the children attending both schools come from the same catchment area; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that the school in question applied for inclusion in the disadvantaged areas scheme in 1994. Schools were selected for inclusion in the scheme at that time on the basis of priority of need as reflected by a range of socio-economic indicators. Account was also taken of the views of my Department's inspectorate on the relative levels of need between schools and the prevailing teacher ratios. The case put forward by the school in question was considered at that time. Unfortunately, when taking these factors into account, the needs of the school were not considered to be of such priority as to warrant their inclusion on that occasion. I have no plans at present to extend disadvantaged area status to this school. I am aware that the adjacent boys school already has disadvantaged status.

MainHeading.P: In response to the report from the Combat Poverty Agency and the Education Research Centre, I recently launched an important new initiative which seeks to break the cycle of educational disadvantage in selected urban and rural areas. In line with the recommendations of the report, a targeted programme of supports is being made available to 25 selected schools in designated areas of disadvantage in the Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford and Galway urban areas. In addition, 25 clusters of small schools with fewer than five teachers and particularly those in rural areas with high levels of disadvantage, will receive a targeted programme of supports. Schools from all parts of the country with fewer than five teachers are eligible to apply for inclusion in this scheme. The Education Research Centre has recently been in touch with all the target schools and invited applications for consideration for support under the new initiative. The centre is currently prioritising all applicants in terms of level of need as represented by the data submitted by the school and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly. Schools selected as a result of this process will be invited to submit five year development plans. Each such plan will be required to identify current difficulties and put forward specific proposals and targets for addressing the problem of educational disadvantage. Qualification for support will depend on the submission of suitable development plans.

Qst.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the roof at Ramsgrange national school, County Wexford was to be replaced during the summer holiday period; if this programme of work is on course to commence; the cost of the works; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A grant has been sanctioned by my Department for works to the roof of Ramsgrange national school. Contract documentation for the job is currently being completed and the project should proceed to tender stage within the next fortnight. It would not be prudent of me to publicise a cost estimate for the work in advance of the competitive tendering process.

Qst.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the difficulties with the condition of and space in Ballycullane national school, County Wexford; if so, when she proposes to resolve the problem; when works will be completed; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware of the conditions at Ballycullane national school and, for this reason, I included extension of the school in my Department's capital programme. The school has appointed its own architect for the project and work is proceeding on the preparation of sketch plans. As the project is at an early planning stage, I cannot say when the work will be undertaken.

Qst.Quest: if she will make capitation grants available for children attending ordinary national schools who have special needs, such as cerebral palsy, physical disablement resulting in co-ordination difficulties with writing and so on; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Capitation grants at the rate of £40 per pupil are paid in respect of all pupils, including children with special needs, attending ordinary national schools. It is proposed to increase the level of grant to £45 per pupil for the coming school year. The Special Education Review Committee recommended that the capitation grant payable to ordinary schools in respect of pupils with disabilities and-or special educational needs, who have been assessed and satisfy the criteria for enrolment in special schools or classes, should be that which would be payable if the pupils were enrolled in special schools or classes. An action plan has been drawn up with the aim of giving effect to the review committee's recommendations over a target period, having regard to likely resource availability and the need to prioritise responses. I have adopted a positive approach in relation to the review committee's recommendations and wish to see them implemented as quickly as possible.

Qst.Quest: if she intends to allocate funding to the Tallaght Partnership for the Killinarden Afterschool and Holiday Service, previously funded by the NOW Programme, to enable the Tallaght Partnership to continue to fund this vitally needed service after the end of July 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department has no record of an application for funding from the Tallaght Partnership in respect of the Killinarden Afterschool and Holiday Service. Should the group in question wish to submit such an application, it will receive consideration in the context of resources available in 1996.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - VEC School Building Projects.

Qst.Quest: the reason her Department is seeking an indemnity from vocational education committees under the Health and Safety Regulations for vocational committee school building projects in view of the fact that insurance companies are refusing to provide this cover and it is not required by other Departments for their building projects: the reason it applies to vocational education committee building projects and not to third-level colleges; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Safety, Health and Welfare at Work (Construction) Regulations 1995 came into operation on 6 June 1995, with the exception of section 31 (1) and 5, which became operative on 1 March 1996. The purpose of the regulations is to improve safety on construction sites. S.I. No. 138 of 1995 — Safety. Health and Welfare at Work (Construction) Regulations 1995 — implements in Ireland, European Directive 92/57/EEC and imposes statutory obligations on the client, the designer and the contractor.

As the Deputy will appreciate, the vocational education committees are statutory bodies and, as the contracting authority, are clients in respect of building projects. My Department's concern is to ensure that the vocational education committees understand their obligations under, and comply in all respects with, this legislation and that they indicate this in writing.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Remedial Teachers.

Qst.Quest: the primary schools in County Leitrim which have a remedial teacher or who are sharing a remedial teacher; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the primary schools in County Leitrim where an application has been made for a remedial teacher or a shared remedial teacher and where no decision has yet been taken on granting such a request.
the primary schools in County Sligo where an application has been made for a remedial teacher or a shared remedial teacher and where no decision has yet been taken on granting such a request.
the primary schools in County Sligo which currently have a remedial teacher or who are sharing a remedial teacher; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions No. 440, 443, 444 and 445 together. The information regarding the primary schools in Counties Leitrim and Sligo which have a remedial teacher, or who are sharing a remedial teacher, is detailed on the attached list. The information regarding the primary schools in both counties which have applied for a remedial teacher, either on a full time or on a shared basis, is not readily available within my Department. If the Deputy would like to make an inquiry regarding an application from a particular school, my Department would require details of the school concerned.

I am not in a position at present to make additional remedial teacher posts available to the schools referred to by the Deputy or to any primary schools. Since my appointment as Minister for Education, I have allocated an additional 241 remedial teachers to the primary sector. A total of 1,188 remedial teachers are now in place and the percentage of pupils who have access to a remedial service has increased from 77 per cent to 87 per cent. I consider that the substantial improvements which I have already achieved in this area provide practical confirmation of my commitment to the needs of the children in question. However, as Minister for Education I have to consider how best to deploy available resources across a wider range of special needs. I have to determine priorities and try to allocate resources to best effect.

During the period 1994-1995, in addition to allocating an extra 155 remedial teachers, I adopted a particular focus on the needs of children attending special schools and classes. In addition to reducing the pupil-teacher ratios in all such facilities, I provided a very substantial increase in the special capitation rates applicable in such cases. In the current school year. I have adopted a particular focus on children who suffer from educational disadvantage and have sought to target resources into this area in an effort to break the cycle of disadvantage. As part of this approach, I recently launched a major new initiative aimed at bringing special targeted assistance to children in selected urban and rural areas who suffer serious educational disadvantage.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that since my appointment as Minister for Education I have achieved substantial advances across the entire spectrum of special needs, including the remedial area. It is my intention to continue this process. Of the 43 national schools in County Leitrim, 25 have the services of a remedial teacher either on a full time or a shared basis. They are as follows:
Of the 71 national schools in County Sligo, 38 have the services of a remedial teacher either on a full time or a shared basis. They are as follows:

Qst.Quest: if she will give details of the various inquiries pursued, the various processes pursued and the various people interviewed by Price Waterhouse consultants in their efforts to seek to establish the way in which items of craftwork produced by pupils of the Ursuline College in Sligo for the art paper in the 1995 leaving certificate examination went missing; if it has been established that the craftwork reached her Department's buildings in Athlone, County Westmeath; if it can be assumed that the difficulty arose and the loss took place in the one area, such as her Department's building in Athlone, in view of the fact that craftwork of students in Navan and other parts of the country also went missing; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Price Waterhouse report, which the Deputy will have received, gives a full explanation of the methodology used to conduct the investigation. Price Waterhouse have not named those people whom they interviewed in the course of their inquiries. The material was properly despatched from the Ursuline College. An Post have stated that a package bearing the same reference number as the package of craftwork from the Ursuline College was signed for as having been received by an employee of a Sligo-based company. However, the package itself has never been traced and Price Waterhouse state that it is therefore not possible to say with any certainty what was the ultimate fate of this package. Price Waterhouse concluded following a lengthy and very thorough investigation and a report which details the facts as ascertained by them, that there is no single cause for the errors and failures that occurred. They state that the reasons for their occurrence are, in most cases, complex and multifaceted.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in providing funds for the construction of a new school building to a school (details supplied) in County Cork in view of the fact that tenders for the project were submitted in January 1996; and when her Department will permit work to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department was not consulted prior to the invitation of tenders for the building project at the school referred to by the Deputy. Having examined the development plans in detail, my Department has advised the school's design team of the need to make changes to the electrical services installation. Due to financial constraints, I am not in a position to allow the project to proceed to contract at present or to indicate when it might proceed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish National Flying Club.

Qst.Quest: if she will recognise the Irish National Flying Club, involving pigeons, as a national governing body of sport; the procedures involved in obtaining official recognition to enable an application for national lottery funding; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I do not intend to accord recognition as a national governing body of sport to the Irish National Flying Club. The activities of the club would not qualify as “sport” as defined in the European Sports Charter, which stipulates the need for an acceptable level of physical skill and effort before an activity can be recognised as sport or physical recreation.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the serious difficulty experienced by many children attending special schools, special classes and day care centres in rural Ireland due to lack of adequate transport; if this issue will be fully investigated by the School Transport Review Committee with other responsible public bodies, such as health boards; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: At present, approximately 8,500 children with disabilities are carried daily on a national network involving 450 vehicles. In addition, other pupils with disabilities are integrated on ordinary school transport services. The issue to which the Deputy refers is being considered by the School Transport Review Committee and will be dealt with in their report.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Child Sex Abuse Allegations.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that a person currently facing multiple charges of child sexual abuse in proceedings (details supplied) was employed for a number of years at Finglas Children's Centre, Dublin 11; and if so, the steps, if any, she is taking to investigate his activities while in this employment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I can confirm that the person referred to by the Deputy was never employed in the Finglas Children's Centre. However, I am aware that the person was employed in a range of facilities, including a former reformatory school and a former industrial school. I understand that there are a large number of charges against this person, many of which are already before the courts and that the case is still subject to extensive investigations by the Garda. In this context, my Department will continue to maintain contact with the Garda.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Age Profiles of Teachers.

Qst.Quest: if she will give a breakdown of the number of teachers, both male and female, in the current school year in the age categories of under 26 years, 26 to 30, 31 to 35, 36 to 40, 41 to 45, 46 to 50, 51 to 55, 56 to 60 and over 60.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is as follows:
Age Profile of National School Teachers

MainHeading.P: Age Profile of Second Level Teachers

Qst.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the school bus system is most unsatisfactory, namely due to constant breakdowns leading to pupils being late for school, children standing in the rain at pick-up points while waiting on such a bus, buses not turning up for transport at all, over loading of buses with many pupils standing in the aisle, the first pick-up in the morning being at 6.55 am and being left home at 5.05 pm and the wait outside school gates due to an insufficient number of buses; the way in which she proposes to deal with the matter; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department strives to provide the best possible level of school transport for all eligible pupils, with the resources available. The matters to which the Deputy refers are among those currently being considered by the School Transport Review Committee, which is expected to report later this year. When I have considered the recommendations of the committee, I will decide on any future changes to the school transport scheme.

Qst.Quest: if she will insist that all persons who are taking the H.Dip programme will have as a compulsory aspect of the course the ceard teastas gaeilge.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: All second level teachers are required to have a competent knowledge of the Irish language. The Registration Council for Secondary Teachers requires that an applicant for registration must produce evidence of this competence. Evidence can be afforded by tests carried out by either the Department of Education or by an Irish university, a representative of the Department being associated with the university's examiner for this purpose. The ceard teastas Gaeilge or an equivalent qualification is required for the purpose of appointment as a full-time permanent teacher in a vocational education committee or community or comprehensive school.

Qst.Quest: whether her Department will assist a child (details supplied) in Dublin 10 to obtain a psychological assessment in view of the fact that he has been refused access to two local second-level schools in September 1996, has a reading age of seven years and requires the assessment for a place in a special school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A member of the psychological service of my Department will arrange to carry out a psychological assessment of the young person mentioned in the Deputy's question. The arrangements for this assessment are being made at present. The matter of school placement will be considered after the assessment has been carried out.

Qst.Quest: if she has satisfied herself with the safety aspects of the current school transport system, particularly the situation where there are three students for every two seats.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Safety is of paramount importance to my Department and to Bus Éireann, which operates the school transport scheme on behalf of the Department. All aspects of safety, including carrying capacity, are monitored on an ongoing basis. Approximately 165,000 children are transported to school each day in safety. Bus Éireann's record of safety since the inception of the scheme in 1967, speaks for itself. Bus Éireann ensures that the loadings do not exceed the maximum legal carrying capacity of the different bus types in use. The maximum loading on school buses is calculated on the basis of three school children to every two adult seats, in accordance with legislation laid down by the Department of the Environment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Cork School Extension.

Qst.Quest: when funds will be made available to enable work to commence on an extension to a post primary school (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: An extension is currently being planned for the school in question. Architectural planning is proceeding and the project is currently at the developed sketch scheme stage. The design team's submission is being examined by the building unit's technical staff and a response will be conveyed to City of Cork Vocational Education Committee as soon as possible. Funds are being made available this year in respect of design fees. However, the question of providing capital funds for building will not arise until the planning process has been fully completed. Every effort is being made to have the planning of the extension completed as quickly as possible.

Qst.Quest: whether her Department will grant aid St. Mary's College, Arklow, County Wicklow, to enable the college relocate its science laboratory and to undertake the work consequential on this prior to September 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: An application for grantassistance towards the relocation of a science laboratory at St. Mary's College, Arklow, County Wicklow has been examined by my Department. The school authority has been requested to prepare and submit tender documentation for the project. This documentation is currently awaited.

Qst.Quest: if her Department will purchase the Ceardscoil, Fermoy, County Cork, from Cork County Vocational Educational Committee for Gaelscoil De hIde, Fermoy, County Cork, as per previous commitments.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the current position in relation to the signing over of title of the Old Vocational School, Fermoy, County Cork to the Board of Management of Gaelscoil de hIde, Fermoy, County Cork; and if she will give a definite date for the finalising of the takeover.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Question No. 457 and Question No. 463 together.

Details have yet to be finalised regarding the acquisition of the Old vocational school, Fermoy, County Cork for Gaelscoil de hÍde. I am therefore not in a position at present to indicate a definite date for the transfer of the property.

Qst.Quest: when a £3,000 grant from national lottery funding recently approved in respect of St. Joseph's GAA Club, Miltown Malbay, County Clare, will be paid to the club.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department has no record of having recently approved a grant of £30,000 for St. Joseph's GAA Club under the recreational facilities scheme. However, every consideration will be given to the application from the club when decisions are being made on grant allocations later this year.

Qst.Quest: if she will meet with a delegation from the Charleville and District Association for the Handicapped, County Cork to discuss the content of recent correspondence sent to her from the association.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware of the correspondence in question, which concerns the provision of escorts on the school transport system. In 1995, I allocated a sum of £150,000 for a pilot scheme of grant-aid towards the provision of escorts on certain school transport services. All applications for support under this scheme, including the application from the school in the area referred to by the Deputy, were carefully considered by my Department. Funding under the pilot scheme was allocated as follows: to special schools for physically handicapped children in respect of their transport routes; and to provide assistance towards the costs of escorts for pupils attending the special schools for the hearing-impaired and visually-impaired who travel long distances by bus and train at the weekends.

It will be necessary to fully evaluate the operation of the pilot phase before considering any modifications or expansion of the scheme. I can assure the Deputy that the needs of the children in the area in question will be given every consideration in the event of any further expansion of the scheme being undertaken. I regret that I am unable to arrange a meeting as requested by the Deputy as my diary is fully booked for the foreseeable future.

The School Transport Review Committee, established earlier this year, has been asked to review the arrangements for pupils in special schools. The provision of escort services and journey times will form part of this review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Grant Assistance for Full-Time Dance Students.

Qst.Quest: whether she will provide funding assistance for full-time dance students in Ireland; and if so, if she will provide funding in respect of the 1996/1997 academic year to a person (details supplied) in County Cork who is attending a professional ballet school in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Eligibility for grant assistance for full-time study at third level is determined under the provisions of the student support schemes. As the college which the student attends, the Gibson Madden School of Dance, is not an approved institution for the purposes of the third level student support schemes the student concerned is not eligible for grant aid in respect of her attendance there.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: when a development will be approved in respect of Adain national school, Oliver Plunkett Hill, Fermoy, County Cork; if her attention has been drawn to the fact that it is a minority religious group that is seeking grant aid; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department's planning section is currently examining an application by Adair national school, Fermoy, for an extension to the school. When this examination is completed, a decision will be conveyed to the school management. The application will be assessed entirely on its merits, without reference to the denominational status of the school.

Qst.Quest: whether two teachers (details supplied) in Bishop Galvin national school, Templeogue, Dublin 6, will be retained to honour the commitment previously given by her that the pupil-teacher ratio in all schools in Ireland will drop.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am committed to reducing the pupil-teacher ratio in primary schools. I would remind the Deputy that since taking office I have reduced the pupil-teacher ratio from 25.2:1 to 22.9:1; and this will be further reduced in the 1996-97 school year. The staffing of a national school for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on 30 September of the previous year. The enrolment of Bishop Galvin national school on 30 September, 1995 was 475 pupils. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and fifteen assistant teachers for the 1996-97 school year. In addition, the school also has the services of a remedial teacher. Accordingly, the sixteenth and seventeenth assistants' post at the school have been suppressed.

Qst.Quest: when she will allocate moneys towards the building programme for a sports hall for St. Mac Dara's Community College, taking into account that the design team for this project has been appointed for almost a year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The present position is that the architectural planning for the proposed PE hall at St. Mac Dara's Community College is proceeding and County Dublin vocational education committee have been requested submit the outline sketch scheme for the project. At this early stage of planning, the question of providing a capital allocation does not arise.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Access to EU Education Events.

Qst.Quest: the number of people from the general public who will have access to each education event or conference under the Irish Presidency of the European Union; the meaning of a reference in a recently published Department leaflet on the matter of access on a limited first-come first-served basis; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The number of people, generally, with access to Department of Education conferences and events during the Irish Presidency, will be contingent on factors such as the capacity of venues, cost, and degree of interest. While, Presidency conferences and events are, in the first instance, aimed at those with a direct interest in the theme of the conference or event, nonetheless the Department wishes to accommodate members of the general public who wish to attend. The number of people from the general public who will have access will be determined in due course, having regard to the factors outlined. The phrase “access on a limited first-come first-served basis”, means that in relation to conference places for the general public, the primary consideration governing their allocation will be in the order in which members of the public apply to the Department for entry to specific events.

Qst.Quest: the cost of a leaflet entitled Initiatives and Activities in Education under Ireland's Presidency of the European Union; the number of copies printed and circulated; the categories of people to whom the leaflet was sent; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Ten thousand copies of the document “Initiatives and Activities in Education”, relating to Ireland's Presidency of the European Union, have been printed at a cost of £3,250. The document is being circulated to a wide variety of interests including public representatives, the education partners, national and local press, first and second level schools, interests in member states, public libraries and the European Commission. The document is also available to the general public from the communications office in the Department of Education.

Qst.Quest: when construction will commence on the proposed new school at Allen, Kilmeague, County Kildare; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A major building project at Allen national school, Kilmeague, County Kildare, is included in my Department's capital building programme. My Department's architectural staff recently completed the working drawings for the project and a quantity surveyor has been engaged to prepare a cost plan and a bill of quantities. In the meantime, my Department will begin the pre-qualification tender process by placing an advertisement in the national press inviting contractors who are interested in tendering for the project to apply to my Department. At this stage, it is not possible to say when construction will commence on the project.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Offaly Disadvantaged Schools.

Qst.Quest: the schools in County Offaly being accorded disadvantaged status as a result of recent applications by various schools (details supplied) in County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, I recently launched an important new initiative which seeks to break the cycle of educational disadvantage in selected urban and rural areas. The initiative is in response to reports which I commissioned from the Combat Poverty Agency and the Education Research Centre. In line with the recommendations in the reports, a targeted programme of supports is being made available to 25 selected schools in designated areas of disadvantage in the Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Galway and Waterford urban areas. In addition, 25 clusters of small schools with fewer than five teachers and particularly those in rural areas with high levels of disadvantage, will receive a targeted programme of supports. Schools from all parts of the country with fewer than five teachers are eligible to apply for inclusion in this scheme. The Education Research Centre has recently been in touch with all the schools in question, inviting their application. The Education Research Centre is currently prioritising all applicants in terms of level of need as represented by the data submitted by the schools and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly. Schools selected as a result of this process will be invited to submit five-year development plans. Each such plan will be required to identify current difficulties and put forward specific proposals and targets for addressing the problems of educational disadvantage. Qualification for support will depend on the submission of suitable development plans.

Qst.Quest: if she will provide financial support to Irish students who wish to study in the Open University, in particular in the payment of fees; if so, the cost involved; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The student support schemes apply only to approved full-time courses in recognised institutions. The free fees initiative applies to approved full-time undergraduate courses in institutions which are recognised for the purposes of student support and are part of the CAO entry system. Open University courses do not meet these requirements and students pursuing the courses are therefore not eligible for grant assistance. It is estimated that the annual fee costs of Irish students pursuing Open University courses is over £1 million. It has been necessary to adopt this approach to the student support arrangements because of overall resource constraints. I would hope that as resources become available it will be possible to provide greater Exchequer support for part-time undergraduate students. The tax relief provisions for certain part-time courses in the Finance Act, 1996 are a welcome step forward in this regard.

Qst.Quest: if she will sanction the funds in respect of a new school (details supplied) in Louisburgh, County Mayo, in view of the fact that there are a number of issues which have to be addressed immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The construction of a new national school in Louisburgh, County Mayo, is nearing completion. The chairperson of the board of management indicated in a letter on 12 June that he would be in contact with my Department concerning some minor problems relating to the contract. When this communication is received, it will be considered within my Department and a decision conveyed to the school management.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Remedial Teachers.

Qst.Quest: if she will give a breakdown in numbers and locations of the allocated remedial teachers for the 106 out of 178 schools in County Donegal; and the locations of the other 72 primary schools as promised in her written reply to Parliamentary Question No. 128 of Wednesday, 12 June 1996.
the current position in relation to having a remedial teacher appointed to schools (details supplied) in County Donegal.
the current position in relation to having a remedial teacher appointed to schools (details supplied) in County Donegal.
the current position in relation to having a remedial teacher appointed to Scoil Naomh Brid, Muff, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 472, 473, 474 and 475 together.

The detailed information requested by the Deputy regarding the breakdown in numbers and locations of the schools which have a remedial service and the schools in County Donegal which do not have a remedial service, is not available yet. However, this information is currently being compiled within my Department and will be forwarded to the Deputy as soon as it becomes available. I am not in a position at present to make additional remedial teacher posts available to primary schools.

Since my appointment as Minister for Education, I have allocated an additional 241 remedial teachers to the primary sector. A total of 1,188 remedial teachers are now in place and the percentage of pupils who have access to a remedial service has increased from 77 per cent to 87 per cent. I consider that the substantial improvements which I have already achieved in this area provide practical confirmation of my commitment to the needs of the children in question. However, as Minister for Education I have to consider how best to deploy available resources across a wider range of special needs. I have to determine priorities and try to allocate resources to best effect.

MainHeading.P: During the period 1994-95, in addition to allocating an extra 155 remedial teachers, I adopted a particular focus on the needs of children attending special schools and classes. In addition to reducing the pupil teacher ratios in all such facilities, I provided a very substantial increase in the special capitation rates applicable in such cases. In the current year, I have adopted a particular focus on children who suffer from educational disadvantage and have sought to target resources into this area in an effort to break the cycle of disadvantage. As part of this approach, I recently launched a major new initiative aimed at bringing special targeted assistance to children in selected urban and rural areas who suffer serious educational disadvantage. I am satisfied that since my appointment as Minister for Education I have achieved substantial advances across the entire spectrum of special needs, including the remedial area. It is my intention to continue this process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Areas Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the reason a distinction is drawn between two primary schools in a particular town, one for boys and one for girls, in that one is given disadvantaged status while the other is not; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that the boys' school referred to by the Deputy has disadvantaged status since 1993. An application for disadvantaged status from the adjacent girls' school was considered in my Department in 1994 in the context of an expansion of the disadvantage areas scheme being undertaken at that time. Schools were selected for inclusion in the scheme at that time on the basis of priority of need as reflected by a range of socio-economic indicators. Account was also taken of the views of my Department's Inspectorate on the relative levels of need between schools and the prevailing pupil teacher ratios. The case put forward by the school in question was considered at that time. Unfortunately, when taking these factors into account, the needs of the school was not considered to be of such priority as to warrant its inclusion on that occasion. I have no plans at present to extend disadvantaged areas status to this school.

MainHeading.P: In response to the report from the Combat Poverty Agency and the Education Research Centre, I recently launched an important new initiative which seeks to break the cycle of educational disadvantage in selected urban and rural areas. In line with the recommendations of the report, a targeted programme of supports is being made available to 25 selected schools in designated areas of disadvantage in the Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford and Galway urban areas. In addition, 25 clusters of small schools with fewer than five teachers and particularly those in rural areas with high levels of disadvantage, will receive a targeted programme of supports. Schools from all parts of the country with fewer than five teachers are eligible to apply for inclusion in this scheme.

The Education Research Centre has recently been in touch with all the target schools and invited applications for consideration for support under the new initiative. The centre is currently prioritising all applicants in terms of level of need as represented by the data submitted by the school and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly. Schools selected as a result of this process will be invited to submit five year development plans. Each such plan will be required to identify current difficulties and put forward specific proposals and targets for addressing the problem of educational disadvantage. Qualification for support will depend on the submission of suitable development plans.

Qst.Quest: the funding being made available to ensure that St. Joseph's boys school, Moville, County Donegal, will be ready for amalgamation in September 1996.

the steps, if any, she is taking to ensure that the amalgamation of two schools in Moville, County Donegal, is completed on time for the commencement of the 1996/1997 academic year, to the satisfaction of parents, teachers and students in view of the fact that costings were to take place as a matter of urgency in early May and it is now the end of July and no repairs or building have commenced.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 478 and 500 together. The chairperson of the boards of management of the boys' and girls' national schools in Moville, County Donegal have informed the Department that agreement has been reached locally on the amalgamation of both schools. A report on the condition of St. Joseph's boys' school has been received within my Department. Clarification on certain aspects of this report has been sought together with a request for details of the condition of St. Brigid's girls' school. When this information is to hand, my Department will be in a better position to determine, both economically and educationally, how best the amalgamation process can be facilitated. At this point, I am unable to indicate a time-scale or costing for any necessary works.
The school management was advised of the position in a letter on 9 July last.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the proposed extension to De La Salle College, Dundalk, County Louth; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Architectural planning of the proposed extension at the school in question is progressing. The Stage IV — detail design — has been accepted by my Department. Sanction has been given to the school authorities to proceed to Stage V — bills of quantities. This documentation is now awaited.

Qst.Quest: when she proposes to authorise payments to a contractor (details supplied) who completed work for her Department in February 1996 at a school (details supplied) in view of the commitments in respect of the principle of prompt payments made in the programme A Government of Renewal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Approval was given in September 1993 for the employment of a replacement contractor to complete works which were outstanding at the school in question as a result of non-completion of the building contract by the original contractor. The new contract also included remedial work to the school roofs. All moneys officially approved by the Department in relation to the replacement contract have been paid in full by my Department's building unit. However, payment was sought in respect of additional roof works which were carried out at the school without the prior approval of my Department. The building unit of my Department are involved in ongoing negotiations with the school authorities with a view to resolving this matter and a decision will be made shortly.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the buildings and sites in County Louth under the ownership of his Department; the location of these sites; if such sites are currently in use by her Department; if not, the use which will be made of such sites; when it is envisaged to utilise these sites or buildings; the proposals, if any, there are to dispose of these sites or buildings; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The information sought by the Deputy is not readily available in my Department and I cannot justify assigning scarce staff resources to its compilation. If the Deputy has a concern about a particular site or building in the ownership of my Department, I would be happy to provide as much information as I can.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Grants.

Qst.Quest: if she will make a statement regarding the extension of higher education grants to third-level educational institutions within the EU; and if she will publish a comprehensive list of courses and colleges covered by the higher education grants scheme in the EU.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Means tested maintenance grants will be extended in the 1996-97 academic year to students following a full-time undergraduate course of at least two years' duration in an EU member state. The course must be followed in a university or third level institution which is maintained or assisted by the recurrent grants from public funds. The following courses are excluded: courses in Medicine, Dentistry, Veterinary Medicine — which are subject to a Higher Education Authority quota on places — and teacher training including those leading to the award of Bachelor of Education — also subject to a quota; courses in colleges of Further and Higher Education; courses in colleges akin to private commercial colleges in Ireland and courses provided in colleges in the EU which are offered in a private commercial third level college in Ireland and which are validated by that European college.

MainHeading.P: It is not feasible because of the range and number of colleges and courses that would be involved to publish a comprehensive list of colleges and courses. The criteria set out above are deemed adequate for this purpose. Colleges which can satisfactorily certify compliance with the criteria will be eligible for recognition.

Qst.Quest: if she will grant permission to a school (details supplied) in County Cork to use a grant provided for temporary accommodation to be applied for the purpose of constructing permanent additional accommodation where the school concerned will meet the additional costs out of its own resources.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department has no record of having received a request to use a grant provided for temporary accommodation towards the cost of a permanent structure at the school referred to by the Deputy. If a request is received, it will be considered within my Department and a decision will be conveyed to the school management.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Additional Assistance for Schools.

Qst.Quest: if she will confirm her commitment outlined in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress (details supplied) and in the Programme for Competitiveness and Work (details supplied) to provide additional grant aid to all primary schools of 100 pupils upwards for caretaking and clerical services; if so, whether this commitment will be honoured by September 1996, at the commencement of the new school year and before the expiry of the Programme for Competitiveness and Work agreement in December 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I remain committed to the provision of additional assistance to schools for caretaking and clerical services. Since 1992, the scheme of additional capitation grants to primary schools in respect of clerical and caretaking services has been expanded in line with the Programme for Economic and Social Progress-Programme for Competitiveness and Work undertakings. The scheme has been extended to more schools by a reduction of the qualifying enrolment towards the target of schools with 100 pupils or more. However, present indications are that, in light of current resource constraints, it will not be possible to meet this target by September 1996.

Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the proposed new primary school in Farranfore, County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I take it that the Deputy's question relates to Knockaderry national school in Farranfore, County Kerry. The architectural planning work for the new school is completed and my Department is beginning the pre-qualification tender process by placing an advertisement in the National Press inviting contractors who are interested in tendering for the project to apply to my Department.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: when approval will issue to Whitegate national school, Midleton, County Cork, for a general purpose room which is urgently needed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Due to the current level of contractual commitments on the Primary Capital Programme, it is not possible to provide grant assistance towards a general purpose room at Whitegate national school. While I am anxious to extend the provision of general purpose facilities in primary schools, the pace at which this can be achieved will be dictated by the financial resources available and the priority must remain the provision of essential classroom accommodation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Space Requirements for School Construction.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the land area required for a post primary school of 400 pupils and 600 pupils; the criteria used in determining space requirements, for example square feet/metres per pupil and the surrounding recreational space needed; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The optimum land area of a site for a post primary school of 400 to 600 pupils is eight to 12 acres depending on site conditions. However, when schools are being planned each case is considered individually and the decision is based on a number of factors which include availability, location and cost. The area norm of a new school building or a major extension is calculated on a figure of six square metres per pupil which includes teaching spaces, administration, toilets, social areas and circulation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the number of the 11 acres at the site on Scholarstown Road, Knocklyon, Dublin 16, owned by her Department and purchased in 1982 for a post-primary school, that would be required for accommodating the proposed Gaelscoil Cnoc Liamhna; the space area of the site being considered; the type of building proposed; the likely commencement date; where the Gaelscoil will be accommodated from September 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I recently decided to grant provisional recognition to Gaelscoil Cnoc Liamhna, Knocklyon, Dublin 16. In accordance with established practice, the provision of accommodation for the gaelscoil during the period of provisional recognition is a matter for the promoters and I understand that, in this case, they intend to locate the school initially in the Scouts' Hall in Knocklyon. In the circumstances, there is no immediate requirement for a permanent site for the school. Normally, a gaelscoil would get provisional recognition in the first instance and would be in operation for a few years before its viability can be confirmed and permanent recognition granted. It is only at this stage that the school could apply for capital grant-aid towards the purchase of a site and the provision of a school building. A general guideline for primary school sites gives a requirement of around 2.5 acres for an 8-room school and three acres for a 16-room school. I intend to monitor the progress of the new gaelscoil closely and will consider what action is appropriate in relation to the site on Scholarstown Road in that context.

Qst.Quest: when she intends to give a full and comprehensive reply to correspondence dated 18 June 1996, from a parent of a 1996 leaving certificate honours student (details supplied) in Dublin 9 regarding the marking of the 1996 leaving certificate honours paper II.

the way in which the error in the 1996 leaving certificate honours examination paper II is being dealt with by examiners; and if full credit will be given to students for Part C of the question irrespective of whether they began or finished that particular section of the question.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to reply to Questions Nos. 489 and 490 together.

As I stated on 25 June last in reply to a previous question, the original marking scheme for question 4 (c) of the Leaving Certificate Higher Level Mathematics Paper (II) examination has been adapted. Examiners have been instructed to accept either the value of the angle as indicated on the paper or the value of the angle — which may be obtained from observation of the diagram — in the formula. Where an attempt has been made, due allocation of marks has been given subject to the usual deductions as indicated on the marking scheme. Where a candidate has stated that there is a problem with the question, full marks has been given. I should add that I have been advised that question 4 (c) was very popular and well answered and that there were only two cases — out of a total of 10,500 candidates — where the candidate stated that there was a problem with the question. I am arranging to have the above information forwarded to the correspondent referred to by the Deputy.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to amend the School Transport Act, 1967.

if she recognises the very serious difficulties young children experience in rural Ireland as a result of the school transport system; and the steps, if any, she intends to take to redress this difficulty.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 492 and 493 together. There is no School Transport Act, 1967, but there is a school transport scheme, which is administered by my Department. The terms of the scheme are currently being examined by the school transport review committee, which is expected to make recommendations later this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Remedial Teachers.

Qst.Quest: the current status of an application for a remedial teacher for schools (details supplied) in County Limerick; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the number of primary schools in County Clare which do not have the services of a remedial teacher available to them; and the total enrolment of these schools in September 1995.
the number of new remedial teachers that will be appointed to schools in County Clare in September 1996.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the serious concern in County Clare in regard to the proposal of the non-appointment of any remedial teachers to the county in September 1996; and the plans, if any, she has in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 494, 519, 520 and 546 together.

I am not in a position at present to make additional remedial teacher posts available to the schools referred to by the Deputies or to any primary schools. The total number of ordinary national schools in County Clare is 122, 63 of these schools, with an enrolment of 8,941 pupils on 30 September 1995, have the services of a remedial teacher available to them. The number of ordinary national schools in County Clare which do not have the services of a remedial teacher is 62. The combined enrolment of the 62 schools on 30 September 1995 was 3,294.

MainHeading.P: Since my appointment as Minister for Education, I have allocated an additional 241 remedial teachers to the primary sector. A total of 1,188 remedial teachers are now in place and the percentage of pupils who have access to a remedial service has increased from 77 per cent to 87 per cent. The substantial improvements which I have already achieved in this area provide practical confirmation of my commitment to the needs of the children in question. However, as Minister for Education I have to consider how best to deploy available resources across a wider range of special needs. I have to determine priorities and try to allocate resources to best effect.

During the period 1994-1995, in addition to allocating an extra 155 remedial teachers, I adopted a particular focus on the needs of children attending special schools and classes. In addition to reducing the pupil teacher ratios in all such facilities, I provided a very substantial increase in the special capitation rates applicable in such cases. In the current school year, I have adopted a particular focus on children who suffer from educational disadvantage and have sought to target resources into this area in an effort to break the cycle of disadvantage. As part of this approach, I recently launched a major new initiative aimed at bringing special targeted assistance to children in selected urban and rural areas who suffer serious educational disadvantage. I am satisfied that since my appointment as Minister for Education I have achieved substantial advances across the entire spectrum of special needs, including the remedial area. It is my intention to continue this process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Allocation of Whole-Time Teacher.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the reason a permanent whole-time teacher has not been made available to a school (details supplied) in County Galway; if her attention has been drawn to the negative attitude being displayed by her Department towards young persons who cannot speak for themselves; if she will treat this case with the utmost compassion and allocate a whole-time permanent teacher to this school and class as a matter of urgency; if so, when; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: On the basis of recommendations from my Department's Psychological Service and having regard to the projected number of students my Department has allocated 0.5 whole-time teacher equivalent to the County Galway Vocational Education Committee to meet the needs of the class in the 1996-97 school year. If the enrolment increases in the future my Department will review the case for the allocation of additional staffing resources for the class.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if she has completed her consideration of an application for the establishment of a gaelscoil in the general Whitehall area of Dublin 9; if approval will be given to commence the school in September 1996; the number of applications for new gaelscoileanna that have been submitted nationally in 1996; and the number of applications approved to date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A detailed examination of the application for provisional recognition of a gaelscoil in Whitehall, Dublin 9 has been completed in my Department. Having given due consideration to the matter, I have decided that the application should be refused in light of the negative impact which the establishment of a gaelscoil in the area would have on the enrolments of neighbouring schools. My Department is in the process of advising the promoters of this decision. In all, 14 applications for the establishment of gaelscoileanna have been submitted to my Department in 1996. Of these, six have been approved to date, five have been refused and a decision on the remaining three applications is expected imminently.

Qst.Quest: the amount of grant aid paid to projects from the capital sports grant scheme each year since its inception; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the total amount of grant aid paid under the recreational facilities scheme, which is funded by the national lottery, each year since its inception; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 497 and 498 together. Expenditure for each year up to 1994 is published in the appropriation accounts for the relevant year. I also refer the Deputy to my reply to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 125 and 126 dated 19 June 1996. Expenditure in 1995 was as follows:

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Early Start Pre-School Programme.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to provide an Early Start Programme in the 1996-97 school year for amalgamated schools (details supplied) in Dublin 7; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have no plans at present to extend the Early Start Pre-school Programme. The Early Start Pre-school Programme is currently focused on schools serving areas which have been identified as being particularly disadvantaged.
The programme has been expanded in the current school year by the inclusion of a further 25 pre-school projects. This brings the total number of projects now in place to 32.

I have also established an expert monitoring committee to advise me on the operation and future development of the Early Start Pre-school Programme. This committee is representative of a wide range of interests involved in the provision of pre-school services.
The needs of this newly amalgamated school will be considered in the context of any future development of the Early Start Programme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Fore (Westmeath) School.

Qst.Quest: the result of an inspector's visit to review the remedial needs of the children at St. Feichen's National School, Fore, County Westmeath; and if she will review the need for this school to retain its second assistant teacher in view of all of the circumstances which have been conveyed to her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The staffing of a ordinary national school for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on 30 September of the previous year.
The enrolment of St. Fiechen's national school on 30 September 1995 was 56 pupils. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and one assist and teacher for the 1996-97 school year
In the circumstances, I regret that am unable to accede to the Deputy' request to allow the retention of the second assistant teacher's post at the school for the 1996-97 school year.

MainHeading.P: In addition to the staffing mentioned above, the school has the services of a shared remedial teacher. However, I understand that there has been a problem regarding the provision of the remedial service in St. Feichen's national school. I have requested my Department's Primary Inspectorate to investigate the situation and bring forward proposals to overcome this problem.

Qst.Quest: the arrangements, if any, in place each year by the primary teacher training colleges in respect of the intake of mature students; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A separate competition to enable mature students (i.e. those 23 years or over) to secure entry to the three year Bachelor of Education degree course is held annually in colleges of education. Selection is by means of a competitive interview and oral Irish test.
The number of places available for mature students is determined in the light of the overall approved intake to the colleges of education in eary year.

In addition, the special post-graduate course for the training of teachers beginning in January 1997 will also afford an opportunity for mature students, who meet the conditions, to train as primary teachers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Postgraduate Course for Primary Teachers.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in a formal announcement of a further postgraduate intake for primary teaching in view of the fact that she made an announcement some time ago in respect of this matter; if all details of this course will now be announced; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have already announced that I will be introducing a further postgraduate course for the training of primary teachers. This course, subject to the formal agreement of the college authorities, will begin in January 1997 and will provide places for 150 students.
Further details in relation to the course will be announced when the consultation process with the college authorities is complete.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Additional Teaching Posts.

Qst.Quest: if she will urgently reconsider and review the needs of Down's Syndrome and other children in the east Clare area who have become integrated in local national schools but who clearly need a specialist teacher to allow them to further the integration process and to allow for the further potential of personal, social and academic needs of these children to be realised.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Qst.Quest: if she will have arrangements made to approve a resource class for a school (details supplied) in County Cork.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Qst.Quest: if she will approve a resource teacher to be shared amongst three schools (details supplied) in County Cork.
the number of the 300 primary teachers available for redeployment due to falling pupil enrolments that will be appointed as resource teachers to rural schools.
the number of the 300 primary teachers available for redeployment due to falling pupil enrolments that will be appointed to schools in County Clare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 504, 508, 509, 517 and 518 together.
I am not in a position to make additional resource teacher posts available to the schools referred to by the Deputies or to any primary schools.

Since my appointment as Minister for Education, I have allocated an additional 241 remedial teachers and 29 resource teachers to the primary sector. A total of 1,188 remedial teachers and 36 resource teachers are now in place.
I consider that substantial improvements which I have already achieved in this area provide practical confirmation of my commitment to the needs of the children in question.

However, as Minister for Education I have to consider how best to deploy available resources across a wider range of special needs. I have to determine priorities and try to allocate resources to best effect.

During the period 1995-1996, in addition to allocating an extra 155 remedial teachers and 23 resource teachers, I adopted a particular focus on the needs of children attending special schools and classes. In addition to reducing the pupil teacher ratios in all such facilities, I provided a very substantial increase in the special capitation rates applicable in such cases.

In the current school year, I have adopted a particular focus on children who suffer from educational disadvantage and have sought to target resources into this area in an effort to break the cycle of disadvantage. As part of this approach, I recently launched a major new initiative aimed at bringing special targeted assistance to children in selected urban and rural areas who suffer serious educational disadvantage.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that since my appointment as Minister for Education I have achieved substantial advances across the entire spectrum of specials needs, including the resource teaching area. It is my intention to continue this process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Schools Scheme.

Qst.Quest: if a school (details supplied) in County Cork will be included in the scheme for special disadvantaged schools as announced by her on 9 May 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, I recently launched an important new initiative which seeks to break the cycle of educational disadvantage in selected urban and rural areas. The initiative is in response to reports which I commissioned from the Combat Poverty Agency and the Education Research Centre.

In line with the recommendations in the reports, a targeted programme of supports is being made available to twenty-five selected schools in designated areas of disadvantage in the Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Galway and Waterford urban areas.

In addition, 25 clusters of small schools with fewer than five teachers and particularly those in rural areas with high levels of disadvantage will receive a targeted programme of supports. Schools from all parts of the country with fewer than five teachers are eligible to apply for inclusion in this scheme.

The Educational Research Centre has recently been in touch with all the schools in question, inviting their application. The centre will prioritise all applicants in terms of level of need as represented by the data submitted by the schools and will advise my Department of the outcome shortly.

MainHeading.P: Schools selected as a result of this process will be invited to submit five year development plans. Each such plan will be required to identify current difficulties and put forward specific proposals and targets for addressing the problems of educational disadvantage. Qualification for support will depend on the submission of suitable development plans.

On the basis of the information currently available to my Department, the school in question would be eligible for consideration for support under the scheme and will have recently been invited by the Education Research Centre to submit an application for inclusion in the scheme.

Qst.Quest: when grant aid will be allocated for the repair of the roof of Oughterard Community Centre, County Galway; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I can confirm that my Department has received a completed application form from Oughterard Community Centre seeking additional grant-aid under the Recreational Facilities Scheme.
Every consideration will be given to the application when decisions are being made on grant allocations later this year.

Qst.Quest: if she will grant disadvantaged status and an over-quota teaching post to St. Mary's Central School, Killenaule, Thurles, County Tipperary, in view of the fact that the school has lost two teaching posts for the 1996-97 academic school year, the local vocational school, Scoil Ruain, has been granted disadvantage status, the housing authority Respond is currently undertaking the development of 18 new housing units and the local authority is planning the development of a further 28 new housing units; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware the staffing of a national school for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on 30 September of the previous year.
The enrolment of the school in question on 30 September 1995 was 240 pupils. This enrolment warrants a staffing of a principal and seven assistant teachers for the 1996-97 school year.
In addition to the staffing mentioned above, the school has the services of a shared remedial teacher.
In the circumstances, the eighth and ninth assistant's posts at the school have been suppressed.
