MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Foot Patrols.

Qst.Quest: her current policy in respect of the provision of foot patrols by An Garda Síochána in suburban areas; the reason such patrols are not carried out; and if she will make a statement on the policy of foot patrols generally
her views on the need and importance of Garda foot patrols in each area; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 590 and 647 together.
The deployment of Garda personnel in individual areas is a matter for the Garda authorities.

MainHeading.P: They have informed me that it is the policy of An Garda Síochána to have foot patrols performed in all areas. The local deployment of personnel is a matter for the local district officer who ensures that personnel are deployed in accordance with the local priorities and available resources. The Garda authorities assure me that where particular problem areas are identified by local management mobile and foot patrols are arranged as required.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dundalk (Louth) Garda Station.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: further to her reply to a parliamentary question raised by Deputy Ahern in relation to the reduction of Garda numbers in Dundalk, County Louth, if it was taken into account that an inspector had already been moved to Drogheda and that the position of collator, which had been vacant, had not yet been replaced; whether the position of collator will be filled in Drogheda and not in Dundalk; the total number of personnel, Garda and civilian, who will be transferred or have been transferred to Drogheda further to the divisional headquarters move; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I understand from the Garda authorities, who are responsible for the detailed deployment of Garda personnel and resources to individual areas, that prior to September 1994, there were two uniform inspectors in both Dundalk and Drogheda Garda stations. When an inspector in Drogheda retired in September 1994, his replacement was allocated to Dundalk. In February this year this new inspector transferred to Drogheda to assist in the preparatory arrangements for the transfer of the divisional headquarters, thus restoring the status quo in relation to uniform inspectors in both stations.

I have also been informed by the Garda authorities that the position of collator will be filled at Drogheda station. However, should the current collator not transfer to Drogheda it is envisaged that he will be absorbed into the uniform operational strength at Dundalk.

MainHeading.P: I understand that it is planned to transfer the following personnel from Dundalk station to Drogheda station when the proposed transfer of divisional headquarters is effected: one chief superintendent; one superintendent; two sergeants; seven gardaí; one clerical assistant (typist).
As outlined in my previous reply to Deputy Ahern, all of the above staff are associated with the functions of the divisional headquarters.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Deployment.

Qst.Quest: her views on the current numerical strength of the Garda Síochána in the Carrigaline area of County Cork; and if she will allocate additional resources to ensure a greater number of gardaí in this particular area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Garda authorities are responsible for the detailed allocation of Garda personnel and resources to individual areas. They have informed me that the present strength of Carrigaline Garda station is two sergeants and ten gardaí. I understand that the strength of Carrigaline station will be examined, in conjunction with the needs of other stations, districts and divisions, when gardaí next become available for allocation.

Qst.Quest: her views on the current numerical strength of the Garda Síochána in Cork city; and if she will allocate additional resources to ensure a greater number of Gardaí on the streets of Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The detailed allocation of Garda personnel and resources to individual areas is a matter for the Garda authorities. They have informed me that the Cork City Division comprises the Anglesea Street, Togher, Mayfield and Gurranabraher Garda districts.
The current total strength of the division is 549, which is made up of the following ranks:

MainHeading.P: The total divisional strengths — all ranks — for the previous two years were: 31 December 1994, 570; 31 December 1995, 560.

The decreased in strength is attributable to the fact that Fermoy, which was part of the Cork City Division, is now a divisional headquarters in its own right. I understand from the Garda authorities that the question of allocating additional gardaí to the Cork City Division will be examined, in conjunction with the needs of other divisions in the country, when gardaí next become available for allocation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Reachhtú um Chiontaí in Aghaidh an Stáit.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: cén líon daoine ar eisíodh barántais chuardaigh ina leith faoi alt 29 den Acht um Chiontaí in Aghaidh an Stáit chun a gcuid tithe a chuardach i gContae na Gaillimhe le mí anuas; cén bonn ar ar eisíodh na barántais sin agus cé air a raibh an t-amhras bunaithe go raibh rudaí á gcoinneáil acu go mídhleathach; agus an ndéanfaidh sí ráiteas ina thaobh.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: an dtabharfaidh sí ainmneacha agus seoltaí na ndaoine ar eisíodh barántais chuardaigh ina leith faoi alt 29 den Acht um Chiontaí in Aghaidh an Stáit i gContae na Gaillimhe le mí anuas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Tóghfaidh me Ceisteanna Uimh. 594 agus 595 le chéile.

Tuigtear ó Údaráis an Gharda Síochána gur eisíodh barántais chuardaigh faoin alt úd i leith 54 áitribh i gContae na Gaillimhe idir 29 Meitheamh agus 19 Iúil, 1996. De réir an ailt, féadfaidh comhalta den Gharda Síochána, nach ísle céim ná Ceannfort, barántas a eisiúint más deimhin leis go bhfuil cúis réasúnach ann chun a chreidiúint go bhfuil fianaise ar chionta áirithe nó i dtaobh cionta áirithe ar fáil in aon áit atá ainmnithe sa bharántas. Níl sé mar chleachtadh ag na Garda faisnéis a thabhairt ar an mbonn ar eisíodh barántas cuardaigh ná ar ainm ná ar sheoladh aon duine atá ainmnithe i mbarántas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Deployment.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to deal with the ongoing problem of the lack of a Garda presence in Bunclody, County Wexford, which is causing grave concern to the local community where a number of robberies have taken place recently; and if her attention has been drawn to the fact that a Garda car from Bunclody was absent from the area for a number of days due to the Golf Classic at Druid's Glen, County Wicklow, which was totally unacceptable to the residents of Bunclody.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The detailed allocation of Garda personnel and resources to individual areas is a matter for the Garda authorities. I understand from them that the current strength of Bunclody Garda station is four gardaí. The station is supervised by a sergeant from Courtown station. One of the gardaí from Bunclody station is temporarily assigned to Courtown for the July-August holiday period.
The station at Bunclody is open daily between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. and when unmanned a direct communications link placing members of the public in contact with the Garda at Gorey is in operation.

MainHeading.P: I have been informed by the Garda authorities that there is a patrol car attached to the station and on certain days during the Irish open golf championship at Druid's Glen it was necessary to divert the car to other duties. However, during these periods I understand that patrols were carried out by the traffic corps, thereby maintaining continuity of Garda service to the Bunclody area.
The Garda authorities have stated that to date in 1996 there have been no robberies recorded in the area. In fact, crime statistics for Bunclody for the past three years indicate a downward trend.

The Garda authorities have informed me that they are satisfied with the current level of policing in Bunclody and that they do not intend increasing these levels at present. However, they will continue to keep the matter under review.

Qst.Quest: the number of indictable offences in respect of murder, manslaughter, assault, robbery, rape, sexual assault, burglaries, larcenies and interference with cars in respect of each of the years from 1991 to 1994 in the districts of Waterford Ballybricken, Aglish Cappoquin, Ardmore, Ballyduff, Ballymacarbery, Cappoquin Barrack Street, Dungarvin, Dunmore East, Ferrybank, Kill, Kilmacthomas, Kilmeaden, Lemybrien, Lismore, Passage East, Portlaw, Rathgormac, Ring, Stradbally, Tallow, Tramore and Galway Mill Street, County Waterford; and the manning levels in each of these stations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that the information requested is not available in the format sought by the Deputy and could not be compiled without a disproportionate expenditure of Garda time and resources. Such information as can be readily compiled will be supplied to the Deputy as soon as possible. Crime statistics under a number of headings are available in the annual reports of An Garda Síochána which are laid in the Oireachtas Library each year.

Qst.Quest: when further planned works will be undertaken at Mill Street and Salthill Garda Stations, Galway; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: It is planned to build extensions at both the Mill Street and Salthill Garda stations. While is is not possible to say at this time when the proposed works will commence, they will be progressed as quickly as possible having regard to overall priorities and the availability of finance.

Qst.Quest: the number of indictable offences in respect of murder, manslaughter, assault, robbery, rape, sexual assault, burglaries, larcenies and interference with cars in respect of each of the years from 1991 to 1994 in the districts of Ahascragh, Ardrahan, Athenry, Ballinasloe, Ballygar, Ballymoe, Barnderg, Corofin, Dunmore, Eyrecourt, Glenamaddy, Gort, Kiltomer, Kilconly, Kiltulla, Kinvara, Menlough, Milltown, Mount Bellew, Portumna, Tuam, Tynagh and Williamstown, County Galway; and the manning levels in each of these stations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that the information requested is not available in the format sought by the Deputy and could not be compiled without a disproportionate expenditure of Garda time and resources. Such information as can be readily compiled will be supplied to the Deputy as soon as possible. Crime statistics under a number of headings are available in the annual reports of An Garda Síochána which are laid in the Oireachtas Library each year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Service Retirements and Career Breaks.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the number of staff in the Public Service who have, since 1 January 1992, applied for early retirement, re-deployment or career breaks; the number of staff in her Department who have made successful application; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy in respect of the number of staff who have applied for career breaks since 1 January 1992 in my Department is set out in the following table.

row.entry: No. of Applications for Career Breaks
Offices of Charitable Donations and Bequests

MainHeading.P: All applications with the exception of 12 in the Garda Síochána, one in the prison service and one in the courts service were granted.

There has been no scheme for early retirement and no applications for redeployment in the Department of Justice from 1992. There have been 683 voluntary retirements in the Garda Síochána for the period concerned, i.e. members who retired before having reached the statutory maximum retirement age. The Garda authorities have stated that redeployment of members within the Garda Síochána is an integral part of the efficient administration of the force. Movement of members will arise for a variety of reasons including the exigencies of the service, special unforseen circumstances, United Nations duties etc.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the total number of prisoners under the age of 25 years; the total number of prisoners over the age of 25 years; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The precise information requested by the Deputy is not readily available. However, the following statistical information on the age profile of those in custody may be of assistance:
On 15 June 1996, of a total population of 2, 182, 545 persons were under 21 years of age, 1,007 persons were over 21 but under 30 years of age and 630 were 30 years of age or over.
Persons in custody under the age of 30 years generally represent about 70 per cent of the total population on any one day.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the number of female prisoners in Irish prisons; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Female offenders are detained in two institutions: one located at Mountjoy prison and the other at Limerick prison. On Monday, 22 July 1996, 52 female offenders were in custody — 40 in Mountjoy prison and 12 in Limerick prison.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the cost of keeping a prisoner in prison for one week.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The weekly cost of the operation of the prison system per head of the prisoner population was approximately £860 in 1995, based on the 1995 outturn.

This figure does not include any element in respect of capital expenditure or expenditure not connected with the running of the prisons e.g. probation and welfare service and community service orders scheme. Relevant costs borne on other Votes are included, such as superannuation, teachers salaries.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Louth Departmental Property.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the buildings and sites in County Louth under the ownership of his Department; the location of these sites; if such sites are currently in use by her Department; if not, the use which will be made of such sites; when it is envisaged to utilise these sites or buildings; the proposals, if any, there are to dispose of these sites or buildings; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: For the purpose of replying to the Deputy, I am concentrating on buildings and properties which are owned — the Department occupies a large number of properties on a leasehold basis, throughout the State.
In relation to County Louth, the only building which is owned by my Department is Dundalk Garda station. It is in current use and there are no plans to dispose of it.

MainHeading.P: However, a disproportionate expenditure of official resources would be involved in attempting to compile particulars of old custodial properties, if any, in County Louth — disused, as such, throughout most of this century — and largely handed over for decades for use by local authorities or, in the case of some former staff dwelling houses, rented to occupants.

Qst.Quest: when a land registry file plan will be supplied to a person (details supplied) in County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that a copy folio and the file plan referred to, which were applied for on 27 June 1996, were issued on 22 July 1996.

Qst.Quest: if she will have arrangements made to issue a map of a folio (details supplied) to an applicant's solicitor.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that the map referred to, which was applied for on 15 July 1996, was issued on 22 July 1996.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Marriage Notification Exemptions.

the number of application made pursuant to section 33 of the Family Law Act, 1995, up to and including 31 July 1996, to dispense with the necessity to give three months prior notice of marriage; the number of such orders granted; the number refused; and the courts to which such applications were made.

Family Law Act, 1995 — Applications for exemptions from 3 months notice of marriage

row.entry: No. of applications due to be heard

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: if she has considered amending the law regarding the identification of alleged criminals by members of the public who currently must physically place their hands on the person identified in a formal identification parade; if she has given consideration to the use of one way glass partitions for such identification parades; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that under the guidelines governing the holding of identification parades there is no requirement for a witness to place his or her hand on a suspect and that it is sufficient for the witness to clearly point out the person being identified.

It is also the case that the Supreme Court has stated that there is no rule of law or practice that requires visual identification in all cases to be by means of an identification parade: each case must be considered on its facts.

The overriding consideration in any identification procedure is to exclude any suspicion of unfairness or the risk of erroneous identification and to make sure the ability of the witness to recognise the suspect has been fairly and adequately tested. The inherent fairness or otherwise of the procedure followed at the identification parade is among the matters which can be questioned by the defence in the course of any subsequent trial.

Clearly complex issues arise and any changes in existing procedures could only take place after very detailed consideration. While I understand that the Garda authorities envisage difficulties arising in relation to the proposal in the Deputy's question, I shall keep the question of changes in this area generally under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Use of Syringes in Crime.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the increase in the use of syringes with hypodermic needles, in the commission of robberies, aggravated burglaries, muggings, assaults and injuries to gardaí; the plans, if any, she has to introduce legislation to specifically cover the carrying and use of syringes in view of the 53 per cent increase in recorded statistics of the use of syringes in crime between the years 1993 and 1995; whether 67 per cent of the 12 months total for 1995 for the use of syringes in crime was already recorded in the first half of 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am aware of the increase in the use of syringes as a weapon in the commission of an offence.

While there is no specific offence of using a syringe as a weapon, the criminal law already includes penalties up to life imprisonment for offences involving the use of a syringe in the course of committing a robbery or other offence. The possession of a syringe in a public place is also prohibited under the Firearms and Offences Weapons Act, 1990.

Legislation to reform the law relating to non-fatal offences against the person is at present being drafted and if I believe that some further strengthening of the law in this area is required or would produce some actual benefit I will consider it in that context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Applications for Copy Folios.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: the number of applications for copy folios requested before 1 June 1996, that have not been provided; the reason for the delay in providing copy folios; the steps, if any, she intends to take to ensure that all copy folios requested are provided within two weeks from date of lodgement of a request; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that, on 1 June 1996, there were approximately 12,900 applications for copy folios and file plans on hands in the Land Registry. This figure must be viewed against the Land Registry's output for this category of business which, in the five month period 1 January to 31 May 1996, was 53,241 applications for copy folio maps and file plans.

MainHeading.P: The ten week period of industrial action by members of the CPSU affected the operations of the Land Registry in common with other Government Departments. During this period, the efforts of the Land Registry to reduce the arrears were hampered since priority was given to servicing personal callers in the various public offices of the Land Registry and the Registry of Deeds. In consequence, applications lodged by post in the registries were affected for the duration of the dispute.

Despite these difficulties, however, the current position is that the period for issue of the majority of applications for copy folios and file plans ranges from one day to 14 days, depending on the region of the Land Registry involved. However, in case where queries arise in relation to the application, completion can be delayed.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: when copies of folios (details supplied) in County Galway, requested by Deputy Ó Cuív on 13 March 1996 and 28 March 1996, will be provided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that a copy folio with map attached issued in respect of Folio 7258F County Galway on 6 June 1996.

I am also informed that the reference by the Deputy to Folio 2405 County Galway appears to be incorrect but that an application for a copy folio in respect of Folio 22405 County Galway is currently being dealt with. In this case, I understand that the Land Registry are awaiting estate maps from the Land Commission in order to prepare the copy folio requested.

Qst.Quest: if she will have arrangements made to expedite a dealing for a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that there is no dealing currently pending on Folio 15805F which was formerly part of Folio 3526F. If the Deputy can let me have any further Land Registry reference — dealing number or date of lodgement — which may be available, I will have further inquiries made with the Land Registry and I will write to the Deputy to let him know the position.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Community Policing.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the date on which community policing was introduced; the location/district/areas in this country where community policing operates; the number of Garda personnel of all ranks involved in community policing; the number of reviews of community policing which have taken place since its introduction; the dates of each review; the number of reports produced by Ministers for Justice; if community policing is currently under review; if so, the date on which this review commenced; when it will be concluded; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The scheme of rural community policing was introduced in June 1982 on a pilot basis in the districts of Thomastown, County Kilkenny and Claremorris, County Mayo.

In 1989, following a review of the scheme by Garda management and officials of my Department, it was recommended that the initiative be extended to a further 12 locations and in September 1991 the scheme was extended to the following Districts:

MainHeading.P: The Garda Commissioner, following a review in June 1994, submitted a report to my Department outling proposals for a further extension of the scheme. These proposals are still the subject of discussions between my Department and the Garda authorities. While I expect these discussions to be concluded in the near future, it is, of course, vital that all aspects of such proposals be carefully examined and reviewed in the context of current demands being placed on the Garda Síochána. I am particularly anxious to ensure that there will be sufficient consultation with local interest groups before any decision is made to extend the scheme.
No ministerial reports on the scheme of rural community policing have been produced.
There are currently 535 members of the force deployed on rural community policing duties throughout the country.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: whether a change in traffic speeding fines to an on-the-spot fine system would greatly assist in releasing Gardaí from Court attendance and onto the streets; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Minister for the Environment is at present drafting Regulations under the Road Traffic Acts, 1961 to 1994 to provide for on-the-spot fines for certain categories of speeding offences, following consultations between senior representatives of the Department of the Environment, my Department and the Garda authorities.

It is not possible to say how many speeding offences will be dealt with by way of issuing fine-on-the-spot notices when the regulations are made. Neither is it possible to say how many of such fines would be paid before the need to proceed by summons arose.
The Garda Síochána annual report for 1994 shows that there were 37,478 prosecutions for speeding offences in that year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ballymun (Dublin) Garda Station.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the current staffing levels at Ballymun Garda Station, Dublin 11; the staff numbers envisaged when the station was originally planned and erected; the facilities currently available; the criteria under which Garda stations are built; the amounts allocated for construction of stations in each division over the past 15 years; and the reason the north side of Dublin has fared so badly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The current strength, all ranks, at Ballymun station is 50 members. The number serving when the station was built was around 45. However, the increased level of activity at the station and the need for additional facilities has rendered the existing building inadequate.
The facilities currently available at Ballymun include:
Parade Room
Male Toilet
Doctor's Room
Public Office
Reception Area
Waiting/Interview Room
Cells (2)
Car Compound
Locker Room
Ladies Toilet
Kitchen
District Detective Unit
Det. Sergeant Office
Interview
Warrant/Summons Office

Garda stations are built in compliance with standard briefs of requirements which were agreed by a committee established to review the Garda Building Programme in 1993 on which both Garda management and staff were represented. Priorities are assessed on an annual basis and again the Garda Representative Associations are consulted in this regard.

MainHeading.P: The information requested to the amounts allocated for construction of Garda stations in each Division over the last 15 years is not readily available as records of expenditure are not maintained on a divisional basis. The total amount allocated this year is £9 million.
I cannot accept that the north side of Dublin has fared less favourably than other areas in terms of the provision of Garda facilities.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: whether the Public Safety Act, 1928, still operates; whether the Act or any sections thereof have been subsequently amended; and if so, the changes, if any, that have been made in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The provisions of the Public Safety Act, 1928 are spent.

Qst.Quest: whether she has responded to a detailed submission made to her by a deputation of the community alert group from Ballymore, County Westmeath; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Following a meeting on 3 April 1996, with representatives from the Ballymore Community Alert Group regarding the policing arrangements for the area, I requested that the issues raised by the group be brought to the attention of the Garda Commissioner for his consideration as he is responsible for the detailed allocation of Garda personnel and resources to individual areas. I have only recently received his report in the matter and I hope to be in a position to issue a response to the Ballymore community alert group shortly.

Qst.Quest: whether it is an offence for motorists to speak on hand-held mobile telephones whilst driving; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that there is no specific provision under the Road Traffic Acts prohibiting the use of hand-held mobile telephones by drivers of moving vehicles. However, if driving is accompanied by some action or inaction on the part of the driver which itself suggests a contravention of the Road Traffic Acts, a prosecution may be appropriate.

Qst.Quest: if she will have arrangements made to have deeds of land submitted to her Department in relation to a transfer dealing urgently returned to a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny or the solicitor acting on his behalf.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that there is a fourth dealing associated with the three dealings referred to by the Deputy. In the case of the three dealings, which were lodged in the Land Registry on dates in 1990 and 1992, it appears that the applicant has been unable to satisfy the Land Registry of entitlement to absolute title to the land in question. The applicant's solicitors have been advised of this and of the possibility of registering possessory title only. There has been no reply to this suggestion from the applicant's solicitors.

Queries regarding the associated dealing were issued to the lodging solicitors on 12 August 1994 to which it appears no replies have been received. The delays, therefore, appear to have resulted from the failure of the applicants' solicitors to reply to the suggestion mentioned and to the queries raised by the Land Registry.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Judicial Separation Applications.

Qst.Quest: the number of applications made and decrees granted under the Judicial Separation and Family Law Reform Act, 1989 in each Circuit Court area for the periods 1 October 1989 to 31 July 1996; and the total number of such Circuit Court applications made and decrees granted from the commencement of the Act to 31 July 1996.

the grounds on which decrees under the Judicial Separation and Family Law Reform Act, 1989 were granted in the Circuit Court in each county in the period October 1989 to 31 July 1990 and in each full legal year thereafter up to the legal year 1 August 1995 to 31 July 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 635 and 636 together.

I have previously indicated my dissatisfaction with the systems in place within the criminal justice system for compiling statistics in such a way that everybody using the statistics is clear as to the precise meaning. For example, I have found that in the past court statistics were maintained primarily for the purpose of measuring activity levels and thereby measuring resource requirements for the courts.

Taking the case of statistics relating to applications for judicial separation as an example, previous Ministers for Justice and myself have given figures in respect of the number of applications for judicial separation to the Circuit Court since the enactment of the Judicial Separation and Family Law Reform Act, 1989, to 31 July 1995, which, if totalled would come to over 11,000. Such statistics, which have been given many times, were a measure of the actual volume of business which was before the courts over the years, but in some cases involved an element of double counting, if a case went from one term to another.

When I became aware of the lack of clarity and difficulties of interpretation which existed in the past in relation to judicial separation statistics, I instituted a complete review of such statistics to ensure that everyone who had occasion to use the statistics would know exactly what was represented by the figures produced to avoid any double counting.
The actual number of individual applications for judicial separation which were made to the Circuit Court frem the commencement of the 1989 Act of 31 July 1995 was 6,712.

MainHeading.P: A breakdown of the number of applications made and decrees of judicial separation granted under the 1989 Act by each Circuit Court area is as follows. The review of judicial separation statistics did not focus on recording the grounds under which decrees of judicial separation were granted. Such information is not readily available and could only be compiled by the allocation of very scarce resources from other more important tasks.

The information sought by the Deputy in relation to the number of applications for judicial separation and the number of decrees granted for the 1995-96 year will be compiled after the completion of the current legal year which ends on 31 July next and I will arrange for it to be forwarded to the Deputy as soon as possible.
Statistics Relating to Applications for Judicial Separation which were made under The Judicial Separation and Family Law Reform Act, 1989.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Bridge Project.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if the Bridge group for the placing of ex-prisoners is operated or supported by her Department; if so, if she will give details in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Bridge Project is an intensive probation supervision initiative established by my Department's probation and welfare service in 1991. The project is run as an alternative to custody and referrals are made up from the following groups:
—offenders who have committed serious crimes and, at the court stage, are placed on the programme as an alternative to custody;
—prisoners, who are serving sentences for serious crimes, and who are given temporary release on the condition that they attend the programme.

The participants are placed on a demanding community based programme while under the strict supervision of the probation and welfare service. The project provides a programme which addresses the lifestyles of offenders, aimed at diverting them from crime and finding them employment or other meaningful occupations. Recently, I was pleased to launch, on behalf of the project, a major new initiative to explain to employers the reasons why exoffenders should be considered for jobs, and the benefits that can be derived by employing them. The programme also facilitates the development of constructive personal and social skills aimed at reducing recidivism.

The bridge project has a management committee comprised of representatives of criminal justice agencies, business people, the Irish Youth Federation, City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee. FÁS, ICTU, and research interests.

MainHeading.P: My Department provided grants amounting to £110,000 to the project for running costs in 1995, in addition to over £4,000 for capital equipment. My Department is also in the process of having new premises in Parnell Street, Dublin, renovated for use by the project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
