MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Crime Package Costs.

Qst.Quest: the total cost of the crime package announced on 2 July 1996; the aspects of the package that will be introduced in each of the years 1996 and 1997; the additional moneys that have been allocated to her Department in respect of these measures in each of the years 1996 and 1997; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the time schedule for each of the measures to tackle crime as announced on 2 July 1996 to be put in place and to be operative; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the total cost of the measures announced by her on 2 July 1996, to tackle the crime problem; and the anticipated costs over the next two years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 646, 652 and 654 together.
The estimated cost of the measures decided upon by the Government on 2 July 1996 is £2.28 million in 1996 and in the region of £35 million in 1997 in relation to the Justice Group of Votes.
The precise costs in relation to 1997 will be published in due course in the context of the Government's consideration of the allocations for 1997 in the Estimates for the Public Service.

MainHeading.P: There are a number of measures before the House today which are directed towards implementing some of these decisions and I will, in due course, be announcing further details of developments in regard to the measures, and the financing of them.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Offences Committed on Bail.

Qst.Quest: the number of persons charged with an offence while out on bail for another offence from 1 January 1995 to 31 December 1995; the number of detention places which may be required if there is a change in our bail laws; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Statistics on the number of offences committed by persons on bail are published in the Commissioner's Annual Report on Crime, copies of which are available in the Oireachtas Library. The 1995 report will be published shortly.

As regards the number of detention places which may be required if there is a change in the bail laws, the Government has approved my proposal to build a new remand prison capable of holding 400 prisoners on the enclosed site already available at Wheatfield.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Air Support.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, that has been made in respect of the provision of enhanced air support to the Garda Síochána; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: In April this year, the Government approved my proposal for the establishment of dedicated air support for the Garda Síochána. This will involve the purchase of specialised aircraft which will provide the Garda Síochána with a 24-hour air support capability. The Air Corps already provide a significant level of air support to the Garda Síochána and the current proposals are directed towards enhancing that support.

MainHeading.P: I announced on 19 July that tenders have been invited for the supply of these aircraft.

Qst.Quest: whether the Garda retirement age is to be extended by five years; if so, the total numbers in each rank that could remain in the Garda force; the mechanism required for such an extension to be granted; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: There are no proposals to extend the Garda retirement age by five years. In regard to the general question of the extension of the retirement age, the position has remained unchanged since my reply to the Deputy's Parliamentary Questions 9850/96 and 9851/96 on 15 May 1996.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Additional Detention Places.

Qst.Quest: the additional number of detention places that will be required to meet the demands that will be placed on required detention places in order to implement the measures contained in the crime package as announced on 2 July 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Government has, in the current year, approved my proposals for the provision of a total of approximately 880 additional prison places. The additional places include 60 places for female prisoners, at least 400 places for male remand prisoners and 420 places for male convicted prisoners. These additional places represent an increase of 40 per cent on the existing level of available prison accommodation.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that the above programme to provide additional prison places represents a very significant and appropriate response to the existing problems in regard to overcrowding, early and temporary prisoner release programmes and to any demands that are likely to arise from reform of the existing bail laws.

Qst.Quest: the total cost of the provision of recreational facilities available to prisoners in 1995; the estimated cost in 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Total expenditure on recreation equipment and materials amounted to £0.275 million in 1995. This figure covers a wide range of items from televisions to physical education equipment. It does not include any element in respect of staffing costs, as it would not be feasible to differentiate those costs from the overall staffing costs of the institutions. The provision in the 1996 Estimate is £0.277 million.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Resources.

Qst.Quest: her views on whether the Gardaí have been given the necessary resources in order to offer the general public full and adequate protection at all times and in every situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: As I outlined in my response to the Deputy's previous question in this matter, I am satisfied that the Garda Síochána have the necessary personnel and resources to enable them to meet the demands placed on them. However, as I also stated in my previous response to the Deputy, this is something which must be kept under continuous review and changes made as deemed necessary.

MainHeading.P: The actual deployment of these resources is a matter for the Garda Commissioner and, of course, I am guided by his operational knowledge and expertise in such matters. Many factors influence the recruitment and allocation of the Garda Síochána such as demographic change and crime tends. These trends are continually monitored and measures adopted where necessary to counter any difficulties which may arise.

The anti-crime measures which i announced recently, having obtained Government approval, are a continuation of the ongoing commitment to the fight against crime. These proposals are in addition to the other major initiatives which I have already introduced since taking up appointment as Minister for Justice and are testament to my determination and that of the Government to tackle crime in a swift and effective manner.

Qst.Quest: if she will report on the work being carried out in the Office of the Attorney General in respect of the preparation of legislation for the possible verification of arms decommissioning by paramilitary groups at some future date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Work on the preparation of legislative proposals on decommissioning of arms, including the question of an arms amnesty, consistent with the terms of the recommendations contained in the International Body's report is under way in my Department in consultation with the Attorney General's Office. That work is now at an advanced stage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Media Briefings on Garda Murder.

Qst.Quest: the briefings, if any, given by the Government Press Secretary to the media in the wake of the murder of Garda McCabe and the attempted murder of Garda O'Sullivan in Adare on Friday, 7 June 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I understand that the Government Press Secretary did not give any media briefings in this matter and that press queries were redirected to the Garda Press Office. When the then Garda Commissioner, Mr. Patrick Culligan announced on 13 June 1996 that a unit of the IRA was responsible for the murder of Garda McCabe and the wounding of Garda O'Sullivan, the Press Secretary confirmed that the Government considered the Commissioner's announcement as authoritative and definitive.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Garda Station.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: if she will sanction a project (details supplied) in County Galway; if she will give details of the project; the date on which sanction will be given; the cost of the project; the date on which construction will begin; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware a major refurbishment scheme to incorporate the married quarters into the Garda station is proposed for this centre. However, in view of the nature of the works to be carried out it has been decided to progress the project on a phased basis. Phase I will involve the completion of all works to the married quarters. Upon completion of same, the station party will be moved into the married quarters and works to the station itself will comence under Phase II.

The Office of Public Works has been asked to prepare a revised sketch scheme for the proposed works along with costings for Phase I and II. Subject to the availability of finance and overall priorities, it is expected that works will commence during 1997.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: if she will sanction a project (details supplied) in County Galway; if she will give details of the project; the date on which sanction will be given; the cost of the project; the date on which construction will begin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware major refurbishment works including the incorporation of the married quarters and the building of an extension are proposed for this centre. The Office of Public Works is currently preparing a revised sketch scheme for the proposed project. Subject to the availability of finance and overall priorities, it is expected that works will commence during 1997. Costs cannot be finally established until the tender stage.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: if she will sanction a project (details supplied) in County Galway; if she will give details of the project; the date on which sanction will be given; the cost of the project; the date on which construction will begin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Consultant architects have been appointed to prepare a preliminary plan and cost estimate for the refurbishment of Portumna Courthouse. At this stage it is not possible to provide a time scale for this project.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Student Garda Numbers.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the number of student gardaí admitted to Templemore Training Centre in each of the years 1995 and 1996; the number to be admitted in 1997; the number currently awaiting a call to training; the number currently in training in Templemore College; if she proposes to have a new Garda entrance competition in 1996 and/or 1997; if so, the dates of these competitions; the number to be admitted to the Garda force in the year immediately ahead; if she has satisfied herself with the current strength of the Garda force; the current strength of the Garda force, including the number of gardaí of all ranks in each division in the country; the number attached to Garda Headquarters; the number serving overseas; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The number of student gardaí admitted to the Garda College in 1995 was 350, and, to date, in 1996 was 174. Two more intakes of 163 trainees are scheduled each for next week and October 1996. The number scheduled to be admitted for training in 1997 is 600. There are 144 candidates from the current competition remaining to be medically examined. These medical examinations are currently in progress and it is not possible at this point to state how many will be declared medically fit for entry into the college. There are 176 trainees in Phase I and Phase III training at the Garda College, with a further 179 on Phase II at selected Garda stations, giving a total of 355 in training.

The current strength of the Garda Síochána, including all ranks and 61 members serving overseas on United Nations duty, is 10,768. It is not possible, in the time available, to give the detailed information sought by the Deputy in relation to the distribution of numbers between divisions, headquarters, etc. This information will be communicated to the Deputy as soon as it is available.

I expect to submit my proposals for Garda recruitment for the three to four years period commencing 1998 to Government later this year. The current recruitment competition, which covers the period 1995 to 1997 inclusive, provided for the recruitment of 1,050 new gardaí. This figure is being augmented by a further 400 following the recently announced crime package. The recruitment of 200 civilians under that package will also be a significant boost to the operational strength of the force through the release to operational duties of a comparable number of gardaí.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that all these measures will provide the Garda Síochána with the necessary manpower resources to meet the challenges it now faces.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Psychotic Prisoners.

Qst.Quest: if she will give details of the specific response her Department has made to the problem of unattended and unassessed psychotically ill prisoners in Mountjoy Prison as referred to in the 1993 and 1994 Visiting Committee Reports; the extent of the waiting list for admission and evaluation of undiagnosed psychotically ill prisoners from Mountjoy Prison to the Central Mental Hospital; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will give details of the specific response her Department has made to the reports of the Visiting Committee of Mountjoy Prison that psychotically ill prisoners are being put into padded cells in the prison for many days at a time; her views on the slowness and adequacy of prisoner assessment in the prison; the steps, if any, which have been taken to improve the situation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 662 and 663 together.

MainHeading.P: I do not accept that there is, or was, a problem of “unattended and unassessed psychotically ill prisoners in Mountjoy Prison” in 1993 or 1994 or the period since then. There is, I freely acknowledge, a long-standing problem in relation to a waiting list for admission to the Central Mental Hospital (CMH) for prisoners who are mentally disordered and are deemed, on medical examination, to require in-patient treatment in that setting. The waiting list in question fluctuates considerably in size from time to time. The Central Mental Hospital operates under the aegis of the Department of Health and the Eastern Health Board. Responsibility for its staffing and admissions policy ultimately rests with those bodies. At the request of my Department, a working group was established by my colleague, the then Minister for Health in 1994 to examine, inter alia, the accommodation provision in the Central Mental Hospital in respect of mentally disordered prisoners. This group included senior officials from my Department, including the Director of Prison Medical Services. The group reported to the Minister for Health in mid-1995 and its recommendations, which included steps to increase the number of beds available for prisoners, were accepted by the Minister for Health. The main step to increase bed availability was the transfer to local psychiatric hospitals of older patients at the hospital who were deemed to no longer require treatment in conditions of high security. Implementation of this policy recommendation is ongoing and I understand that several patients have in fact been transferred under this policy to local psychiatric hospitals in their home areas.

Recent court decisions have led to an increase of inward referrals to the Central Mental Hospital from the health boards and this has, to an extent, offset the potential gains from the outward placement of older Central Mental Hospital patients to which I have already referred.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mountjoy Prison Medical Service.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, she has to remedy the lack of accountability for the medical service in Mountjoy Prison; if she will respond to the statement in the Mountjoy Visiting Committee report that the current systems operating, particularly in the male prison, can have serious and fatal repercussions within the prison; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The ethical accountability of all doctors registered in the State is to the Medical Council, which is essentially constituted to function as a watchdog of medical standards on behalf of the public. No doctor is ethically accountable to another doctor.

In relation to medical management accountability, the appointment of a director of prison medical services in 1990, which was a newly created position at that time, did not focus on clearly defining the accountability of existing prison doctors to this new medical manager. While this omission is understandable, given the difficulties that occurred in recruiting a suitably qualified doctor to the position, it is clearly time to revisit the relationship between the medical director and the medical practitioners in the prisons.

As a first step, I have asked the director of prison medical services to review his role and make a submission to me on the matter. Among the aims of the proposed common contract for prison doctors, which has been under negotiation with the IMO for some time, is to more clearly define the line management responsibilities of prison doctors to both prison governors and to the director of prison medical services.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prison Service Overtime Bill.

Qst.Quest: the specific steps, if any, her Department will take to reduce the overtime bill in the prison service in view of the fact that the overtime budget in prisons is consistently breached; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The overtime allocation for the prison service has been constantly exceeded over the years. The factors involved are complex. Prisons by their nature are labour intensive and agreed staffing levels must be maintained in the interest of the good order of the institutions, irrespective of demands arising outside the prisons for escorts to courts, hospitals and other prisons. These demands, which must be met, account for more than one quarter of overtime expenditure.

The level of overtime also reflects the increasing pressure on the prison system which has had to cope with a 50 per cent increase in the number of committals since 1991. A further factor which links into overtime is sick leave as staff who do not attend for duty, by and large, must be replaced on overtime in order to maintain required staffing levels.

Whatever the justifiable reasons for overtime, high levels of overtime are not in the long-term interests of either prison staff and their families or of the prison service. With a view to addressing this and other matters which affect prison costs, a review of the operating costs of the prison service is being carried out. This review group includes representatives of prison governors, prison staff, my Department, as well as people from the public and private sectors and the Department of Finance. I hope to receive its report within a matter of months.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recapture of Prisoners.

Qst.Quest: the number of prisoners who absconded from places of detention in each of the past three years who were recaptured and returned to prison; the number of prisoners who are still unlawfully at large, having breached temporary release bonds or absconded from detention; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Information is not maintained, at present, in such a way as to provide the information on recaptures requested by the Deputy.

MainHeading.P: However, the total cumulative number of persons unlawfully at large on 23 July 1996 was 1,316. It should be noted that the term “unlawfully at large” may refer to a person who has absconded from custody or breached the conditions of their temporary release by, for example, failing to sign on on a regular basis. This latter category would, therefore, already be released before they would become a statistic for the purposes of being “unlawfully at large”.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Assaults by Prisoners at Large.

Qst.Quest: the amount of claims which have been settled by the State in respect of injuries sustained by persons arising from crimes committed by those on temporary release or those unlawfully at large; the amount of such claims which are pending; the estimated actual cost to the State in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: My Department's records show that three claims have been settled in respect of personal injuries sustained by persons arising from assaults on them by offenders while on temporary release or unlawfully at large. Four similar claims are currently pending against the State. I am advised that it would be neither desirable nor appropriate to disclose the estimated costs of settling pending claims.

The total cost of actual settlement payments in the three cases where claims were settled by the State was £73,000. Plaintiffs' legal costs in all three cases, which were borne by the State, amounted to £30,000 approximately. Excluding the State's costs, the total sum expended in modern times on settling such cases was, therefore, £103,000.

Qst.Quest: the reason there is no committal assessment procedure in place in Mountjoy Prison in view of the fact that this was a key recommendation of the 1991 Report on Prison Deaths; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Medical examination is a key element in committal assessment and such examination should take place as soon as possible after committal. GPs attend the prison on a daily basis, usually in the mornings, when they examine all new committals. The issue of evening attendance at the prison is under review by the director of prison medical services in consultation with the GPs who attend at the prison and in the context of negotiations on a common contract for prison doctors with the Irish Medical Organisation which represents the prison doctors.

The recommendation cited by the Deputy included the provision of a special building devoted solely to dealing with offenders in the initial days of their imprisonment. The Government has decided to provide such a building in the proposed new remand-dispersal centre at Wheatfield.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Computerisation in Mountjoy Prison.

Qst.Quest: the computerisation available in Mountjoy Prison to log committals and releases; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: At present, two committal institutions, Mountjoy Prison and St. Patrick's Institution, are linked to a computerised prisoner record system located in the Department of Justice.

While the system is vital in the day to day running of the prisons service, due to its age and the amount and structure of data now on the system, it cannot readily provide statistical reports of a detailed nature. This problem has led, for example, to delays in the publication of the annual report on prisons and places of detention and generally hampered the collation of up-to-date figuretrends.

MainHeading.P: The provision of a new computerised prisoner records system, which will extend to all institutions, is being pursued as energetically as resources will allow. It is planned that any new system will be able to provide a more efficient system of tracking offenders and a more comprehensive statistical service.

Qst.Quest: the status of the negotiations between her Department and the Eastern Health Board concerning the adequacy of the prison psychiatric services, negotiations which have been ongoing since 1992; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Discussions on restructuring the psychiatric services to prisons in the Dublin area have been ongoing with the Eastern Health Board since 1993. While significant progress has been made in these discussions, a number of points remain to be resolved. I hope however, that these matters will be resolved soon. Recently the Eastern Health Board appointed two psychiatrists who will attend at prisons in the Dublin area and particularly at Mountjoy Prison.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drug Treatment Services.

Qst.Quest: the time scale envisaged to open and improve drug-free accommodation for male and female inmates; whether the detoxification unit will proceed in spite of union objections regarding the hiring of agency nurses; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will ensure that there is adequate co-operation between the Eastern Health Board drug abuse services and the prison authorities to enable continuity of care and drug treatment when addicts on methadone maintenance are committed to jail; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 671 and 679 together.

A drug-free area with accommodation for up to 90 prisoners has been operating successfully at the training Unit, Glengarriff Parade, Dublin 7 since March 1996. Regarding the possible expansion and improvement of drug-free accommodation for prisoners, I am currently examining several options in respect of other institutions. I hope to be in a position to announce significant developments in this regard in the autumn. The treatment facility for drug addicted prisoners, which includes a detoxification facility, is now in operation at Mountjoy Prison's health care unit. While the staffing arrangements for the unit have been the subject of some discussions with staff representatives, this matter has now been satisfactorily resolved.

Methadone maintenance is one of the treatment options which will be available in the treatment unit. Committals who had been complying with a recognised course of maintenance immediately prior to imprisonment will, subject to certain criteria, be facilitated with a continuation of their course.

These developments at present cater for male prisoners only. Having regard in particular to the self-contained nature of the health care unit, I am not totally excluding the possibility of providing treatment for female prisoners at this location. This will, however, depend on the development of the services there and other operational factors. The plans for the new female prison reflect fully the medical needs of inmates including provision for the treatment of drug addicts.

MainHeading.P: I readily acknowledge that close co-operation between Eastern Health Board drug treatment agencies and the prison authorities will be essential to the successful delivery of treatment measures for addicts, both in the prisons and in the community. Regarding the practical arrangements, the staffing of the unit includes medical and psychiatric personnel who are already active in this field with the Eastern Health Board. I am satisfied, therefore, that co-operation will be more than adequate.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Guidelines on Padded Cells.

Qst.Quest: her Department's response to the recommendations of the 1995 Visiting Committee for full implementation of the guidelines on padded cells in the Five Year Management of Offender's Report; if she will respond to the committee's expressed concern at the ambivalence in relation to the conditions for restraint in padded cells; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Governor of Mountjoy prison has already pointed out publicly the urgent practical necessity of putting prisoners in a place of safety where they are not a danger to themselves or others when they start being difficult in prison. I do not accept there is any ambivalence in this matter. The guidelines in place for the use of padded cells require all such placements to be reported to the Department of Justice. They also require the early involvement of a prison doctor where a stay in a padded cell goes on any longer than overnight. It is simply not practical to call out the doctor every single time the padded cell has to be used, day or night. On many occasions it has to be used at the prisoner's request.

MainHeading.P: The references to the use of padded cells in the Department's Five Year Plan for the Management of Offenders, June 1994, arises in the context of discussion of new prison rules. On page 119 of the plan document it is indicated that padded or strip cells shall not be used for the confinement of prisoners except where necessary to prevent them injuring themselves or others. The text goes on to require that the reasons for use of the padded cell shall, in each instance, be recorded and conveyed to the Department. This reflects currently observed policy in the prisons.

Qst.Quest: the person/organisation who negotiated the confidentiality clauses relating to the amount of settlements agreed and paid in relation to claims settled by the State in respect of injuries and damage caused by persons on temporary release; the reason therefor; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be aware it is common legal practice for civil claim settlements to contain a confidentiality clause. I am not aware of any precedent for providing the information sought by the Deputy in this respect.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Security Measures.

Qst.Quest: the implications, if any, for security of the bombing in Enniskillen caused by a jeep stolen in the Republic and the bomb hoax in Dublin on 18 July 1996; if she has received a full Garda report on both incidents; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The implications of the incidents in question are that security measures must continue to be taken throughout this island to counter the use or threat of use of paramilitary violence. I received a detailed briefing on these incidents, and the security situation generally, from the Garda authorities. They assured me that all worth-while security measures are in place to deal with incidents of this nature.

MainHeading.P: At the same time, the incidents referred to in the question, and other recent incidents of paramilitary violence in this and other jurisdictions, have highlighted once again the horror of violence pursued for political ends and the need for the Governments and all parties to work earnestly and urgently for the achievement of a lasting political solution.

Qst.Quest: the status of the investigation into the collapse of the prosecution case in a recent murder trial; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I assume the Deputy is referring to the trial of Frederick Flannery. The investigation ordered by the Garda Commissioner into this matter is continuing.

Qst.Quest: the status of the investigation into the murder of Detective Garda Jerry McCabe and the attempted murder of Detective Garda Ben O'Sullivan; the number of persons who have been and are currently in custody in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: It is not the practice for Ministers for Justice to go into details of individual investigations. However, I am informed by the Garda authorities that the Garda investigation in this case continues to be actively pursued. They also inform me that of the total of 35 persons detained for questioning in the course of the investigation, one is currently in Garda custody and three others are remanded on charges brought before the Special Criminal Court arising from the investigation.

Qst.Quest: whether she has met with the groups involved in the ongoing dispute in the Garda Representative Association since the publication of legislation in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Following its publication, a copy of the Bill was sent to the groups involved in the dispute, that is, the Garda Representative Association, the Garda Federation and the representatives of the four Garda divisions who, while still members of the GRA, are not full participants in the affairs of that organisation.

I met separately with all three groups on 21 May 1996 to discuss the terms of the Bill. I subsequently received written submissions from the Garda Federation and from the representatives of the four Garda divisions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Obscene and Illegal Activities Involving Minors.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to prostitution or other obscene and illegal activities involving minors in the State; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to my reply on 15 May 1996 to Parliamentary Question No. 158.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Deferred Release of Prisoner.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the reason the release of a person (details supplied) is not now going ahead in view of a previous letter from her dated 21 July 1995 in this regard which stated that he would be released in 12 months from that date; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The prisoner in question is serving a life sentence for the murder in 1984 of a member of the Garda Síochána. His sentence is indeterminate and, subject to the approval of the Minister, he may be released under licence at any time. It would not be appropriate for me to comment on the decision to defer his planned release date of July 1996. The giving of such information in relation to an individual offender would be unprecedented.

Qst.Quest: the sitting times and days and the date of terms in respect of the Circuit Court, the District Court, the High Court and the Supreme Court.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to my reply to Parliamentary Question No. 253 of 2 July 1996 at column 2196 of the Official Report.

Qst.Quest: the amount of grant aid which has been given at national level to the Community Alert Organisation; the way in which this grant was allocated to local community alert groups throughout the country; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am making £50,000 available this year to Muintir na Tíre to provide it with the resources to significantly expand the number of community alert schemes in operation. The grant will be used to employ a number of development officers on a regional basis to promote and develop the scheme.

Qst.Quest: the most recent year for which she has received the annual report on prisons and places of detention and the annual report of the criminal injuries compensation tribunal; when she intends to publish the reports; the proposals if any, she has to speed up preparation and publication of such reports; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The annual reports on prisons and places of detention are compiled and published by my Department. The prisons report for 1993 is currently being printed and will be available shortly. The compilation of the statistics in respect of 1994 and 1995 is in progress. However, as I already indicated to the House, I recently decided that the written elements of the reports for those years, which include the main developments in the prisons service, the reports of the Visiting Committees and the various prison services, will be published separately. I plan to have these interim reports ready for publication later this year. The statistical tables would then be published as soon as possible afterwards.

The lack of comprehensive information technology in the prisons has inhibited the preparation of the statistical elements of the prison reports. The work of updating prison information technology, which will include the ability to provide the required statistical reporting, is currently under review.

Annual reports of the criminal injuries compensation tribunal for the years 1993 and 1994 have been presented to me and those for the years 1990 to 1992 to my predecessor. Arrangements are in hand for the presentation of these reports to the Houses of the Oireachtas and their publication at an early date. Steps are being taken to ensure that the preparation of the tribunal's annual report and its presentation to the Minister and Oireachtas does not fall into arrears in future years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. Byrne Mr. E. Byrne
Qst.Quest: whether the system of petitioning a Minister for Justice, which was used in the past to have fines reduced or alleviated or prison sentences reduced, the legality of which was tested in the High Court resulting in the courts finding against the Minister for Justice, is no longer used, encouraged or available to public representatives; and whether such a petitioning policy currently exists in view of the fact that there is apparently a view in the Garda Síochána and the general public, particularly those fined by the courts, that this system is still available.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The High Court judgement to which the Deputy refers does not affect a person's entitlement to petition. However, it requires the adoption of new procedures for dealing with petitions, and, as I indicated on a number of previous occasions, I will make an announcement on the matter as soon as a settled procedure is in place. In the meantime, petitions continue to be accepted and my decisions on petitions take into consideration the 1995 High Court judgment on petitions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sales of British Lottery Tickets.

Qst.Quest: the action, if any, she intends to take to deal with the illegal sales of British lottery tickets in Ireland; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that they are currently investigating a number of alleged breaches of the Gaming and Lotteries Act, 1956, which concern the sale of British national lottery tickets.

MainHeading.P: On completion of the Garda investigation, it is anticipated that a file will be forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions for directions.

Qst.Quest: if she will give details of any financial settlements or extraordinary severance arrangements entered into with civil servants in her Department or with public servants in State agencies under the aegis of her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: There have been no financial settlements or extraordinary severance arrangements entered into with civil or public servants in my Department. There are no State agencies under the aegis of my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Relocation of Stamping Office.

Qst.hpid: Mr. B. O'Keeffe Mr. B. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if she intends to relocate the stamping office from Anglesea Street to the courthouse in Washington Street, Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The location of the court stamping office in Cork city is under review at present. However, I wish to advise the Deputy that in addition to the fee franking machine located in the District Court office in Anglesea Street, there are 17 solicitors in Cork city licensed by me to operate court fee franking machines, 13 of which are located in the South Mall/Washington Street area of the city.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Provision of Medical Service to Prison.

Qst.Quest: the current status of the negotiations between her Department and the Irish Medical Organisation in relation to a common contract to provide medical services to a prison which have been ongoing since 1992; the progress, if any, that has been made in this matter since the Parliamentary Question raised by Deputy O'Donnell of 19 June 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Since I set out the position in relation to this matter in my response to parliamentary questions to Deputy Quill on 19 June 1996, and to Deputy O'Donnell on 2 July 1996, I have had discussions with the law officers on certain aspects of the proposed contract and as soon as their formal advice is available to me it will be considered by my Department and the Department of Finance and further discussions will be take place with the IMO. I hope these discussions may bring this issue to a conclusion.

Qst.Quest: if a file which relates to the deportation of a person (details supplied) who was deported from Ireland by the Government in 1933, will be made available for public inspection; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Despite an intensive search on foot of a previous request for information on the person in question, my Department has been unable to locate a file bearing his name or with the reference number referred to in the question. It is possible that such a file is held in storage by the National Archives but my Department has been advised that all attempts by that office to locate it have also so far approved fruitless.

In the circumstances the Deputy will appreciate that it is not a question of my deciding whether the file should be made available for public inspection. On the assumption the file still exists and in the event of it being located, I will give every reasonable consideration to the Deputy's request to make it available for public inspection.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Qst.Quest: the reason a decision pertaining to the location of a garda (details supplied) has been taken; if she will reverse this decision; if her attention has been drawn to the serious community concern pertaining to this decision; if she will ensure that the current position is maintained at this location; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Garda authorities are responsible for the detailed deployment of Garda personnel and resources to individual areas. They informed me that the area referred to by the Deputy forms part of the community policing initiative in operation in the district, and as part of this there is one garda allocated to the station in question. The whole area is also covered by mobile patrols. It is understood that this garda will soon be transferred to another location and the consequential vacancy will be advertised, complete with official accommodation, in the normal way.

The Garda authorities have informed me that the strength of this station in 1962 was one sergeant and two gardaí and has never exceeded this level. At present, in addition to the garda serving at the station, one of the three sergeants based at the administrative headquarters has responsibility for policing in the area. The Garda authorities are satisfied that these policing arrangements are satisfactory but they will keep them under constant review.

Qst.Quest: the number of murder investigations which are currently under way by the Garda; the number of murder cases in 1996 wherein a suspect has been charged; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that there are currently 26 cases of suspected murder, which occurred during 1996, under investigation. Suspects have been charged with offences in connection with 16 of these cases. A file has been forwarded to the DPP in respect of one further case and files are being prepared for submission in relation to two other cases.

Qst.Quest: the number of indictable offences in respect of murder, manslaughter, assault, robbery, rape, sexual assault, burglaries, larcenies and interference with cars in respect of each of the years from 1991 to 1994 in the districts of Abbeyleix, Arlex, Ballacolla, Ballinakill, Ballylinan, Borris-in-Ossary, Clonaslee, Durrow, Mountmellick, Mountrath, Portarlington, Portlaoise, Rathdowney, Stradbally, Banagher, Birr, Clara, Cloghan, Clonbullogue, Daingean, Edenderry, Ferbane, Geashill, Kilcorman, Kinnitty, Moneygall, Rhode, Shannonbridge, Shinrone and Tullamore; and the manning levels in each of these stations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that the information requested is not available in the format sought by the Deputy and could not be compiled without a disproportionate expenditure of Garda time and resources. Such information as can be readily compiled will be supplied to the Deputy as soon as possible. Crime statistics under a number of headings are available in the annual reports of An Garda Síochána which are laid in the Oireachtas Library each year.

Qst.Quest: further to her reply to a parliamentary question raised by Deputy Callely on 15 May 1996, regarding the new women's prison on the Cowley Place site beside Mountjoy Prison, wherein she indicated that planning and related matters are being processed, the stage of process of these matters; and the likely date for completion of this project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: On 2 July this year I obtained Government approval for the necessary capital funding to enable the construction works for the new women's prison at Cowley Place, near Mountjoy, which will provide 60 extra prison places, to begin in January 1997. The project is due for completion in 1998.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Pension Rights of Former Workers.

Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the pension rights for former workers of Irish Tanneries at their former plants at Carrick-on-Suir, Dungarvan and Portlaw, County Waterford; the conditions attached to such pension rights; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: I assume the Deputy is referring to Irish Leathers Ltd., and the two pension schemes which commenced on September 1975 and April 1977. Following the liquidation of Irish Leathers in July 1985, the schemes were concurrently paid up.

As far as I am aware, court proceedings were taken but a settlement was reached without the matter going into court. I understand negotiations are taking place at present between representatives of the parties involved and it is hoped a settlement will be arrived at soon.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Student's Summer Jobs Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in County Mayo did not qualify for the student's summer job scheme in view of the fact that she is attending third level education and she will be returning to college in September 1996.
when a person (details supplied) in County Mayo will be accepted for the student summer job scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 697 and 720 together.

The underlying purpose of the scheme is to provide income support for less well off third level students who are disqualified from receiving unemployment assistance and are unable to obtain summer work. Priority, therefore, is being given to enable the maximum number of eligible low income students to participate within the overall financial allocation of £10.2 million for the 1996 scheme.

The persons concerned are not affected by the 1993 disqualification of students claiming unemployment assistance and consequently are not eligible for participation in the student summer jobs scheme. If they are unable to find alternative work they may, subject to a means test, qualify for unemployment assistance.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Extra Cost of Unemployment.

Qst.Quest: the extra cost to the Exchequer of the higher levels of unemployment in the first six months of 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The social welfare Estimates of expenditure on unemployment for 1996 are based on an average live register forecast of 275,000. The amount provided for unemployment payments in 1996 is £1,013.5 million, including payments to smallholders.

MainHeading.P: Due to an industrial dispute, now resolved, in An Post, returns of actual expenditure on the unemployment schemes are available only to the end of April 1996 at this stage. On the basis of these returns, it is estimated that the extra cost to the Exchequer of the higher levels of unemployment for the first four months of 1996 is of the order of £3.35 million.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to extend double child benefit to all multiple births, particularly double child benefit for twins; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: the number of sets of twins that were paid a special grant of £100 per child on birth in 1995.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 699 and 700 together.

Child benefit is payable in respect of all children, including twins, up to 16 years of age and up to 19 years in respect of children who are in full-time education or are physically or mentally handicapped. Child benefit is payable at double the normal rate for each child where three or more children are born together.

In recognition of the significant additional costs involved for parents of twins, I made provision in the 1996 budget for increasing the grant in respect of the birth of twins to £500 and for the introduction of a new grant of £500 which is payable on the twins reaching the ages of four and 12. These new grants are intended to assist with the particular financial pressures arising at birth and as the twins enter primary and secondary school.

MainHeading.P: These improvements in relation to twins were brought into effect from 1 January 1996, and are in addition to the increases being provided in the monthly rates of child benefit. From September next, the monthly payment will be £29 in respect of each of the first two children and £34 for the third and subsequent children. When taken together with the increases provided for in the 1995 budget, these rates represent an increase over the last two years of 45 per cent in the rate payable for the first two children and 36 per cent in the higher rate payable in respect of other children. Further improvements in child benefit will be considered in the light of available resources and within a budgetary context.
Birth grants were made in respect of a total of 609 sets of twins in 1995.

Qst.Quest: the number of sponsors for the student summer job scheme; the projected number of students participating in the scheme; the proposals, if any, he has to allow students who have been refused participation in the scheme to now take part; and the total number of students approved for this scheme to date.
the basis of the number of students approved under the student summer job scheme; the estimated total cost of the scheme in 1996; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.Quest: the number of students at third-level studying for a diploma or degree course in the 1996-7 college year who applied for inclusion in the student summer job scheme but who have been refused.

Qst.Quest: if a parent's contribution to a pension scheme through purchasing notional years service will be allowed as a deduction from total parental income with regard to the student summer job scheme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the number of regional technical college students who applied for the student summer job scheme, who were refused participation and who are now claiming unemployment assistance; if he has satisfied himself with the effects on voluntary agencies of this revised scheme which precludes students who have completed certificate and diploma courses but who have enrolled for degree courses; his views on whether the new rules effectively discriminate against regional technical college students who are between courses and who would have qualified under the previous scheme, in view of the fact that other students who opt out of degree courses are considered eligible; his views on the loss of self-esteem of students who would have been eligible under the previous scheme but who now may claim unemployment assistance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the actual or approximate number of additional people claiming unemployment assistance as a result of the changes introduced in the student summer job scheme; his views on whether the increase in unemployment numbers can be attributed to these changes over and above seasonally adjusted numbers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the effects of the revised student summer job scheme on a summer project (details supplied) in Dublin 16 where 20 participants were sought, as was the case in 1995, but only three were received; if he has satisfied himself that this revised scheme is advantageous to the community and to students in a situation like this where the previous year's participants were largely drawn from the ranks of regional technical college students who are declared ineligible in 1996; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the number of applications received for the student summer job scheme in 1996.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Qst.Quest: the number of students approved to date under the student summer jobs scheme; and the number of students approved on this date in 1995.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The underlying purpose of the student summer jobs scheme is to provide income support for less well off third level students who are excluded from receiving unemployment assistance under the change in social welfare law in 1993 and are unable to find summer work. Students who are not disqualified from unemployment assistance by this 1993 exclusion are not eligible for the student summer jobs scheme.

MainHeading.P: Due to the improvements which I introduced to the scheme in 1995 there was a large growth in the number of students seeking to participate. While £6 million was allocated in the 1995 budget, the expenditure on the scheme rose to £10 million and the numbers participating rose from 9,000 to almost 16,000. I received Government sanction to again spend £10 million on this scheme in 1996 and I am satisfied that approximately the same number will participate this year. In order to ensure the students for whom it is intended actually benefit from this sizeable expenditure, that is, low income third level students who have been denied unemployment assistance since 1993, it was necessary to strictly adhere to the conditions of the scheme.

It is too early yet to provide reliable statistics on the specific take up of either sponsors or students in this year's scheme. This information will not be available until later in the year when the vast majority of sponsors will have submitted claims for recoupment of payments made to students.
The following table is a summary of the number of sponsors in each county who failed to get students for the years 1994 and 1995:
Summary of Sponsors, Places and Students 1994-95

To qualify for the scheme, students must satisfy a means test which is broadly similar to that which is applied for entitlement to unemployment assistance. The means assessment does not make any allowance for voluntary contributions made to pension schemes.

As I pointed out earlier and in previous parliamentary questions, the scheme was never intended for students who are entitled to claim unemployment assistance if they cannot find work. Students in regional technical colleges who have completed a course of study although they may intend to do further courses are not barred from claiming unemployment assistance if they cannot find work and are, therefore, ineligible for the scheme. Every ineligible student included would squeeze out an eligible needy student with no alternative source of income. Students were excluded in previous years on grounds of ineligibility; this is shown in the table.

The number of sponsors offering jobs has increased significantly this year so that the individual sponsors such as the sponsor concerned in Dublin 16 may be experiencing greater difficulty in attracting approved students to their projects than they did in 1995. Each approved student is given a booklet containing a list of all the sponsors. It is a matter for the students concerned to choose the sponsor, and for the sponsor to accept the student.

Where we become aware that an approved student has failed on their own initiative to secure a job under the scheme, my Department makes every effort to assist that student in the search for a suitable sponsor.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Branch Offices.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the discussions, if any, there have been between his Department and the branch managers of local social welfare offices around the country, particularly the branch office at Ardee, County Louth; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the current position regarding the proposed closure of employment exchanges in County Donegal; the outcome of the talks that were held on 7 June 1996 with exchange managers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if he will agree to meet with a deputation of the Branch Managers Association to discuss the future plans, if any, he has for the operation of branch offices.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 702, 724 and 741 together.

Branch managers are represented in negotiations with the Department by the Branch Managers' Association. All discussions on the future of the social welfare branch offices are carried out with the association under the terms of the conciliation and arbitration scheme which covers them.

MainHeading.P: Officials from my Department met with representatives of the Branch Managers' Association on 27 May 1996. The meeting involved a frank and productive exchange of views on both sides. A further meeting will be arranged with the Branch Managers' Association following consideration of the issues arising from that meeting.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Kitt Mr. M. Kitt
Qst.Quest: the number of persons approved in 1996 on the back-to-work scheme and the jobstart scheme; the plans, if any, he has to amalgamate these schemes; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The back-to-work allowance was introduced in September 1993 as an integral part of my Department's programme of initiatives designed to encourage the long-term unemployed to return to the active labour force. This scheme has proved to be a significant success with close to 13,000 persons currently in receipt of the allowance. An independent evaluation of the scheme has just been completed and the final report shows that it is proving to be a success in encouraging the long-term unemployed to leave the live register and return to work. A total of 3,767 persons have been approved so far this year for the scheme.

The jobstart initiative which is aimed at employers was launched by the Minister for Enterprise and Employment at the end of last May. It is too early to provide statistics on the specific take-up rate of this programme.
There are no plans to amalgamate these programmes which are designed to tackle long-term unemployment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The underlying purpose of the scheme is to provide income support for less well off third level students who are disqualified from receiving unemployment assistance and are unable to obtain summer work. Priority, therefore, is being given to enable the maximum number of eligible low income students to participate within the overall financial allocation of £10.2 million for the 1996 scheme.

The person concerned is not affected by the 1993 disqualification on students claiming unemployment assistance and consequently is not eligible for participation in the student summer jobs scheme. If she is unable to find alternative work she may qualify, subject to a means test, for unemployment assistance.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Departmental Surveys.

Qst.Quest: the total cost of surveys undertaken by the MRBI for his Department since January 1995; the number of such surveys undertaken; the costs incurred in respect of each survey; and the surveys, if any, which included a questionnaire to ascertain the level of support for political parties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: In the period since January 1995 the MRBI was selected, following a competitive tendering process, to undertake one independent, quantitative research survey for the Department of Social Welfare.

The main fieldwork was conducted in the period February 1996 to June 1996. The cost of conducting this research by the MRBI amounted to £39,675. The VAT charge of 21 per cent increased the total payment to £48,006.75

MainHeading.P: The objective of the research was, through a sample of 1,000 recipients, to obtain an objective assessment of the nature and levels of service provided to social welfare recipients generally; to highlight areas of service where improvements are required, and, through a sample of 1,000 members of the public, to measure the level of knowledge of and attitudes towards the Department of Social Welfare and its services.
No surveys undertaken by the Department have included questions in relation to support for political parties.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Occupational Pension Benefits.

Qst.Quest: the reason the Government has failed to legislate for the preservation of occupational pension benefits for redundant workers in the private sector; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The Pensions Act, 1990, provides for compulsory preservation of occupational pensions in respect of post-1991 service.

The National Pensions Board in its final report referred to the fact that, although many schemes provide for preservation voluntarily in respect of pre-1991 service, many others do not. The recommendation made in the NPB's first report was that the preservation requirement should not be extended to the period before the introduction of the Pensions Act because of the potential cost implications of sudden new requirements on schemes for which advance financial provision would not have been made. It also indicated that the preservation requirements should be extended to pre-1991 service within a period of ten years of the Pensions Act coming into force. The NPB also recommended that the statutory Pensions Board should continue to keep this issue under review.

MainHeading.P: I recently wrote to the Pensions Board requesting that a number of issues, including this one, be put on the board's policy agenda and that the board prepare a report for me on the issue.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Representation on Pensions Board.

Qst.Quest: the reason deferred pension scheme members have no representation on the Pensions Board; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The method of nominating people to the Pensions Board is set down in the Pensions Act, 1990. I consider the board to be representative of all pension interests, including all members of schemes both active and deferred.

Under the Pensions (Amendment) Act, 1996, which was recently enacted, I provided for an additional two members on the board, both of whom must be trustees of pension schemes, one nominated by the Irish Congress of Trade Unions, ICTU, and one nominated by the Irish Business and Employers Confederation, IBEC. These representatives jointed the board on 5 July 1996.

The Pensions Board represents a balance of interests between the pension scheme members, employers, trustees and the industry generally. It provides an excellent forum for the strategic development of pensions policy over its term of office.

Qst.Quest: the reason there is no competition in the supply of pension schemes within the work place; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: A private occupational pension scheme is an arrangement organised by an employer to provide pensions and/or other benefits to one or more employees on retirement or to surviving dependants on death. A scheme may be on a defined benefit or a defined contribution basis. There is no legal requirement on employers to provide pension benefits or offer a choice of pension benefits to employees under an occupational pension scheme. It is an entirely voluntary arrangement and, while I agree with the desirability of making schemes as flexible as possible, I have no plans, at present, to change the voluntary aspect of this arrangement.
I understand employers establishing pension schemes have a wide variety of choice in the types of scheme they may establish and in the pension products on offer.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Refusal of Allowances.

Qst.Quest: if he will review his decision to refuse a back-to-school clothing allowance to a person (details supplied) in Dublin 7 who has three school-going children, is in receipt of a deserted wife's allowance and whose maintenance payments go exclusively to pay mortgage arrears.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The back-to-school clothing and footwear scheme, which is administered on behalf of my Department by health boards, is designed to assist recipients of social welfare and health board payments with the cost of children's school uniforms and footwear. People on low incomes who are in receipt of family income supplements may also qualify for assistance.

To qualify for the allowance, the applicant must be in receipt of a qualifying payment and must satisfy a means test. The means test takes account of any income over and above the appropriate rate of survivors, widows and widowers, contributory pension plus £5 where the guardian is single, and contributory old age pension plus £5 where the guardian is one of a couple. Where the income of a household exceeds these limits, the back-to-school clothing and footwear allowance is not payable.

MainHeading.P: The person concerned has a total weekly income of £179.10 which is made up of £119.10 deserted wife's benefit, plus £60 maintenance payment which, under the terms of a maintenance order of 3 May 1996, is paid directly to Dublin Corporation in discharge of mortgage payments, including arrears. The income limit for this scheme for a lone parent family and three children is £124.10 but, as the person has a total income of £179.10, she does not satisfy the means test for receipt of the back-to-school clothing and footwear allowance.

Qst.Quest: if he will review his decision to refuse a back-to-school clothing allowance to persons (details supplied) in Dublin 10 who are on disability benefit and who are fostering two school-going children for several years for whom they have only recently received a social welfare payment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The back-to-school clothing and footwear allowance scheme, which is administered on behalf of my Department by health boards, is designed to assist certain recipients of social welfare and health board payments with the cost of children's school uniforms and footwear. Certain people on low incomes who are in receipt of family income supplement may also qualify for assistance.

To qualify for the allowance, the applicant must be in receipt of a qualifying payment and must satisfy a means test. The means test takes account of any income over and above the appropriate rate of survivor's, widow's and widower's, contributory pension plus £5 where the guardian is single, and contributory old age pension plus £5 where the guardian is one of a couple. Where the income of a household exceeds these limits, the back-to-school clothing and footwear allowance is not payable.

MainHeading.P: Orphan's pension is not considered to be a qualifying payment under the terms of the back-to-school clothing and footwear scheme. The orphan's pension, which is a basic social welfare payment, is payable to the guardian and is intended to cover the child's cost of living, including food and clothing. Eligible applicants will receive either a contributory or non-contributory orphan's pension of up to £42.60 per week. In comparison, the allowance paid in respect of dependent children with other social welfare or health board payments is either £13.20 or £15.20 per week. The higher rate of orphan's pension compared to the child dependant allowance rate means that the guardian receives an additional income of up to £1,400 per annum in respect of the orphaned child.
